text.b: I. GENERAL AGRICULTURAL POLICY FRAMEWORK AND HORIZONTAL MECHANISMS
Please provide a general description, with an indication of recent and expected future
developments, of the national and regional farm income policy, production policy and
structural policy (in particular related to rural development), including information on the
national and/or regional institutions (e.g. Ministry of Agriculture, Intervention Agencies, etc.)
involved in agricultural policy formulation, execution and monitoring, as well as on farmers’
organisations. Please indicate as well the budget earmarked and used for this general
Please describe the current land cadastre system and mechanism.

i.b: Economic and social significance of the agriculture sector

page.text: The agriculture sector in Republic of Macedonia covers the primary agricultural production, forestry,
hunting and fishery. The agriculture sector plays an important role in the overall social and economic
environment. In 2003, approximately 14% of the entire working force is earning their income mainly
out of agriculture, hunting and fishery. In the permanent and dynamic process of changing the
economic and political system in the Republic, the agriculture plays a critical role in the social and
From the economic perspective, the share of the primary agricultural production in the Gross
Domestic Product is amounted to 10% to 12%, during the period 1991 – 2002. Taking into the
account the value of the agri-food industry, the value of the entire Agri-complex ranges from 15% to
20% of the entire Gross Domestic Product.
Table 1: Trend of the share of agriculture in the total GDP
Source: State Statistical Office; Prepared by: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
The share of the various agricultural sub-sectors in the agricultural GDP in 2002 is as follows:
production of vegetables is 27%, livestock is 34%, cereals is 13%, plants for forage and cattle feed
as well as meadows production is 10%, industrial plants take up 8%. Vineyards and orchards each
took up 4% of the agricultural value in 2002. The wine production, which is not covered in the table
below, is a very significant branch in the entire economy, and when added to the grape production,
the combined share ranged from 17% - 20% of the agricultural GDP.
Table 2: Share of the agricultural sub-sectors in the agricultural GDP in 2002
Source: State Statistical Office; Prepared by: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
After the independence, the Macedonian agriculture inherited bimodal farm structure: small,
individual/private farms, and large farms in public ownership, so-called Agro-Kombinats. Although the
private land ownership used to be limited within the frames of the policy for maximum allowed private
land ownership, yet around 80% of the agricultural land used to be a property of the private
agricultural farms, and the remaining 20% of the agricultural land used to be a property of the state,
managed by the large, publicly owned farms. As a result of the size limitation of private property/land,
there has been a long process of fragmentation of the small individual farms, whose average size
now is 1.3 ha of arable land, or 1.4 ha agriculture land as per the population census implemented in
During the period before independence, the agriculture policy measures were predominantly aimed
at the small number of large agricultural farms, with an objective to strengthen their role as pillars of
agriculture production development, through a massive budgetary support. These Agro-Kombinats
used to play a large role in supplying agricultural inputs; they managed agricultural machinery, used
to purchase the agriculture production and used to be considered best possible form of Agri complex
development. The small individual farms used to be considered insufficiently productive and with low
accumulation capability. Yet, after the independence, the small individual farms strengthened their
position within the sector. With the breakdown of the industrial complexes/facilities, massive portion
of the labour transferred to the agriculture, which strengthened the role of the individual farms
through their increased share in the overall agriculture production volume. This confirmed the role of
the agricultural sector as a factor of alleviation of the social and economic crisis during the period that

text.b: II. General outline of the agricultural policy

page.text: Till the independence, Republic of Macedonia did not have own agrarian policy, which was in
accordance to the state structure of the common Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia (SFRY).
The first moves towards establishing own, independent agrarian policy were made right after the
declaration of the independence and the introduction of the measures of the market-and-price
protection, i.e. external trade protection. This Macedonian policy in the field of the agricultural and
food sector is in fact a kind of an extension/continuation of the former agrarian policy of the SFRY. It
is mainly based on “market-prices” activities and basically covered market interventions through
customs-based protection and trade limitations, as well as subsidizing prices of certain agricultural
products. This approach, coupled with the sharp decline of the budget of the Ministry of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy (approximately 1% of the state budget of the Republic of Macedonia),
used to sustain for several years, which further sharpened the problems within the sector, and the
dissatisfaction from this macroeconomic policy of both the producers and consumers used to rise
In order to determine the general frame of the agricultural policy and agricultural development in our
country, several strategic documents of unquestionable contribution have been prepared up to date
(prepared by the Macedonian Academy of Science and Arts, the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy, and etc.). These documents initiated reforms in the agrarian policy aimed at
abandoning the system where the prices were developed/defined by the government (state set
prices), as most salient measure for support to agricultural sector. The system of
protected/guaranteed prices remained on force for wheat and tobacco, as strategic products.
The privatisation of the Agri complex in Republic of Macedonia started late and progressed at a
slower pace relative to the other sectors of the economy, because of the sensitivity of the Agri
complex from methodological perspective, the organizational restructuring of the large agro-plants
and the treatment of certain specific infrastructure facilities, equipment and the agriculture land as a
good of public interest. The Agri complex transformation started in April 1996, after the Law on
Transformation of the Enterprises and Co-operatives Running Agricultural Land (“Official Gazette of
The models of transformation, i.e. privatization of the Agri complex of Republic of Macedonia are as
Agricultural/arable land in public ownership is not transformed/privatised. The mode of
utilization/exploitation of this land is regulated by the Law of 1998; agricultural land and other
real estate which had become a state, i.e. public ownership, by means of forced regulations,
is regulated by a special Law on Denationalization (“Official Gazette of RM “ No.20/98, 31/00,
The transformation stands for privatization of the agricultural enterprises into joint-stock
companies and limited liability companies, such that the agricultural land in public ownership
is operated by them based on a contract for long-term land lease.
Agricultural enterprises that, within their structure, used to operate processing capacities and
other technically completed units (livestock farm, factory, wine cellar, fishpond, greenhouses
etc.) were transferred – privatized with a special privatization program, which included
separate valuation of the public capital for each unit independently.

i.b: Measures and instruments of agricultural policy

text.i: Measures of direct/price support and market interventions

page.text: Measures of direct support are enforced through guaranteed purchase prices by the government,
with an objective to support the income of the agricultural producers (farmers) through establishing
higher commodity purchase prices relative to the prices on the world markets. Nonetheless, as a
result of the macroeconomic stabilization program of the Government during the period 1994-1995,
the direct support to the agricultural sector was significantly diminished. In 2001, the government
established the Fund of Agriculture. During its operation, it used to directly support the development
of the agriculture sector through certain measures and activities. This Fund seized to exist on 31

text.b: Table 3: Support to the agriculture sector by the Fund of Agriculture, in 2003
Source: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
Prepared by: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy

page.text: The measures of market interventions used to be implemented through the Commodity Reserves
Bureau that functions as an agency within the Ministry of Finance. The Bureau is competent for
procurement and maintenance of reserves of foodstuffs and food products of strategic significance.
With swift procurement actions, the Bureau maintains the guaranteed purchase price of the
agricultural products of strategic significance, or performs sale in cases of demand on the market.
These interventions on the domestic market are performed if the government makes a decision on
stabilization of the domestic price of food and if there is a need to provide support to the agriculture.
According to the obligations that come out of the Protocol for accession of the Republic of Macedonia
into the WTO, the function of the Commodity Reserves Bureau boils down to securing permanent
supply of basic food products in cases of war or other natural disasters, and shall not intervene with a
The measures of direct support are implemented through the Budget of the Ministry of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy. Out of the direct support in 2002, approximately 75% of the support to
agriculture was intended for direct subsidizing of the agricultural sector. The reforms of the agrarian
financial support aim at moving from quantity-based payments to hectarage (per unit of land under
crops) and headage payments (per head of livestock).
Before the independence, approximately 60% of the Macedonian trade was performed internally
within the former Yugoslav Federation i.e. with the other constitutional republics. The foreign trade
was performed predominantly with the EU member states, the member states of the Council for
Mutual Economic Assistance (CMEA), and other countries from throughout the world. The
agricultural trade policy used to be performed with high custom duties for import of agricultural
products which provided for high protection level of the agricultural sector from competition. After the
independence, Macedonia began a process of trade liberalization which was intensified during the
second half of the 1990’s. The process of trade integration of Macedonia can be divided into regional,
EU integration and global. Republic of Macedonia concluded a series of Free Trade Agreements
(FTA’s) with the neighbouring countries and other traditional partners, thus renewing the traditional
trade relationships which contributed to its regional integration. Republic of Macedonia has signed
FTA’s with the following countries: Turkey, Serbia and Montenegro, Bulgaria, Croatia, Bosnia and
Herzegovina, Ukraine, Albania, Moldova and Romania. The Stabilization and Association Agreement
of the Republic of Macedonia with the EU in 2001, inter alia, regulates trade aspects focused on
increased trade liberalization between the two parties. The Macedonian membership in WTO marked
its global trade integration. In 2004, Macedonia began the negotiations for accession into Central
European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA), for its further trade liberalization.

text.i: Measures for maintenance and renovation of irrigation systems

page.text: Irrigation, as a segment of water management, is a significant factor for stable and competitive
agricultural production in the Republic of Macedonia. Capital investments in maintenance and
extension of irrigation systems, and water accumulation system constructions are funded from the
Budged of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy in the frame of the annual
programs of the Water Economy Directorate.
The mode of utilization of this important resource is stipulated in the Law on Waters, (“Official
Gazette of RM”, No. 4/98, and 19/2000), enacted in 1998. The Government of Republic of
Macedonia places a special importance to the implementation of reforms in organizations and
systems operating in the field of irrigation.
The enacting of the Law on Waters Communities (“Official Gazette of RM”, No. 51/2003), and the
Law on Waters Management Enterprises (“Official Gazette of RM”, No. 85/2003), stipulate the
manner of utilization and management of irrigation systems as a part of the structural reforms in the
agricultural sector, since they all introduce legal and institutional reform in the irrigation sector.
Developing movements regulated by these two Laws cover liquidation of the existing social and
public water management enterprises managing hydro-land reclamation systems as well as
establishing new public entities – water communities and water management enterprises within
which the farmers organize themselves with respect to shared and joint management with the
irrigation systems on the lowest level, level of infrastructure and small systems, and level of irrigation
capital constructions and main infrastructure according to production system.
The measures for rural development are partial and are implemented through programs of various
institutions. The absence of a sole criterion for definition of rural areas is in line with the availability of
limited statistical data, in particular, data on rural livelihoods. The support to rural areas was carried
out through individual programs whose implementation took place in several institutions. At the
moment, institutions that monitor the situation in rural areas are the Institute for Sociological, Political
and Legislation Research and the Agency for Economically Underdeveloped Areas. During the past
period , there was no strategy for rural development. At the beginning of 2004, the Ministry of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy set up a Sector for Support to Agriculture and Rural
Development, with a special department for rural development, in charge of planning and
coordinating faster development of the rural areas. It is planned a preparation of a National Strategy
for Rural Development, which shall be a basis for creation and implementation of a coordinated rural

text.i: Measures for research, development and advisory services in agriculture

page.text: Given all societal and economic changes, the agriculture is prioritized for finding a mode for
enhancement of the volume and quality of agricultural production. By its program, the Ministry of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy instigates research and development in the agricultural
sector. The research is performed in cooperation with the educational institutions, and scientific &
research institutions. The objective is production improvement through introduction of new seed
varieties, quality planting material, selection and reproduction, enhancement of the cattle species and
There have been reforms implemented in the agricultural advisory services with support from the
World Bank Project, which resulted in transformation of the former centres for development of the
individual agriculture into the Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture, founded by the
Law on Establishing Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture (“Official Gazette of RM“
No 03/98). Through direct contact and building up a confidence, the Agency advisers offer
assistance with a purpose to enhance the agricultural production profitability. The Agency has a well
developed farm monitoring system. This system is a single organized network of collection of
structural and financial data on the functioning of individual farms. Currently this system is used by
advisers, but there is a tendency to adjust it to the needs of a wider set of users, through increased
The overall size of agricultural land is 1.32 million hectares (51% of the total country surface). Out of
it, 577,000 hectares are classified as arable land, and 738,000 hectares as permanent pastures.
Agricultural land as basic natural resource is of special significance for development of agriculture,
due to which, in 1998 the legal regulation was changed, and the Law on Agricultural Land (“Official
Gazette of RM”, No 25/98, 18/99, and 2/2004) was enacted, which defines two types of ownership –
public and private. This law also regulates its utilization and management (land lease and
continuation of public ownership of land), as well as protection (from erosion and pollution) and
control of reallocation of agricultural land for non-agricultural purpose. The individual/private farmers
own or rent approximately 80% of the arable land, and the rest is owned or rented by the agricultural
enterprises (privatized or not-yet-privatized agricultural plants and cooperatives). As far as the
pastures, they are owned or rented by the agricultural enterprises.
The pastures as special category of agricultural land are stipulated in a special Law on Pastures
(“Official Gazette of RM”, No.3/98, and 101/2000), which regulates the foundation of the Public
Enterprise for Pastures Management whose competence is management, protection and
improvement of the pastures in public ownership.
The State Authority for Geodetic Works is the competent institution for the issues related to land
cadastre in Republic of Macedonia. This institution implements its activities through its
local/municipal departments/units in 30 municipalities. The State Authority for Geodetic Works
maintains the Land Cadastre and Cadastre of Real Estate. These two institutions represent public
books. The Land Cadastre is a database of data on land and land users/owners with unclear right of
property and other real rights. The Cadastre of Real Estate is main and fully, legally defined system
of the overall physical, ownership and legal component of the real estate (land, buildings).
The Cadastre of Real Estate covers approximately 45% of the territory of the Republic of Macedonia,
and the Land Cadastre covers the remaining 55%. The records on land are maintained based on
submitted requests by land owners, or by Ex officio, performed by a competent institution. Obtaining
specific information from the land cadastre of the State Authority for Geodetic Works still functions
through a one-window system, in absence of a sophisticated equipment, which makes the procedure
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy creates and bears the general agricultural
policy. The Ministry is competent for the agriculture and rural development, forestry and hunting,
fishery, animal and plants health care, water management, organized in 5 sectors, 4 administrations
and two state inspectorates for agriculture and forestry, with a total of 400 employees, the Hydro-
meteorological Directorate – an institution within the Ministry, with a total of 207 employees
The State Agriculture Inspectorate is an institution within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy, and its scope of work is stipulated in the Law on Agricultural Inspection (“Official
The State Forestry and Hunting Inspectorate is an institution within the Ministry of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy, and its scope of work is stipulated in the Law on Forests (“Official
Gazette of the RM” No 47/97, 7/00, 89/04) and Law on Hunting (“Official Gazette of the RM” No
The Veterinary Inspection is within the Veterinary Directorate, an institution within the Ministry of
The Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture performs agricultural-related services,
tailored to the needs of the sole proprietors-individual agricultural producers/farmers.
The Chamber of Commerce of Republic of Macedonia, as defined in the Law on Chambers of
Commerce (“Official Gazette of the RM” No 54/02), organizes and consolidates the positions and
needs of the legal entities operating in agriculture.
Farmer associations, as a form of organization of natural/individual persons, function as entities for
advocacy of their interests, and promotion of certain agriculture branches.
The agricultural scientific institutions are as follows:
Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food;

The reforms in the agricultural sector are performed within the responsibilities that come out of the
Stabilization and Association Agreement with the EU, the Protocol for Accession of the Republic of
Macedonia to the World Trade Organization, the National Strategy for European Integration, bilateral
free-trade agreements and other international agreements.
Pursuant to the Decision on Strategic Priorities of the Government, the National Strategy for
European Integration and the European Partnership Action Plan, the approximation of the
Macedonian agricultural sector to the EU has been set as a priority of the future activities and
reforms. Consequently, the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy prepared the
Strategy for Approximation of the Macedonian Agricultural Food Sector with the Common Agricultural
Policy (CAP) of the EU. This document represents a foundation of the future agricultural reforms that
are yet to be implemented in the forthcoming period.
Pursuant to the Strategy, the reforms in the agricultural sector will be implemented through three
main pillars, i.e. through policy reforms, institutional reforms and legislation reforms. Policy reforms
will be implemented through the following instruments: introduction of the structural measures for
rural development intended for enhancement of the competitiveness of the producers, and support to
environmental protection and organic production, as well as enlargement of the state support to
The status, competences and responsibilities of the functioning of the public enterprises and
agencies for management of forests, waters, pastures, markets, advisory services, agricultural
information system, and other service-oriented and control and inspection bodies, and institutions
related to the agricultural and food sector will be defined, and the new ones that will be formed, will
be in accordance to the results that will come out of the projects and analysis necessary for
implementation of reforms planned in the Operational Plan of the Strategy for approximation of the
Macedonian agriculture and food sector to the Common Agricultural Policy of the EU.
The activities for legislation reforms were initiated as early as 2001, in line with the first National
Program for Legislation Approximation, with which document, the Republic of Macedonia accepted
the obligations for approximation of its legislation with the Acquis Communitaire of the EU, developed
in three directions, as follows: taking over of all legal documents related to the agricultural and food
sector, monitoring of institutional reforms through legal solutions and definition of legal and
systematic frame for management of the sector policy, by enacting of the highest legal documents in
The Law on Agriculture is meant to provide for a sustainable financial infrastructure as well as
transparent implementation of the financial support. The Law on Agriculture should define the
objectives and measures of agricultural policy, institutions for support, eligibility for financial support,
bearers of agricultural policy, monitoring and control of finances in the agriculture, as well as the
administrative and inspection supervision. After the enacting of the new regulation in this field, the
establishment of recordkeeping registers will be a priority of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy. It will serve for entering, processing and updating data contained in the central
database that will be maintained in the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy. Getting
entered into the register will be compulsory for all legal entities and sole proprietors operating in the
agriculture that in order to be eligible for financial support. The process of establishment of cadastral
recordkeeping and register of agricultural land use will be implemented simultaneously with the
establishment of the database. These activities are aimed at harmonization with the overall
administration and implementing control that has been practiced in the EU member states. With the
establishment of the reformed measures and activities for support to agriculture, it is expected that
the measures for financing and agricultural improvement will be simplified, establishment of database
for the needs of creation and analysis of the agriculture policy and reduction of possibility for misuse

text.b: 1. The common agricultural policy measures are applied on a product by product basis. A full
description of the policies currently applied or planned is requested for each of the following
The description should detail the aims, the functioning and the main quantitative elements of
all the product-specific agricultural policy measures currently applied and planned (support
scheme, production or export levy, tax, import duties and equivalent charges and other
border measures like tariff rate quotas and other preferential imports production control, etc.).
Please explain the management of import quotas, whether a system of import/export licences
is used, and whether such a system provides for securities (bank guarantees). “Product-
specific” means a measure which is directed at certain products or product categories, e. g.
livestock headage payments. If you have production subsidy schemes, please provide details
on the management and control of such schemes (procedure for lodging applications for
production subsidies, registration of farmers’ plots in the national farm register, containing
which data, practical control of relevant crops).

page.text: Cereals production takes up 41% of total arable land in the country. Wheat is the most widely spread
with 21%, than barley with 10%, maize 7%, rye 0,8%, oats 0,5%, and rice with 0,4%.

text.i: Objectives and general description of the policy measure

page.text: The Government of the Republic of Macedonia sets out a guaranteed price of soft wheat and durum
wheat to the benefit of the producers.
Pursuant to the Law on Trade (“Official Gazette of RM” No 23/95), the goal of this measure is to
protect wheat producers from monopolistic conduct of the milling and processing companies.
Pursuant to the Law on Trade (“Official Gazette of RM” No 16/04), guaranteed prices shall be
Pursuant to the Law on Stock Reserves (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 47/87 and 13/93), agricultural
and food products for which guaranteed prices are set, are exempted from public bidding procedures.
Pursuant to the Law on Stock Reserves (“Official Gazette of RM”No 68/04) the provision on agro-
food products procurement at guaranteed prices is abolished. It is now carried out at market prices.
The quantity of wheat delivered to milling and baking enterprises by wheat producers.
The calculation of guaranteed price of wheat was made in line with the provision stipulating that
guaranteed price of wheat for each consecutive year should not exceed 70% of the average three-
year world prices plus average three-year shipping and handling charges to Skopje. This price
mechanism is in compliance with the World Bank. The guaranteed price of wheat in 2004 was fixed
having in mind the wheat production costs in the country as well.
The guaranteed price on soft wheat in 1999 and 2000 was set to 10,00 Denars per kilogram. For
The guaranteed price on soft wheat in 2001, 2002 and 2003 was set to 10,50 Denars per kilogram.
For durum wheat, 20% increase is applied.
The guaranteed price applies to all wheat producers throughout the country, with no regional
The guaranteed price of wheat is announced by a Decision adopted by the Government of the
Republic of Macedonia, based on the proposal of the Ministry of Economy in cooperation with the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.

Most-favoured-nation duties (MFN duties), reduced custom duties and tariff quotas which are
implemented in the Republic of Macedonia have been determined on the basis of Free Trade
Agreements, Stabilisation and Association Agreement with European Communities and Protocol of
Accession of the Republic of Macedonia to the WTO.
The MFN duties, determined in accordance with the Protocol of Accession of the Republic of
Macedonia to the WTO are subject to reduction within a transitional period by equal annual amounts
with effect as of January 1 each year.
The liberalisation of the particular agricultural and food products imports has been agreed upon
within the framework of Free Trade Agreements and the Stabilisation and Association Agreement.
The liberalisation is carried out through tariff quotas or through full or partial reduction of duties.
The MFN duty on mercantile wheat in 2004 is 15+0,1 EUR/kg Max. 75, on wheat for sowing it is 0%,
The MFN duty on mercantile rye in 2004 is 5% and on rye for sowing it is 2%.
The MFN duty on mercantile and barley for feed in 2004 is 10%, on malt barley 8% and on barley for
The MFN duty on oats in 2004 is 10% and on oats for sowing it is 0%.
The MFN duty on all maze varieties in 2004 is 0%.

page.text: Subsidies for acquisition of quality fruit planting material.
The goal of this incentive is to maintain and regenerate the existing orchards with certified as
phitosanitary safe and quality planting material.
The measure is particularly aimed to encourage the production of stone fruit (apricots, peaches and
cherries) and small fruit (raspberries, blackberries and strawberries).

was paid through legal entities registered in the Register of importers, producers and finishers of

text.i: Economic importance of associations of fruit and vegetables producers

page.text: Associations of fruits and vegetables producers are registered in the Register of the Federation of
Macedonian Farmers. The objective of the associating is to emphasize and sublimate issues
concerning fruit and vegetable production, as well as the producers’ interests. The main activity of the
associations is to promote and represent the producer interests when negotiating with processors
and purchasers. Some of the associations provide marketing services, and facilitate access to the
foreign markets. In this regard, the associations provide educational and know-how programmes ,
access to market information, as well as exchange of experiences with similar foreign associations. A
small number of these associations have fruit and vegetables storage facilities at their disposal. The
associations’ activities are funded by membership fees, i.e. members’ self-financing and by individual
No detailed analysis on the economic importance of the associations in the overall fruit and vegetable

text.i: Details on significant markets, relevant for establishing production and import prices

page.text: Fruits and vegetables are marketed at the wholesale or retail domestic markets. At the wholesale
markets, large amounts of imported, or produce from domestic growers are accepted, temporarily
stored and prepared for further sale. Organised wholesale markets do not have sorting, classification
and packing facilities at their disposal, necessary to fulfil the particular marketing requirements. The
adoption of marketing strategies through introduction of new regulations in line with the EU standards
is necessary for the strengthening of these facilities. A large portion of produces are retailed to the
so-called Green Markets, and thus distributed do the end consumers. Recently, the wholesale
markets assumed an increasingly important role in distribution of the produce. State Statistical Office
is responsible for collecting, processing and publishing of data on the wholesale and retail markets
No relevant statistical data regarding production prices and import prices of fruit and vegetables is
available in the Republic of Macedonia, due to the fact that no Integrated Agricultural Market

text.i: Indication on the subsidy types on fresh fruit and vegetables processing

page.text: Currently, no subsidies for processed fruit and vegetables are applied.

text.i: Legal relations between the fresh produce processors and the producers

page.text: The agreements between fruit and vegetables grower, and processors on direct purchase of produce
are reached in the interest of both parties.

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: The Legislative basis is the same as given under
The mode of establishing custom duties and tariff quotas, and annual dynamics of reduction of
For certain types of critical vegetables produced in the Republic of Macedonia, seasonal periods of
several months have been set, during which they are subject to different combined custom duties (ad
valorem and specific duty). The goal of the seasonal periods with different duty protection levels on
importation of fruit and vegetables is to guarantee a certain security to domestic producers in that
they know exactly when a higher protection level on import of vegetables is available, but also for
importers as the conditions for import are known in advance for the entire year.
The MFN duties in 2004 on fruits are in range from 0% (coconuts and brazil nuts, for instance); 5%
on almonds; 10% on walnuts, chestnuts, pistachios, dates, figs, pineapple, avocado, mango,
grapefruit; 15% on hazelnuts, lemons, raspberries, blackberries, kiwis, black and white currants; 0.03
EUR/kg on bananas and oranges; 0,04 EUR/kg on tangerines; 30% on pears and quinces; 40% on
plums and strawberries; 45% on cantaloupes, watermelons, apricots, cherries, sour cherries,
peaches and nectarines, to 50% on grapes and apples.
The MFN duties in 2004 on vegetables are in range from 0% and 2% on seed products, 25% on
edible mushrooms, artichokes, asparagus; 30% on lettuce and chicory, spinach, olives; 35% on
cauliflower, broccoli, eggplant, celery, courgette; 40% on carrots, celery, horseradish, to 65 maximum
duty rate on tomatoes, onions, cabbage, cucumbers and peppers.

text.i: Objectives and general description of the policy measure

page.text: The objective of the measure was to protect the production of the oriental small leaf aromatic tobacco
in the Republic of Macedonia, of the 1999 and 2 000 crops.
Guaranteed price serves as a basis for determination of the purchase price by types and classes of
tobacco, for concluding production and purchase agreements between producers and tobacco
In accordance with the Law on Trade (“Official Gazette of RM” No 23/95), the goal of this measure is
to protect tobacco producers from eventual monopolistic conduct of the purchasers.
In accordance with the Law on Trade (
In accordance with the Law on Tobacco, tobacco as declared goods of public well being is
subsidised by a state aid through allocation of funds in the State Budget. If the company-purchaser is
incapable of making the payment due to a bankruptcy or liquidation, the state takes over the
Tobacco sold by a producer to a tobacco company-purchaser. The calculation of the guaranteed
price of small leaf tobacco was made in line with the provision regulating that the guaranteed price of
tobacco for each consecutive year should not exceed 70% of the average three-year global prices
plus the amount of shipping and handling charges to Skopje in the last three years. The provision
was harmonized with the World Bank.
The guaranteed price on 1999 and 2000 tobacco crops was 111 MKD/kg.
t the proposal of the Ministry of Economy in cooperation with the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry
and Water Economy, the Government of the Republic of Macedonia adopted a Decision on
Guaranteed Price of Oriental Small Leaf Types of Raw Tobacco in Leaf (Prilep, Jaka and Jebel).

ewes for reproduction with respect to the last year, are eligible beneficiaries.

rate is paid throughout the Republic of Macedonia.

page.text: Subsidy for acquisition of honeybee colony
The goal of this incentive is to increase the physical volume basis of the apiculture, as
the economy. The acquisition of new honeybee colonies anticipates not only to expand already
established apiaries, but also to encourage new beekeepers to establish their own bee-hive yards.
The subsidies for acquisition of honeybee colonies amount to 40% to 60% of the purchasing price.
- Law on Instigation of Development of the Agriculture (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 24/92,
The Budget of the Republic of Macedonia.
The beneficiaries are mostly individual producers, who acquired a honeybee colony from a producer
The subsidy amount is determined depending on the current market price of a honeybee colony, and
the same subsidy rate is paid throughout the Republic of Macedonia.

text.b: 2. Where the individual measures are applied to more than one product category, they should
be included within the description for each product category concerned. The descriptions
should include at least the following information:
a) name of the policy measure;
b) whether currently applied or planned (planned date of likely introduction);
c) legislative basis (name and reference number of the relevant legal act);
d) objectives and general description of the scheme;
e) eligibility criteria of policy measure;
f) payments (and levies or other indirect support);
g) basis for payments and for their regional differentiation (also the basis for determining the
h) amounts spent since 1999; total and per unit (ranges, if regionally differentiated);
i) use to which the levies/taxes are put (paid into general budget or destined for finance of
particular activities in which case please specify);
In addition, the description for the fruit and vegetables sector should include an indication, if
relevant, of the economic importance of producers’ associations (including number and
percentage of production covered by such associations). It would also be useful to provide
details of any representative markets for determining production and import prices. An
indication should also be included of any subsidies for the processing of fresh fruits and
vegetables and of the legal relationship between processors and producers of fresh products.

page.text: The answer to this question is comprised under

text.b: III. RURAL DEVELOPMENT POLICY AND STRUCTURAL / ENVIRONMENTAL MEASURES
1. Detailed information is required on existing rural development activities as described
Information should be provided on all publicly funded rural development activities, whether
these are implemented as part of integrated programmes, or as stand-alone schemes, and
should include activities financed both nationally and regionally. The information should
cover the legal basis, design, objectives, content, financing, implementation, monitoring,
control and evaluation of the programmes or schemes. Any selection criteria used for the
definition of areas targeted by specific activities should also be described, and the bodies
responsible for the programmes or schemes should be listed.
Rural development activities may include, but are not limited to:
· Increasing the competitiveness of the agricultural sector through support for investment and
restructuring, including investments on farms, support for processing and marketing, land
improvement, reparcelling, irrigation and water management, early retirement, vocational
training, provision of advisory and extension services, establishment of producer groups, and
establishment and operation of quality schemes for agricultural products;
· Enhancing the environment and countryside through support for sustainable land
management, including supporting farming in mountain areas or other areas with particular
handicaps, schemes to protect biodiversity, habitats and landscapes, support for
environmentally friendly farming and forestry methods, including organic farming (please
provide details of the certification system for organic farming);
· Enhancing the quality of life in rural areas and promoting diversification of economic
activities, including the provision of basic services (e.g. roads, electricity, water, sewerage)
for the rural population, the renovation and development of villages, development of new
economic activities to diversify the rural economy, and support for local development
The description of each measure/activity should include the following information:
· The name of the policy measure;
· The legislative basis (name and reference of the relevant legal act);
· The objectives, rationale, and general description;
· Details of the support provided (payment levels etc.);
· The amount spent per year since 1999, and the budget foreseen for future years;
· Number of beneficiaries and average support per beneficiary;
· The administration of the scheme (body responsible etc.).

page.text: Currently, there is no National Strategy/Plan for rural development, representing more complex
approach to the process of rural development in the Republic of Macedonia. The institutional capacity
for inducement of rural development within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
is in its initial stage. In January 2004, a Sector for Support of Agriculture and Rural Development has
been established within the Ministry. Unit for Rural Development has been incorporated within the
Sector, whose task is to start the process of overcoming problems of the rural population by defining
and implementing the rural development policy measures. The rural development policy plays a
particularly important role in promotion of the successful development of rural areas and communities
that depend on the agricultural and alternative economic activities.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy adopted a Strategy for Approximation of the
Macedonian Agro-Food Industry to the Common Agriculture Policy (CAP) of the EU, whereby
preparation of Strategy for Rural Development by the end of 2005 is anticipated. Through the
CARDS 2004 project “Structural and Legal Reforms in the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy", will be provided technical assistance to build up planning mode and institutional capacity
for rural development, harmonised with the practices and policies of the EU, thus providing the basis
for the future acceptance and implementation of the Structural Funds of the EU.
No single institution responsible for the implementation of the rural development policy, as defined in
the EU, is established in the Republic of Macedonia. The support measures for rural areas are
performed through partial programmes, implemented by various institutions.
The partial rural development measures implemented in the Republic of Macedonia are as follows:

text.b: Increasing the competitiveness of the agricultural sector

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: Southern and eastern regions – rural rehabilitation project - IFAD 1
- Law on Indebtedness of the RM at the International Fund for Agricultural Development for
Realisation of the Project for Development of the Southern and Eastern Regions (“Official
The goals of the measure are: improvement of the living standard of the rural population by
increasing household income; improvement of the quality of production and market competitiveness;
reduction of the unemployment among rural population. Furthermore, creation of steady,
economically worthwhile and specific-purpose credit lines, compliant with the rural sector needs. For
that purpose, the project provides loans to the final beneficiaries under favourable conditions – lower
interest rates and more favourable repayment with respect to the commercial loans.
The project started in 1997, with total fund of 8.3 million USD, out of which 7.6 million USD came
from the IFAD loan and 0,7 million USD participation of the Government of the Republic of
Macedonia. At the beginning, areas at an altitude of 800 meters and areas within 5-kilometer border
zone in the southern and eastern regions of Macedonia were covered by the project. Since 1999 all
rural areas in the southern and eastern part of the country have been included. The deadline of the
The funds coming from this credit line cover all agricultural production activities, except tobacco
production and processing, mechanisation procurement and construction of facilities. The following
credit categories, intended for the project’s beneficiaries, have been set out by this credit line:
Up to 10.000 USD loans or up to 30.000 USD loans, intended for individual farmers;
Loans of up to 75.000 USD, intended for small and medium size enterprises.

text.b: Summary of loans by loan category, funded through IFAD-1 project,
Source: Ministry of Аgriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
Data prepared: Ministry of Аgriculture, Forestry and Water Economy

page.text: The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy is responsible for the administration of the
project, and the credit line realisation is conducted through a commercial bank.

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: Project on financial services in agriculture – IFAD 2
- Law on Indebtedness of the RM with the International Fund for Agricultural Development for
Implementation of the Project on Financial Services in Agriculture (“Official Gazette of RM” No
The objectives of the measure are: improvement of the standard of living of the rural population by
increasing household income; improvement of the production quality and market competitiveness;
reduction of unemployment among rural population. Furthermore, creation of steady, economically
worthwhile credit lines, intended for a specific purpose and in line with the rural sector needs. For that
purpose, the project provides loans to the final beneficiaries under favourable conditions – lower
interest rates and more favourable repayment, relative to the commercial loans.
The project on financial services in the agriculture – IFAD 2 commenced in May 2002, and it is
foreseen to be finalized by June 2007. Total funds available are 9,1 million USD, out of which 8
million USD are from the IFAD loan, 0,86 million USD grant from the Kingdom of Sweden, and 0,24
million USD participation of the Government of the Republic of Macedonia. The credit line has been
realised throughout the Republic of Macedonia.
The credit funds launched in October 2003 are intended for all agricultural activities, as well as for
procurement of basic and attachable agricultural machinery. Production and processing of tobacco,
as well as construction of facilities are excluded from the credit programme.
The following credit categories have been provided to the users within the project:
up to 2.000 EUR micro credit, intended for a group of 3-5 farmers;
up to 25.000 EUR credit intended for primary production;
up to 75.000 EUR credit, intended for processing facilities;
up to 75.000 EUR credit, intended for enterprises engaged in trading and export of agricultural

text.b: Summary of loans by loan category, funded through IFAD-2 project, by 30 September 2004

page.text: Source: Ministry of Аgriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
Data prepared: Ministry of Аgriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy is responsible for the administration of the
project, and the realization of credit lines is conducted through business and savings houses.
Note: In addition, technical assistance, and services for better utilisation of the investment and risk
management are available. It includes preparation of business plans and loan requests, advises on
implementation of modern technical and technological solutions, implementation of quality standards
harmonised with the EU, and monitoring of the investments throughout the cycle. The technical
support is provided by advisors assigned to work with individual farmers and agricultural enterprises,

page.text: Programme for Increasing Food Production in the Republic of Macedonia
International agreement between the Governments of the Republic of Macedonia and Japan;
- Decision on Collecting and Using the Foreign Economic Aid Funds for Agricultural
Development of the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM” No 1/98).

text.i: Objective and description of the policy measure

page.text: The objective of the measure is to increase the food production by procurement of modern
In the period of 1998-2003, the measure was implemented through the Programme for Increasing the
Food Production in the Republic of Macedonia, as part of the Official Development Assistance,
The assistance is in a form of a grant awarded by the Japanese Government, intended for annual
projects (2KR projects) for increasing food production in the Republic of Macedonia. Arrangements
for the execution of the programme are set and regulated by an exchange of notes between
representatives of the Governments, acting as an international agreement.
Pursuant to Decision on Collecting and Using the Foreign Economic Aid Funds for Agricultural
Development of the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM” No 1/98) and in accordance with
the agreements, final beneficiaries of the goods supplied through the project are obliged to make a
payment in the amount equivalent to the value of obtained equipment in Denars, to the

text.i: The name of the policy measure
Objective, rationales and general description of the policy measure

page.text: Training programmes are carried out through the IFAD project, and are primarily aimed at increasing
production efficiency and reducing investment risk. The training of the potential credit beneficiaries is
organised in order to familiarise the farmers/credit beneficiaries with the credit lines specifics, as well
as with the process of extension of credits and investment, with regard to the market conditions and
changes in the agricultural policy. The training of the current credit beneficiaries aims at upgrading
the business management capacity and reducing the risk of no profitable and untenable investments.
It comprises of: training for the implementation of up-to-date technical and technological solutions;
familiarizing with the specifics of the potential markets, with the amendments in legislation and
changes in the agricultural policy, as well as with the EU requirements/standards; products marketing
training; acquisition of knowledge on after-harvesting technology (grading, storing, and packing).
The goal of the credit beneficiaries’ training is to introduce the basic features of the credit lines to the
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy is responsible for the implementation of the

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: - Law on Establishment of Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture (“Official
The objective of the measure is to enable more profitable agricultural production in the rural areas by
provision of advisory services in the areas of: crop production; livestock breeding; wine and fruit
growing; gardening and protection; agro-economy, and marketing information. At the same time,
seminars, one-day training programs and practical educational meetings with natural persons –
individual farmers are carried out through the Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture,
in order to increase the product quality and the prosperity of the rural areas.
1,600 natural persons – individual farmers have been using advisory services directly from the
advisors on the basis of the principle of trust. Lodging a request at the Agency for Promoting the
Development of Agriculture by the individual agricultural producers, undertaking full cooperation and
delivering information to the advisors, is a prerequisite for eligibility. Further along, the obtained
information is used for analysis of the situation and providing a quality advice.
Additional 1.400 natural persons – individual farmers are beneficiaries of the training programs,
organised by the Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture. The Agency notifies selected
30 working units within the Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture, assigned to 6
regions, provide advisory services to the farmers.

the Republic of Macedonia. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy intends to

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: Irrigation and drainage of agricultural land by hydro-melioration systems and water resources
Law on Waters (“Official Gazette of RM” Nos 4/98 and 19/2000);
Law on Waters Communities (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 51/2003)
Law on Waters Management Enterprises (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 85/2003)
The Budget of the Republic of Macedonia.
The goal of this measure is irrigation and drainage of the agricultural and other land in order to
stabilise the agricultural production and to attain more rational use of water for irrigation, through
financial participation in the construction of dams for small water storage, running waters
accumulated basins, compensation basins, small hydro-melioration systems, and water supply
systems for sheepfolds and watering holes. Besides the above, participation in the reconstruction
and maintenance of the hydro-melioration systems for irrigation and drainage of agricultural land is
taking place, as well as in the preparing of the project documentation for their construction.
Pursuant to the Law on Waters (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 4/98 and 19/2000), the Public Enterprise
for Water Management is responsible for the management. With the adoption of the Law on Waters
Communities ( “Official Gazette of RM No.51/03) and Law on Waters Management Enterprises
(“Official Gazette of RM No. 85/03) the restructuring of the Water Management Enterprises
commenced, enabling cost-effective management, hydro, irrigation and drainage systems utilisation,
operation and maintenance. Furthermore, the scope of services provided to the end users by the
Water Management Enterprises is defined, and the terms on transfer of ownership of the exploitation
of the systems and objects under the competence of Water Management Enterprises, are laid down.
Finally, prerequisites for normal and successful activity of the Water Management Enterprises are
established, and consequently, the quality of performed services is improved.
Legal entities that are engaged in irrigation and drainage activities according to the Law are eligible
beneficiaries. Elaborated project for construction or reconstruction of the irrigation and drainage

The measures and activities anticipated for the following period are defined in the Physical Plan of

through regional diversity and biodiversity protection, and through protection of the cultural heritage

The National Strategy and Action Plan on Protection of the Biodiversity in the Republic of Macedonia
encompasses on-farm conservation of crops and certain breeds of farm animals, as well as
reintroduction of autochthonous agricultural animal species and plant varieties. The document
creates an opportunity for encouragement and development of organic production, as well as
development of cultivated production of autochthonous, herbs and aromatic plants.

page.text: During the 2003-2007 periods, an inclusion of 1,092 settlements is anticipated. In particular: 500
settlements in the hilly and mountainous areas (109.726 inhabitants), 157 settlements in the border
areas (61.049 inhabitants) and 319 settlements in the particularly underdeveloped areas (99.260
inhabitants). 116 settlements are determined as rural centres (197.337 inhabitants).
Natural persons and legal entities, running investment projects in the settlements defined as
economically underdeveloped are eligible beneficiaries of the funds granted by the Bureau for
The funds approved by the Bureau for the above purposes are disposed through granted financial
participation in particular investment projects. The funds are also approved for other purposes, if they
fulfil the requirements laid down by the Law and the Decisions. The share of the Bureau funds by
certain purposes varies, depending on the status of the area where the investment project in
implemented. In the rural areas, the share ranges from 30% to 60%.
Allocation of funds in the budget of the Republic of Macedonia amounting to 1% of the gross
domestic product, which are transferred to the bank account of the Bureau, is stipulated by the
provisions of the Law on Development of the Economically Underdeveloped Areas.

These goals are achieved through following measures:

An average of 250-300 natural persons in a year use forest planting material for afforestation of their

The funds for implementation of the measures are provided from the annual programmes for
Natural persons and legal entities submit requests for subsidy along with adequate documentation, to

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: Breeding, protection and use of game
Law on Hunting (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 20/96, 26/96, 34/97 and 69/04);
Law on Nature Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No 67/04);
Budget of the Republic Of Macedonia;
Law on the Government of the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM” No 59/00);
The goal of this measure is breeding and protection of the game, enrichment of hunting grounds in
the Republic of Macedonia with autochthonous game species and populating non-autochthonous
game species, as well as protection from harmful animals. This way, the game is used for hunting
tourism, thus providing for a sustainable development of hunting sector in the Republic of Macedonia.
The Government of the Republic of Macedonia assigns the management of the game in the state-
owned hunting grounds to the legal entities. The game from all the other hunting grounds is
concessioned to legal entities and hunting associations (users of the game on the hunting grounds)
for a period of 10 years, by a way of public announcement.
Mutual rights and obligations of the Government of the Republic of Macedonia and the
concessionaries are set out in a concession agreement, regulating the manner and terms of using
the game and pursuing the activity of hunting.
The users of the game on the hunting grounds – concessionaries are bind to pay annual
compensation in the budget of the Republic of Macedonia, amounting to 20% of planned annual bag
(established according to the anticipated figures, on the specific hunting activity basis)
The funds, awarded as compensation for eliminated harmful wild animals, are allocated in the budget
by the Decision adopted by the Government of the Republic of Macedonia.

text.b: 2. Please indicate whether a clear domestic policy, with related instruments, exists for
recognition and protection of geographical indications and traditional names for agricultural
foodstuffs. Describe how geographical indications are protected and any other quality
schemes relating to product origin and other quality characteristics.

page.text: In the national legislation of Republic of Macedonia, the recognition and protection of the geographic
indications and traditional names of agricultural and food products, is under the competence of the
State Office of Industrial Property, and is regulated by the Law on Industrial Property (“Official
Gazette of RM” No. 47/02, 42/03 and 9/04), under the section 4 (articles 164 -212), and the Rulebook
on Origin and Geographic Indication (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 18/04).
Geographic name, as defined by this Law, is a name and/or a designation for a country, region or a
location, which indicates that a product originates from certain specific region.
The section four of the Law on Industrial property (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 47/02, 42/03 and
9/04) is titled as follows: “Origin and Geographic indication of product”. In fact, these are two
categories (articles 164, 165 and 166) for protection of geographic names, and they refer to products
that are specific for special properties, as a result of the conditions in the location of origin (natural
conditions, including the human factor and experience). This protection is tied exclusively to the
specific properties that the product features, exactly because it is produced in a given geographic
The Law on Industrial Property (“Official Gazette of RM” Nos. 47/02, 42/03 and 9/04) refers to
protection of not only agricultural and food products, (EU legislation), but to all goods (TRIPS
Agreement), including wine, which provides for additional protection which is planned for, as defined
in TRIPS, articles 22 and 23 of the Agreement.
In protecting a geographic name of a given product with an origin indication (one of the protection
categories), it is necessary to have a prepared elaborate which describes and calls for all conditions,
parameters that need to be fulfilled, as well as product features, with a special emphasis on its
organoleptic properties. This elaborate is prepared by an institution that needs to fulfil the required
conditions. The content of the elaborate is regulated by the Rulebook on Origin and Geographic
a) The legislation regulates the control of the product. The production, processing and preparation of
the product protected by an indication of origin are performed exclusively on the location of origin.
b) The geographic name can also be protected with a geographic indication, in which case, instead
of an elaborate, it is necessary to have prepared a specification of the given product, from a
producer or a group of producers. In this case, at least one of the production phases is carried out
in the given area (not the entire process).
The protected geographic names can be used for designation/labelling of products only by the
producers that have a recognition of the right to authorised user by the State Office of Industrial
Property, and as such, they are entered into the register that is maintained by the State Office of
The article 168 of the Law on Industrial Property (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 47/02, 42/03 and 9/04)
regulates the protection of traditional names (geographic or non-geographic) of products with a
Pursuant to the article 173 of the Law on Industrial property (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 47/02,
42/03 and 9/04), foreign entities are treated identically with the domestic entities and they can also be
granted a right to protection, in cases when it comes out of international agreements that have been
ratified by Republic of Macedonia, or if it is based on a bilateral agreement for mutual protection,
given that this is regulated in such way by the legislation of the country from which a product

The Law on Organisation and Operation of the State Administration Bodies (“Official Gazette of RM”
Nos. 58/00 and 44/02) defines the competence of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy related to agriculture, forestry and water economy, utilisation of agricultural land, forests
and other natural resources, hunting and fishery, protection of livestock from diseases and pests,
monitoring and exploring the water conditions, maintaining and improving the waters regime and
other items defined with the Law.
The Ministry of Economy monitors the market conditions and possible emergence of goods and
services and the impact of the measures of economic policy, monitors the economic, structural,
technical and technological conditions and proposes measures for realisation of development and
existing economic policy in the domain of production, monitoring of current material balances and the
supply of basic products and goods for general consumption to the citizens, the supply of raw
material to the enterprises, the system and policy of the prices of products and services, and foreign
The Law on Safety of Foodstuffs and Products and Materials in Contact with Foodstuffs (“Official
Gazette of RM” 54/02),defines the conditions for food safety and products and materials that are in
contact with food, the production and trade, rights and obligations of natural persons and legal
entities involved in production and trade with an objective to protect human health, to protect the
consumers from being misled, and to enable free trade in the inland and foreign trade exchange.
The Law on Stimulation of Agricultural Development (“Official Gazette of RM” Nos. 24/92, 32/92,
83/92, 78/93 and 14/96) regulates the right to financial support for certain agricultural products, as
well as financial participation in construction of dams for small accumulations and small hydro-
The Law on Performing Agricultural Activity (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 11/02) regulates the
conditions and method of performing agricultural activities.. As defined by this Law, an agricultural
activity means production, processing and placement of own produced agricultural products on
The Law on Organic Agricultural Production (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 16/04) defines the
production, preparation, marketing and labelling of organically produced agricultural products. The
provisions of this Law refer also to food products and products intended for animal feeding, produced
The Law on Stock Market of Agricultural and Food Products (“Official Gazette of RM” Nos. 32/92 and
83/92) defines the conditions, methods and procedure for establishment of stock markets for
agricultural and food products, with a function to permanently, regularly and in an organised way put
together and concentrate the supply and demand of agricultural and food products; efficient
implementation of trade transactions for agricultural and food products; unification of rules related to
behaviour in stock exchange trade; regulation of a sole system for standardisation of the agricultural
and food products; establishment of a market price and stabilisation of the market of agricultural and
The Law on Quality Control of Agricultural and Food Products in the Foreign Trade Exchange
(“Official Gazette of RM” No. 5/98) regulates the implementation of quality control of certain products
and product processing in the foreign trade exchange. The control of product quality assumes control
of physical, chemical and organoleptic properties of the product, the quantity, declarations,
packaging, labelling, wrapping material, transportation vehicles and the transportation.
The Law on Agricultural Inspection (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 38/04) defines the methods for
organisation, competences, authorisations and implementation of the work of the agricultural
inspection in performing the agricultural supervision.
The Law on Market Inspection (“Official Gazette of RM” Nos. 35/97, 23/99, 7/02) defines the
competences, authorisations and organisation of the State Market Inspectorate.
The state market inspectors perform the duties that are under the competence of the Inspectorate.
The inspectors perform direct inspection supervision over the implementation of laws, regulations
and other general acts by the trade companies, other legal entities and natural persons that perform
activities within their scope of work approved by a law, and they refer to the following: trade of goods
and services, prices of products and services in the production and trade, quality control of imported
agricultural and food products, technical conformity of the products, control of usage of the
measurement units and measures related to trade of goods and services, trade of items made of
precious metals, catering and tourism, artisanship, personal services and protection of the
The Customs Law Tariffs (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 23/03) regulates the following:
Rules and method for calculation of customs duties;
The system of naming goods that are imported or taken inside the customs area of Republic
of Macedonia, or goods that are exported or forwarded from the customs area of Republic of
Macedonia, organised in units and chapters of Customs Tariffs;
System of classification of goods (tariff numbers and tariff marks) in the Customs Tariffs;
Rules for distribution of goods in tariff numbers and tariff sub numbers, as well as tariff
Customs duties that are in force, and
Compulsory unit measures for all tariff marks, depending on the type of goods that is exported
The Consumers Protection Law (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 38/04) defines the protection of the
consumers’ rights, conditions and methods of consumers’ protection, conditions for trade operations
that are of significance to the consumers’ rights, the rights and obligations of the consumers
associations, as well as the competences of the institutions of state administration related to the
The Law on Trade (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 30/04) defines the conditions and methods of trade
operations on inland and foreign markets, and the measures for limitations of trade operations and
The Law on Standardisation (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 54/02) regulates the objectives and
principles of the Macedonian national standardisation, the status of the Institute for Standardisation of
Republic of Macedonia, as well as its tasks, membership and its financing, preparation, adoption and
announcement of Macedonian national standards and their application/utilisation.
The Law on Regulation of Technical Requirements for Products and Assessment of Conformity
(“Official Gazette of RM” No. 55/02) defines the regulation of technical requirements that the products
need to meet before they are released for trade, or set for utilisation in another way; the procedures
for assessment of product conformity to the regulated technical requirements, the validity of foreign
certificates and labels of conformity of foreign origin if the conformity exceeds the regulated

i.b: c) Objectives and general description of the legislation

page.text: The objective of the legislation is to obtain production of nutritional value and health safety
products through the breeding method. The methods of cattle, sheep, and goat breeding are defined
in the National Cattle Breeding Programme adopted on the basis of the Law on Livestock (“Official
Gazette of RM” No. 61/97). Production technology is carried out on the basis of the standard
breeding and processing system and only in a small scale ecological production.
The Law on Livestock (“Official Gazette of RM” No 61/97) and the secondary legislation regulate
cattle breeding and marketing, production of animal products, production and trade of seed and
embryos, and production and trade of feed stuffs, and other issues concerning cattle breeding.
The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No 28/98) and the secondary legislation
thereof lay down animal health protection from diseases, protection from infectious disease carried
from animals to people, veterinary and sanitary check and control, veterinary protection and
improvement of environment and nature, minimum compulsory scope of animal health protection
from diseases, veterinary and health organisation and practise and other issues in the area of
The aforementioned Rulebooks lay down beef, veal, sheep and goat meat production standards.
Having regard to the cattle breeding structure as well as the emphasis placed on milk production in
the last ten years, meat production, and presence of kinds for meat production is insignificant. The
production of beef meat is mainly milk-bred calf and half-bred cattle fattening.
Production of veal meat is mainly based on individual calf production not for fattening but for
slaughtering at a weight of 250 to 350 kilos.
Production of sheep and goat meat is not significant if subtracted as a separate production system.
The biggest fraction is lamb and kid meat, which is especially valued on the domestic and foreign
The sheep are mainly of domestic kinds, or half-bred with merino. The goats breed is mainly Balkan
goat and Sanska half-bred, but there are also goat farms breeding special Alpine breed.
The aforementioned Rulebooks regulate the following issues:
Minimum conditions to be fulfilled regarding quality and other features of animal slaughtered
meat such as packing, labelling, storing, and transport;
Basic compounds and chemical features, organoleptic features and technological treatment to
Minimum conditions to be fulfilled regarding quality of feed stuffs and raw material for feed
The conditions to be fulfilled with regard to slaughterhouses.

with EU law in the livestock sector.
The process of harmonisation of the laws in the veterinary field is detailed in

page.text: The Law on Wine is enacted in 2004 and it stipulates the production and trade of grape and wine and
other grape and wine products; national registry of vine plantations; rights and duties of natural
persons producing and trading wine; and wine description, declaration, labelling, presentation and
The objective of this Law is to protect producers and consumers’ interests; proper functioning of
domestic and foreign markets; quality improvement of wine and grape products; resources
adjustment with regard to the market needs and the needs for oenological substances and
The applicable Rulebooks regulate, in details, vine plantation zoning; grape varieties classification;
wine production procedure; wine categorization; conditions of placing wineon the market; specific
conditions regarding special and sparkling wine; production and placing alcoholic beverages, and
grape and wine by-products on the market ; analysis and control procedure; wine declaration and
labelling; wine quality and application of oenological substances and procedures.
