text.b: c) Objectives and general description of the legislation

page.text: The objective of the legislation is to obtain production of the abovementioned products with regard to
the nutrition value and to provide health safety through the breeding method. The methods of swine
and poultry breeding are stipulated in the National Cattle Breeding Programme.
The production of pork meat is mainly organized in large industrial capacities, and lately on small
family farms whose number is rapidly increasing. Fattening on large farms is intensive and swine are
usually slaughtered when they weigh from 95 to 110 kilos. The system of swine breeding was
modernised after 2000, covering the technology of farrowing to fattening and three streightbred and
Poultry breeding consists of two production categories, as follows: egg production and meat
production. Egg production is organized on large industrial and small family farms. Production
technology is modern and industrially oriented to large farms. Broiler production is in its initial phase
The aforementioned Rulebooks regulate as follows:
Minimum conditions to be fulfilled with regard to the quality and other features of pork meat,
pork bovine, halves, half main parts, slaughtered swine parts intended for consumption
Keeping, storing, packing and transport conditions,
Minimum conditions to be fulfilled with regard to slaughtered poultry meat quality in production
Conditions regarding quality provision and preservation, and conditions with regard to
Minimum conditions to be fulfilled regarding quality of poultry meat products,
Minimum conditions to be fulfilled with regard to obtaining and preserving product quality;
basic substances and chemical composition; organoleptic features and technological
Minimum conditions to be fulfilled with regard to quality of feed stuffs and raw materials for
Conditions to be fulfilled in the slaughterhouses.
The answer under d), e), and f) in this Sector are identical to d), e), and f) in the Sector of beef and
veal meat, sheep and goat meat.

text.b: 3. Details of the plans for future regulatory approximation to EU single Market legislation
should be given (by reference to national strategy programmes, if available). The following
a) detailed plans, including a timetable, for adopting legislation in line with EU laws,
establishing the administrative structures necessary to implement effectively the EU
b) changes required and planned to the existing administrative and enforcement
arrangements, including details of the resource implications (human, financial and

page.text: The accession to the EU will initiate national institutions and bodies to take over entire EU legal
framework related to the market price policy. In order to take over the legal framework, the
agriculture sector has to adjust as follows:
economically, which means in the period before and after the accession to adapt to the
economic relations (price, revenues, competition) of the market as a whole, i.e. of the
institutionally, which means building up a system for undertaking operations aimed at
approximation to the agricultural policy of the Community (institutions, provisions, control,
payment operations, database, standards), which demands reorganisation and prerequisites
in terms of human resources, finances and laws.
The agricultural policy of the Republic of Macedonia is incompliant to the one of EU, and no identical
mechanism for implementation of the market regulations effective in the EU is established in these
The methods of regulation of trade and effects of their mechanisms are different regarding
agricultural products. The trade policy (concerning duty rates, quotas, import and export permits,
preferential import and export, etc) is detailed in the
Furthermore, no framework is established to address existing commodity market failures,
development of commodity markets and introduction of quality standards.. There is no integrated
agricultural market information system, as well as appropriate legal and functional structure for
establishing a dialog with private agricultural producers, aimed at introduction and meeting the
The harmonisation of the legal framework in this field is foreseen to be done by 2007, in accordance
with the National Programme for Approximation of the Macedonian Legislation with the EU
Legislation, Action Plan on European Partnership, and Strategy on Approximation of Macedonian
Agro-Food Sector to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) of the EU.
The priority in the process of approximation is set on establishing the flaws of the economically
significant products, which require elaboration of study on competitiveness, based on continuous
researches and information on different agricultural products. Furthermore, preparation of the primary
legislation is necessary, as well as detailed analysis of the derogations and inconsistencies within the
institutions which currently implement the legislation, particularly on the products intended for export
to EU. The above means approximation to the Common Market Organisations (CMO) of the EU by
implementation of measures aimed at regulating the marketing standards (grading, packing, labelling
The Law on Agriculture is planned to be adopted on which base the Rulebooks on standards of the
agricultural products quality will be prepared. The technical assistance is provided through the
CARDS 2004 Project “ Structural and Legal Reforms of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy”. Within this project initial analyses and policies will be developed.
No detailed evaluation and analysis on the degree of approximation of the national to the EU
legislation has been conducted in the livestock sector yet. In 1997, a Law on Livestock has been
adopted, whose revison is anticipated for 2005 in order to set out the necessary adjustments to the
The process of harmonization in the veterinary sector, including the Law on Animal Identification and
The secondary legislation on the Law on Wine will be adopted by the end of 2006.
Having in mind that the efforts in approximation of the legal legislation relevant to these sectors are
aimed at competitiveness enhancement of the Macedonian agricultural products, the priority is put on
products which have production potential in the country and are also demanded on the markets.
Regarding the approximation of the Macedonian to the EU legislation, the utmost priority is given to
the activities, given bellow, by individual sectors.
Establishment of the legal and formal status of the institutions, as well as coordination of all
institutions within the sector is necessary for development of the system. The process of
approximation demands designation of inspection authorities, responsible for confirming the
approximation in each marketing stage, i.e. bodies authorised for quality control of the fresh fruit and
vegetables, meat, wine and alcohol drinks and their products, starting with the production process,
through the transport and sale stages. It is planned that these bodies be incorporated within the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy – State Agricultural Inspectorate and Veterinary
Directorate. Their adjustment, additional strengthening and staff equipping is necessary to be
capable for execution of the substantial number of new measures related to agricultural products
For the purpose of adapting the agricultural products quality control system to the EU legislation,
simplification of the responsibilities for performing control is planned, as well as their integration and
compliance with EU requirements. The responsibilities are currently divided between two
inspectorates – Agricultural, within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, and
Market, within the Ministry of Economy.
Preparation of a legal basis for the division of responsibilities regarding implementation of the
measures, i.e. amendment of the Law on Organisation and Operation of the State Administration
Bodies (“Official Gazzette of the RM” No.58/00 and 44/02) is planned. The same will determine and
define a comptentent authority for implementation and control of product quality.
In addition, it is planned that operational database on integrated agricultural information system be
established, containing continuously updated agricultural sector information.
In this context, the following stages are planned:
Preparation of legislation on agricultural products quality:
Establishment of a classification system on: beef, i.e. halves (E,U,R,O,P) of pork, i.e. halves
(S,E,U,R,O,P) on slaughter line; lightweight lamb (S,E,U,R,O,P), and on other species of
domestic animals, according to the EU measures. At the moment, pilot project for introduction
of S,E,U,R,O,P standards on pork is executed, with support of the PSO Project of the Dutch
Government and GTZ Project, in collaboration with the Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and
Food. The project on quality of pork on slaughter line is executed in two slaughter facilities.
The results emerged from these pilot projects will produce possible solutions for future
Acceptance and implementation of regulations and quality systems on all kinds of fruit and
vegetables, in line with the EU measures.
Pilot project and preparation of policy in compliance with the principles on regulation of the EU

text.b: 4. Where approximation strategies are likely to require significant investments or changes to
existing arrangements, in either the public or the private sector, the following details should
a) a description of any difficulties anticipated in complying to the new requirements;
b) proposals for any technical or financial assistance which may be offered to the sector
c) whether the legislation fully applies to the entire sector or whether there are derogations or
transitional arrangements (e. g. small businesses. N. B.: certain EU requirements for
slaughterhouses or seed producers for example, are not applied to establishments the
production of which is below a specified level).

page.text: Difficulties in the process of approximation are expected in corect interpretation of the EU legislation
and its integration into the Macedonian legislation relevant to a particular sector. Technical
assistance for overcoming difficulties in the establishement of new and strenghtening of the existing
institutional structure is also needed. For the implementation of the harmonized standards on EU
internal market of agricultural products, additional training of staff hired within offices responsible for
implementation and control of the legal regulation will be necessary. This requires provision of
Technical assistance for establishment of more efficient professional services, hiring experts and
additional funding in all sectors of the internal market of agriculatural products is necessary. No
detailed analysis on required technical and financial assistance exists at the moment, however the
necessary prerequisites will arise from the establishement of the Strategy on Approximation of
Macedonian Agro-Food Sector to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) of the EU. The Strategy
includes detailed studies on implementation and additional analysis, which will enable recognition of
Approximation of the legislation relevant to this area;
Adjustment and strenghtening of the institutional structure;
Staff training for the implementation of common market regulation measures.
In this regard, the initial technical assistance is provided through the Project on Structural and Legal
Reforms in the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy wtihin CARDS 2004.
The initial findings are that the introduction of the internal market measures will have an unfavourable
impact on the processing industry. Thus, a period of time for transition, i.e. adaptation would be
necessary. A detailed list of all capacities (entities) that need to undergo a transition period will be
prepared in compliance with the Strategy on Approximation of Macedonian Agro-Food Sector to the
Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) of the EU.

text.b: 5. Regarding the wine sector, please describe the status of your preparations for the

page.text: The Additional Protocol adjusting the trade aspects of the Stabilization and Assotiation Agreement
between the European Community, of the one part and the Republic of Macedonia, of the other part,
to take account of the outcome of the negotiations between the parties on reciprocal preferential
concessions for certain wines, the reciprocal recognition, protection and control of wine names and
the reciprocal recognition, protection and controls of designations for spirits and aromatized drinks is
a integral and significant part of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement. In addition to trade
aspects, the Protocol covers a development feature for the Republic of Macedonia, in a sense of
promoting quality wine production. Having in mind the importance of this product, efforts are made
toward meeting the selective requirements of the European market, regarding protection and control
of the names and of production standards.
At the moment, the vine management and control system, as well as the institutional and technical
capacity in the Republic of Macedonia are insufficiently developed for attainment of effective
improvement and promotion of the quality wine production. From these reasons, a process for
establishment of vine cadastre has started, in order to enable monitoring and control of the whole
process of grape and wine production.
The vine cadastre will induce an establishment of an adequately processed and analysed database,
for the benefit of all participants in the grape and wine production sector.
The Law on Wine (“Official Gazette of RM” No 69/2004) regulates the management and control of the
vine plantations, which shall be regulated in greater detail by secondary legislation.
The initial technical assistance for establishment of the cadastre is provided through the CARDS
The following activities have been conducted in the initial stage of the establishment of the cadastre:
all participants in the system (inspection offices, wineries, producers, associations and
institutional analysis of the sector, which identified the advantages, as well as the weaknesses
to be removed by adequate measures for the restructuring of the sector. In other words, the
future organisational setup and human resources necessary for the functioning of the system
a pilot region, in which the pilot system will be established, is determined. The pilot region
encompasses 15 cadastral municipalities with a total area of 22,190 hectares, and it includes
about 2000-2500 producers, two wineries, and two regional units of the Ministry of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy (including inspection offices).
Collaboration with State Authority for Geodetic Works is established, as an institution
competent for technical survey of the region.
the global design, operative steps, as well as the necessary hardware and software for
functioning of the system are set.

text.b: VM M Ce ntral Syste m

page.text: After the establishment of the pilot system by the end of 2006, further extension and sustainability of
the vine cadastre throughout the Republic of Macedonia is planned.

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: Enhancement of the individual agricultural holdings competitiveness by reduction of the production
Law on the Government of the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM” No 59/00);
Individual agricultural producers who cultivate their own or leased land and use their own or rented
agricultural machinery are the beneficiaries eligible for receiving diesel fuel coupons. The value of the
coupons received by farmers who meet the above requirements is rated with respect to the area
cultivated: from 0,5 to 1 ha – 750,00 Denars; from 1 to 3 ha – 1.500,00 Denars; more than 3 ha –
On the basis of a Decision rendered by the Government of the Republic of Macedonia, the Ministry of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy was responsible for awarding diesel fuel coupons, on the
basis of previously prepared and submitted documentation by the Ministry's regional units.

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: Enhancement of the greenhouse production competitiveness by reducing the production costs.
Law on the Government of the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM” No 59/00).
The Government of the Republic of Macedonia rendered decisions for provision of 16,000 tons
masut, which partially covers the necessary needs of greenhouse production, as non-repayable aid
for overcoming the price disparity of oil and masut.
The total amount of funds paid was 162.523.430,00 Denars.
The Ministry of Finance - Commodity Reserves Bureau was responsible for the implementation of the

text.i: The name of the policy measure

page.text: Reduction of production costs of the farmers.
Law on the Government of the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM” No 59/00);
By Decision of the Government of the Republic of Macedonia on sale of fertilizer from the commodity
reserves, a quantity of fertilizer intended for farmers was provided at lower than purchasing price.
The basic criterion for eligibility is sowed wheat and barley in the 2003 autumn sowing season. The
maximum quantity of subsidized fertilizer is 50 kg/ha.
6.935.175 kg of Urea 46 fertilizer was sold at 5 MKD/kg.
The Ministry of Finance - Commodity Reserves Bureau, in cooperation with regional units of the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy and the Agency for Promoting the Development
of Agriculture, was responsible for implementation of the measure.

text.i: Type and amount of the aid

page.text: In accordance with the Decision on Defining the Type and Amount of Aid Intended for the
Beneficiaries of Land Vested on Usufruct (“Official Gazette of RM” No 57/03), beneficiaries of land
vested on usufruct are entitled for one-time financial aid amounting to 24,000,00 Denars.
In addition, in accordance with the Rulebook on Defining the Amount of One-Time Financial Aid, one-
time payment amounting to nine (9) average social security payments, but not exceeding two (2)
average net salaries in the Republic of Macedonia is made to the usufruct beneficiary. The necessary
requirements are met, if the beneficiary’s household had received social security benefit up to the
day of conclusion of contract on using land on usufruct. The payment is made consequent the
expiration of the right on social security benefit. According to the Rulebook on Defining the Amount
and Entitlement on One-Time Financial Aid, the unused portion of the financial compensation on the
basis of unemployment amounting up to (6) six monthly payments, but not exceeding (2) two average
net salaries in the Republic of Macedonia shall be paid, pursuant to the Labour Relations Law and
Insurance in Case of Unemployment (“Official Gazette of RM” No 37/97). The eligible beneficiaries
are persons who received financial compensation on the basis of unemployment up to the day of
conclusion of contract on using land on usufruct.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy and the Ministry of Labour and Social
Policy are responsible for the implementation of the measure.

text.b: d) Polocies directed to privatisation of land and other factors of production (including the

page.text: Pursuant to the Law on Agricultural Land (“Official Gazette of RM”No 25/98,18/99, and 2/04), the
agricultural land as goods of general interest of the Republic of Macedonia enjoys special protection
and it is exploited under terms and a mode determined by this Law.
These two types of ownership are defined by the Law: private and state ownership. State-owned
Pursuant to the Law on Restructuring of Enterprises and Cooperatives with Socially-Owned Capital,
which Pursue Economic Activities on Agricultural Land (“Official Gazette of RM”No 48/00 - revised
text), state-owned agricultural land may not be subject to transformation.

text.b: Privatisation of enterprises of agricultural and food sector

page.text: Restructuring of the Enterprises and Cooperatives with Socially-Owned Capital, which pursue
economic activities on agricultural land is regulated by the Law on Restructuring of Enterprises and
Cooperatives with Socially-Owned Capital, which Pursue Economic Activities with Agricultural Land
(“Official Gazette of RM”No 48/00 - revised text). Enterprises and cooperatives in which state-owned
resources were invested are subject to privatisation.
In accordance with the Law, restructuring of enterprises, i.e. cooperatives is carried out by organising
the enterprises as Joint-Stock Company or Limited Liability Company. In the case of the
cooperatives, they are organised as Limited Liability Companies, if the cooperative’s management

text.b: Table 1. Privatised agricultural enterprises, by privatisation models (until 31.12. 2003)

Source and prepared: Privatisation Agency of the Republic of Macedonia
Until the end of 2003, a total of 429 agricultural enterprises with 20.521 employees were privatised,
whereas the privatisation of 15 enterprises with 1.160 employees is currently underway. The total
value of the privatised enterprises amounts to EUR 201 million, whereas the value of the enterprises
to be transformed is estimated to EUR 10 million.
Privatisation of the enterprises through investments is possible by the way of buying stocks and
shares on the Macedonian Long-Term Securities Exchange, and also by public bidding procedure.
The Law on Privatisation provides equal treatment of domestic and foreign investors. In the 1996-
2002 period, direct foreign investments concerning the process of privatisation in the agriculture were
made mostly in the processing sector. In particular, in brewery industry (USD 35,3 million), baking
industry (USD 14 million), tobacco industry (USD 6,6 million), soda and juice production (USD 0,6

The state subsidy in the credit policy is executed through the measures implemented by the
Government of the Republic of Macedonia, and specific-purpose credit lines intended for agriculture,
provided in collaboration with foreign donors.
1. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy and IFAD (International Fund for
Agricultural Development) have developed commercial credit lines for this sector, realised through
commercial and savings banks with lower interest rates with respect to the market’s and favourable
payment conditions. A revolving fund and technical assistance to the credit beneficiaries were also
established. In addition, the Ministry of Local Self-government participates through the Bureau for
Economically Underdeveloped Areas in subsidising the interest rates of the IFAD 1 and IFAD 2 credit
beneficiaries living in underdeveloped municipalities. The total amount of funds for this activity is
sourced from the budget of the Republic of Macedonia.
Within the Project for Rural Development of the Southern and Eastern Regions IFAD 1.751 loans
amounting to USD 4,2 million were granted to individual farmers and small and middle sized
enterprises, with an interest rate of 6% until 30 September 2004 inclusive.
The time limit for repayment by the end users including the grace period is one to six years,
depending on the purpose of the loan.
Within the Project for Financial Services in the Agriculture IFAD 2.233 loans amounting to USD 2,5
million were granted to individual farmers and enterprises engaged in processing and trade of
agricultural products, with an interest rate of 6%, i.e. 7% on funds realised through commercial
banks, until 30 September 2004 inclusive. The time limit for repayment by the end users including the
grace period is one to seven years, depending on the purpose of the loan.
Besides the provision of favourable loans, technical assistance is made available through the IFAD

page.text: In the 2001/2002 period, FAO provided non-repayable aid in agricultural intermediate materials (seed
material, fertilizers and fodder), in order to help the farmers in the areas affected by the armed
conflict and the drought. 50.000 agricultural households were encompassed. The total amount of the
aid in this period was USD 4,5 million.
In 2004 FAO provided non-repayable aid for agricultural intermediate materials (seed wheat and
fertilizers), aiming at facilitating the economic situation of the families pursing agricultural activities,
who were affected by the floods. Total amount of this subsidy is about USD 390.000.

page.text: 17.000 tons of corns were allocated in 2001 as a subsidy measure. The allocation of corn was

cows, i.e. 50 heads of sheep, on the basis of previously prepared lists for allotment, rendered by the
regional units of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy. The allocated quantities
were set to 135 kg/head of cow and 1,5 kg/head of sheep. The Ministry of Finance – Commodity
Reserves Bureau was responsible for the allotment.

page.text: The following five Institutes for research and development carry out researches in the area of
agriculture and forestry: Agricultural Institute, Institute for Cattle Breeding, Institute for Tobacco and
Institute for Southern Fruits, as well as the Veterinary Institute in the area of veterinary health, which
was integrated within the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine. Part of researches was carried out through
the high educational institutions from the area of agriculture, in particular Faculty of Agricultural
Sciences and Food, Faculty of Veterinary Health, Faculty of Biotechnical Sciences and Faculty of
300 full-time employees and staff hired for individual projects are engaged in the institutions pursuing
On the basis of the Law on Scientific Research (“Official Gazette of RM” No 13/96 and 29/02),
Ministry of Education and Science is responsible for funding most of the researches. Funds for
research project are granted according to the proposed programs, or by a public bidding procedure.
Summary of paid funds in the 1999 - 2004 period is presented below. The Ministry of Education and
Science paid 74,718,865 Denars for this purpose, to the following institutions:
Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food
Institute for Southern Agricultural Products – Strumica
Source and prepared: Ministry of Education and Science
In addition to this funds, the Ministry of Education and Science have granted 5,050,000 Denars on
co-financing of 10 development and innovation projects.
Although the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy has no obligation to finance
agricultural researches, it is however included in conducting scientific projects with funds sourced in
regular annual programmes of the sectors and directorates. The summary of funds intended for
Source and prepared: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
Furthermore, the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy initiated programme for
applied researches in the 1999 – 2002 period, supported by the World Bank through the Support of
the Individual Agricultural Producers Project. The goal of the project was instigation of creative
proposals on research projects directly concerning practical problems of farmers, and possible
technological and management innovations that would directly or indirectly reduce the costs and
increase the production profitability. The research projects were directed towards testing
management and technological innovations, in line with the principles of on-farm research.
Furhtermore, the testing were carried out at several producer facilities located in a single agro-
ecological zone, during which inspected producers implementing traditional technology and
24 research projects were carried out for a period of three years. Additional financing of seven
projects on market innovations research was provided.
The reforms on advisory services in agriculture executed with support by the World Bank Project,
have integrated former Centres for Development of Individual Agriculture that had existed as
individual legal entities, into a single national institution – Agency for Promoting the Development of
Agriculture (AIDA). This Agency was founded pursuant to the Law on Foundation of Agency for
Promoting the Development of Agriculture (“Official Gazette of RM” No 3/98). This transformation
created conditions on better quality of advisory service aimed at increasing the quality and quantity of
the farming production. The World Bank project which was finalised in August 2002 focused its
support towards equipping the Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture and upgrading
its experts by emphasising larger scale self financing, as a supplement to the existing budget.
The difficulties regarding direct payments of the given advises by the farmers impose further need of
support in order to accomplish functionality of the advisory services. Besides funds sourced from the
state budget, the agency budget is filled in by additional support coming from projects and own

text.b: Financing of AIDA salaries, overheads and activates from budget funds, by year

page.text: Source and prepared: Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture
The organisational setup of the AIDA is 30 operating units clustered in six regions, whereas the
functional setup is based on six working groups with the following respective specialities: husbandry,
livestock breeding, gardening with protection, agro-economy, and information and marketing. At the
moment, the Agency has 126 employees, most of them agronomy engineers, agro-economists, IT
A director appointed by the Government manages the Agency, and a Management Committee
appointed by the Government on the proposal of the Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy is responsible for administration of the Agency. Three of the Management Committee
members are representatives from the scientific institutions, and another six members are agricultural
The responsibilities of the AIDA encompass: provision of immediate advisory help to the individual
agricultural producers for implementation of adequate measures in the agricultural production
process with practical application of scientific and technical knowledge in compliance with the market
needs; cooperation and strengthening of the agricultural associations; executing a portion of
measures of the Program for Instigation of Agricultural Development; establishment and operation
utilisation of information systems in the agricultural production, including establishment of record
keeping regarding monitoring of its profitability and cost-effectiveness; preparation of informative
organs encompassing domestic and foreign information sources from the area of agriculture for the
purposes of individual agricultural producers, and vice versa – information coming from farmers for
the purposes of other interested parties.
Pursuant to the Law on Foundation of Agency for Promoting the Development of Agriculture of the
Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM” No 24/92, 32/92, 23/92, 78/93, and 14/96) on the
basis of Article 2, the Agency carries out the following activities:
1. Provision of immediate help to the farmers regarding implementation of adequate measures, by
not less than one-month attendance at the farm:
In husbandry, vine production and fruit growing - introduction of new technologies in growing,
correct usage of fertilizers, selection of varieties and types, set up and cultivation of plantation
nurseries, conducting demonstrative tests involving new varieties and technologies and
In livestock breeding – suggestions regarding implementation of measures for improvement of
production features, provision of better diet in order to produce better quality products (milk,
An average of 80 advisors have come into immediate contacts with 1,600 farmers, i.e. an advisor
works with an average of 20-25 farmers. The advisors with particular speciality carry out an average
of 2-30 demonstrative tests, during which new varieties and technologies are implemented.
2. Collaboration with farmers associations and local self-governments by participation of advisors in
establishment of the associations as well as participation in their boards aimed at better functioning
3. Directing the agricultural producers toward production of agricultural crops and products in
compliance with the market demands. Data obtained from the farm monitoring system, containing,
inter alia, agricultural production value indicators, are used as informative and comparable indicators,
contributing to setting out directions for production according to domestic market demands.
4. Direct execution and carrying out part of the measures derived from the Programme for
Instigation of Development of the Agriculture in collaboration with respective offices in the Ministry of
5. Transfer of expert knowledge and applicable scientific achievements in the agricultural production
field to direct agricultural producers, through permanent upgrading of the advisors in the scientific
institutions (domestic and foreign support) and bringing the knowledge forward to the field.
6. Giving directions in the selection and rational use of appropriate agricultural machinery and
equipment for plant and livestock production by defining technical and economic advisory package
on rational use of mechanisation by specific types.
7. Professional training of the agricultural producers by organising seminars, courses, consultations,
etc. During a year, AIDA comes into contact with 1600 farmers, holds 6 seminars, 70 one-day
trainings, 40 practical educational meetings, and group meetings with an average of 1.000 – 1.200
8. Organising competitions in high crops, fairs, exhibitions, etc. On regional level, AIDA helps in
organising farmers for participation in competitions, fairs, exhibitions, etc.
9. Preparation of agricultural research proposals. AIDA has five portable laboratories at its disposal
with a capacity of 50-60 samples testing, depending on the needs and financial capabilities. This also
enables instruction regarding the selection of the most appropriate crop according to the arable land
quality. Furthermore, most suitable crop with respect to the most appropriate period of year with
implementation of adequate methods or crop rotation is also suggested.
10. Establishment and utilisation of information systems in the agricultural production. AIDA has
modern IT system—software (designed with the help of a World Bank consultant) at its disposal,
designed to respond to the users’ demands. The database, continuously built by the AIDA, is
accessible to several users (Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, farmers, State
Statistical Office, Farm Accounts Data Network, science experts, etc).
11. Provision of assistance to the agricultural producers for establishment of records keeping
concerning agricultural production, its profitability and cost-effectiveness, and development of the
farm monitoring system into operative agency for gathering data for FADN in the Republic of
Macedonia. The farm monitoring system includes keeping records on 800 farms, with continuous
activates since 2001. The system allows entering of about 200 different types of data related to farm,
from which it derives adequate profitability and cost-effectiveness calculations as well as other farm
indicators. It also provides conducting activities on keeping accounting records on a farm. During
2002 and 2003, the system was constantly upgraded, particularly as a part of the project for
improvement of agricultural statistics in the Republic of Macedonia carried out by the Swedish
Agency for International Development Project – SIDA. Financial and technical aid has been provided
for conducting monitoring and approximation of the quality of data gathering and processing to the
standards required for introduction of national network for monitoring and gathering farm accounts
data – FADN. It is anticipated that the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy shall
commence with official activities on establishment of FADN during 2005.
12. Issuing informative advertising magazines, brochures, manuals, in which information regarding
innovations in the agriculture from domestic and foreign sources are published. Technical and
economic advisory packages-services include brochures and manuals, and an informative journale is
published quarterly as well. In this respect, a media plan for informing through the mass media and
13. Other expert and applicable measures, when required. In this respect, 18 advisors have been
trained for monitoring, forecasting, determination of pests and plant diseases, on which regular
reports are rendered and forwarded to the Faculty of Agriculture and the Ministry of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy. The advisors suggest adequate measures on overcoming particular
A project for improvement of advisory offices supported by the Swedish Agency for International
Development Project – SIDA is currently underway. It aims to connect all the participants in the
process of giving advisory services to the individual agricultural producers, with an implementation
period of eight to ten years. On the basis of the agreement between the Government of the Republic
of Macedonia and the Kingdom of Sweden a contract on upgrading advisory services was concluded,
aimed at improving the communication and information access, introduction of advisory services in
accordance with the farmers’ needs, building up advisory service provision capabilities, and bringing
science and techniques closer to the farmers.

text.i: 2. Advisory activities, supported by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy

page.text: The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy participates in financing different advisory
activities and training programmes by organising seminars and consultations, and publishing
reference literature from the agriculture field. The activities are funded with finances allocated to
regular annual programmes of the sectors and directorates.

text.b: Summary of the allocated funds intended for advisory activities, by programmes

page.text: Source and prepared: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
No integrated Market Information System is established in the Republic of Macedonia. The
requirements of the market subjects concerning relevant and timely information on prices, on supply
and demand as well as on market trends are partially met through the Market Information System,
established within the State Statistical Office (SSO), and also through several sub-sectoral market
information systems, set up mostly with international donors support.
a) Market Information System within SSO
The agriculture sector within the SSO gathers prices on a weekly basis, and prints the reports once a
month. The prices are gathered on the wholesale markets (of fruit and vegetables in Skopje and
Strumica), 13 retail markets and six livestock fairs. The data is gathered on the so-called market day
on each of the marketplaces respectively, i.e. four to five times a month. The gathered prices are: the
highest, the lowest, and the most frequently occurring, whereas the average prices are not
calculated. The quantities put on sale are also gathered from the livestock markets. The reports
include price comparison set against previous month or year, with no further data analysis. The
National Accounts Sector calculates the prices of the producers, which are currently used for

text.i: Market Information Systems funded by international institutions

page.text: USAID – Land o’Lakes established Market Information System on dairy products, meat and livestock
markets, within so-called Macedonian Agribusiness Marketing Activity (MAMA), which has six-year
experience in gathering, processing and distribution of information from and to incorporated sub-
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy aims to provide more coordinated approach
on development of the Market Information System, thus enhancing the interconnection and
upgrading of the already established Market Information System components.

text.i: Public Enterprise for stock exchange operations “Agro-Stock Market”.

page.text: The public enterprise for stock exchange operations was founded in 1992, pursuant to the Law on
Stock Market on Agro-Food Products (“Official Gazette of RM” No 32/92 and 83/92) and the Decision
on Foundation of Public Enterprise for Stock Exchange Operations “Agro-Stock Market” (“Official
Gazette of RM” No 32/92), with a purpose to improve the placement of agro-food products on the
market. The operationalisation of activities of the Public Enterprise “Agro Stock Market" was
anticipated through development of a stock market including collection and distribution centre, where
the supply and demand of agro-food products would be concentrated, and the sales would be carried
out by a way of auction. Due to the restrictive capacity of the Budget of the Republic of Macedonia in
the last twelve years, the infrastructural working conditions of the Public Enterprise “Agro Stock
Market” with estimated necessary investments of approximately EUR 6 million have not been fulfilled.
The enterprise has nine employees in two sectors. The Agro Stock Market performs services to its
members upon annual agreements concluded with individual agricultural producers or agro-industrial
companies, charging them on the basis of annual membership fee. “Agro Stock Market” receives
commission amounting to 0.7% on all contracts concluded between membership fee payers, i.e. 1%
Recently, the enterprise has conducted its activity mostly in the area of marketing and commercial
operations related to the market placement of agro-food products, as follows: participation on
conferences and business forums, presentation of the Macedonian production on fairs (in the country
or abroad) and publishing agro stock market information material.
The funds for enterprise activities are allocated from the budget of the Ministry of Agriculture,

text.b: Funds approved for support of current activities of the Public Enterprise “Agro Stock Market”

page.text: Source and prepared: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
Structural and organisational reforms of the enterprise are necessary, due to problems occurring in

text.i: Other support to marketing and promotional activities

page.text: 1. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy participates in financing activities related
to promotion of agricultural production and improvement of market placement of the agricultural
products on exhibitions and fairs. The activities are funded with finances allocated to regular annual
programmes of the sectors and directorates.

text.b: Summary of the allocated funds intended for marketing and promotional activities

page.text: Source and prepared: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
2. On the basis of the Law on Foreign Trade Operations (“Official Gazette of RM” No 31/93, 41/93,
of Funds Generated from Duties Paid by the Business Entities on Import and Export of Products,
Goods and Services (“Official Gazette of RM” No 36/02, 36/03, and 31/04) was adopted. The Ministry
of Economy and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy are responsible for the
implementation of the Programme concerning agriculture products. The following activities are
1) Compensation on a portion of the business entities’ expenses for:
consulting services on introduction of quality system;
certification of quality system or certification of products;
preparation of promotional materials intended for foreign markets;
2) Co-financing of the business entities' expenses for the business forums,
3) Organisation of business forums, educational, informative and promotional seminars and training
4) Organisation of promotional campaigns on domestic and foreign markets,
6) Research on international target markets, sector studies, and etc.
7) Compensation of a portion of expenses ensued from projects related to activities on recognition-
branding of products and services on foreign markets.
50% of the total funds allocated to the annual programmes funded from the duties paid by the
business entities amounting to 0.1% of the import/export value of the products, goods and services,
are intended for compensation of expenses in competence of the Ministry of Economy, as well as
additional 25% are provided for the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy. The
expenses of a business entity-beneficiary may not exceed 200,000 MKD.
Pursuant to the Law on Organisation and Operation of the Civil Service Bodies (“Official Gazette of
RM” No 58/00), inspection offices within the agriculture and forestry sectors act as ministerial bodies,
whereas the inspection offices from the area of veterinary health care and of water management are
State Agricultural Inspectorate employs 26 inspectors, whereat 23 of the state agricultural inspectors
are assigned in the Ministry’s regional units.
Operations and activities of the State Agriculture Inspectorate are with respect to the competences,
- Law on Organisation and Operation of the Civil Service Bodies (“Official Gazette of RM” No
Law on Inspectorate for Agriculture (“Official Gazette of RM” No 38/04);
- Applicable laws within the agriculture field, pursuant to which inspection supervision is
Law on Agricultural Land (“Official Gazette of RM” No 25/98 and 18/99);
Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No 25/98 and 6/00);
- Law on Seeds, Planting and Multiplication Materials, Type Adoption, Certification and
Protection of Plant Variety (“Official Gazette of RM” No 41/00);
Law on Livestock Breeding (“Official Gazette of RM” No 61/97);
Law on Wine (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 69/04)
Law on Tobacco (“Official Gazette of RM” No 69/96 and 15/98);
- Law on Quality and Quality Control of Artificial Fertilizers (“Official Gazette of RM” No 10/73
Law on Fishery (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 62/93);
- Law on Instigation of Development of the Agriculture (“Official Gazette of RM” No 24/92,
Law on Field Assets Damage Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No 20/90 and 83/92);
Law on Pastures (“Official Gazette of RM” No 3/98 and 101/00);
Law on Pursuing Agricultural Activity (“Official Gazette of RM” No 11/02);
Law on Production and Traffic of Narcotic Drugs (“Official Gazette of the SFRY” No 13/91);
Law on Designating Bodies for Conducting Specific Operations in the Field of Production and
Traffic of Narcotic Drugs (“Official Gazette of RM” No 24/83);
Law on Organic Agricultural Production (“Official Gazette of RM” No 16/04);
Law on Fire Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No 43/86 and 37/87);
Law on Agro-Food Stock Markets (“Official Gazette of RM” No 32/92); and
Law on Waters (“Official Gazette of RM” No 4/98).
State Agricultural Inspectorate operation derives from the Programme of the Inspectorate for
Agriculture and the Programme for Activities of the Ministry. In addition to the regular inspection
supervision, the State Agricultural Inspectorate is also in charge of the complaints submitted by legal
entities, associations of citizens, natural persons as well as by other state bodies and institutions.
The activities within the competence of the State Agricultural Inspectorate include:
Supervision of the circulation of: plants, products, means, items and other things defined by
the agricultural legislation, in imports, exports and re-exports via state border;
Examination and control of: agricultural land, agricultural crops and plantations, records on
breeding and other cattle, areas of processing and finishing agricultural products, equipment
used in these procedures, processing and finishing process in each of the stages up to the
finished product, areas for storing and maintaining agricultural products, green and cattle
markets, agricultural technique, business quarters, business books, contracts, inventory lists
as well as other documentation relevant for acquiring insight in entities’ activities in
compliance with agricultural and other legislative.
Supervision of the overall quantities of products of plant origin, encompassed with the
certificate issued by authorised legal persons and institutions.
The phytosanitary control on the border crossing points is described in more details under

text.b: 2. State Inspectorate for Forestry and Hunting

page.text: State Forestry and Hunting Inspectorate employs 17 inspectors, whereat 14 of the state forestry and
hunting inspectors are assigned at the Ministry’s regional units.
Operations and activities of the State Forestry and Hunting Inspectorate are within the authorities,
- Law on Organisation and Operation of the Civil Service Bodies (“Official Gazette of RM” No
- Material Laws from the agriculture field, pursuant to which inspection supervision is
Law on Forests (“Official Gazette of RM” No 47/97 and 7/2000);
Law on Hunting (“Official Gazette of RM” Nos. 20/96, 26/96, 34/97 and 69/04);
- Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” Nos. 25/98), as well as current activities
stemming from Programme of Activities of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Programme of Activities of the State Forestry and Hunting Inspectorate.
Pursuant to the provisions and regulations of the above laws, the State Forestry and Hunting
Inspectorate and within its competence conducts the following activities:
Inspection supervision and control of the activities related to upkeep, protection and
exploitation of forests, objects, devices for felling, transport, processing and trade of wood;
Inspection and control of implementation of specific plans, annual development plans and
programmes for forest management and carrying out of specific hunting economic activities
and annual plans, as well as of other documents from the area of hunting;
Inspection and control of deforestation, cattle grazing , and other activities;
Inspection of hunting grounds and breeding facilities, protection and use of wild game
animals, control on observing contracts for wild game animals assigned on concession;
Inspection and control of forest region and forest plants, plants in circulation, plants and plant
Inspection and control of the seed and planting material.
The Veterinary Inspection office is incorporated in the state veterinarian department within the
The department has 62 employees. 50 of them are veterinarian inspectors, 10 assigned on 9 border
crossing points and the remaining 40 in 30 regional units of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
State veterinary inspectors execute inspection supervision activities pursuant to:
The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No 28/98);
The Law on Safety of Food and Products and Materials Coming in Contact with Food (“Official
- The Law on Pharmaceutical Drugs, Supplementary Treatment Substances and Medical
Devices (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 21/98), and
The Law on Identification and Registration of Animals (“Official Gazette of RM” No 69/04) and
The structure and competences of the veterinarian inspection are detailed in
By the Minister's special authority, regional agricultural and forestry inspectors are responsible for
conducting activities fallen under Water Economy Inspectorate’s scope of responsibilities. This is due
to the fact that the two positions in the Water Economy Inspectorate within the Water Economy
Water Economy Directorate is responsible for the operations related to administration of waters,
Law on Waters (“Official Gazette of RM” No 4/98 and 19/00);
Law on Waters Management Enterprises (“Official Gazette of RM” No 85/03), and
Law on Waters Communities (“Official Gazette of RM” No 51/03).
Pursuant to the provisions and regulations of the above laws and within its competence, the Water
Economy Inspectorate conducts the following activities:
Control of water and water management facilities exploitation (whether or not they are built
and operate according to the conditions laid down in the licenses), as well as control of other
occurrences that may create qualitative and quantitative changes in the water regime;
Control and insight in the water dams construction from the viewpoint of water regime, as well
as maintenance and monitoring. It also performs control of the reservoirs filling and releasing
regime as well as condition of the dams of special state concern.
Protection of the water streams from unplanned exploitation of sand and other;
Water managements and water community activities supervision.
The current organisational setup and equipping of inspection offices is insufficient for solid and
thorough conduct of the competences anticipated in law. The principal problems are insufficient
personnel, lack of modern means of work, lack of coordination of activities, and insufficiently
State Geodetic Institute is responsible for operations with regard to survey, cadastre and registering

text.i: Other measures from the regular annual programmes of the sectors and directorates within the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Economy

page.text: Other measures within the regular annual programmes of the sectors and directorates within the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy encompass support of various activities, which
are not comprised in the previously presented description of measures and activities. The remaining
funds from the Programme for Instigation of Agricultural Development are intended for several
servicing agricultural measures, for initial support of a Grapes and Wine Fund, support of the
intervening purchase of agricultural products and financial support of the Register Office, selection
and monitoring of cattle breeding. From the Programme for Expanded Forest Production and from
the Programme for Protection of Plants from Diseases and Pests, for services performed by the
authorised Informative Diagnostic and Prognosis (IDP) offices within the Faculty of Forestry, Faculty
of Agricultural Sciences and Food as well as in following institutes: Agricultural Institute, Institute for
Southern Fruits and Institute for Tobacco.

page.text: No farms structure research was conducted between 1999 and 2003. The most recent data on farms
structure by size and by regions as well as on farms distribution and typology are based on the data
from the 1994 Census of population, households, residencies and agricultural holdings.
The absence of Farm registry is an additional impediment that disables the conducting of structural
Final preparations for conducting Agriculture Census are in progress in State Statistical Office. The
Census shall provide data on agricultural land and tillage areas, livestock population figures,
agricultural production, agrotechnical measures, machinery and equipment, facilities in the economy,
forestry, fishery and labour. All the instruments (census forms, instructions for census takers, control
books and census conduct methodology) have been prepared. The field activities shall be conducted
in October 2005. The text of the Law on 2005 Agriculture Census has been prepared, harmonised
and approved. The next step is the adoption procedure.
The data gathered from the census shall constitute a basis for establishment of Farm registry. The
initial structural farm research is to be conducted in 2009 in accordance with the timescale of the
long-term development of the agricultural statistical system.

4. Farm incomes for full time farmers (gross added value per annual labour unit) including
comparison with average gross wages of employment outside agriculture.

page.text: Data on this question are gathered from economic accounts for agriculture.
Data on farmers’ income pursuing agricultural production as their primary economic activity (gross
added value per annual labour unit) result from gross added value (agricultural economic activity
minus interim consumption) divided by the overall labour in the agriculture (Annual Work Units).
Data on agriculture external average gross payments are gathered from the statistical research on
employees and salaries. Comparison of the revenues generated from a farm by farmers working full
time, with the agriculture external average gross payments (their participation in agriculture) is
calculated according to NCA classification (National classification of activities)
The data are presented in the attached tables.

It is foreseen that the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy during the forthcoming

for some more significant agricultural products.

text.b: 15. Market prices for each product category, indicating the stage of production and the

page.text: Market prices are monitored through three types of researches in the Agriculture Unit within the
State Statistical Office. The following researches are being currently conducted:
Report on the agricultural product prices on retail market.
Report on the agricultural product prices on wholesale markets.
Report on live cattle on livestock markets.
The following markets are included in the monitoring of prices: 13 retail markets, 2 wholesale markets
and 6 livestock markets. The data are gathered on a daily basis, in particular on a so-called market
day on each of the marketplaces respectively. In that way, the data from each of the markets are
gathered 4-5 times per month, depending on the number of weeks in a particular month.
These data are gathered for each product: the highest, the most frequent and the lowest price. As far
as wholesale markets and livestock markets are concerned, the offered quantities are also
The most frequent price is determined as of a particular product price appearing most frequently on a
particular market, regardless the product quality.
Number of heads/quantity in kilograms stands for an offer of a particular product on a particular
market. No data on production stage and quality are tracked.
Data on: Prices on livestock markets, wholesale and retail markets are attached in the tables.

Economic agriculture accounts are processed in the State Statistical Office, in the Sector for
National Accounts, in accordance with data received from the Sector for Business Statistics
– Unit for Agriculture, Hunting and Forestry. Administrative data sources are also used.
Data gathered from the following researches are used in the processing of economic
Purchase of agricultural products of individual farmers - monthly
Output of the agricultural holdings and cooperatives own production - monthly
Survey on number of cattle heads owned by the individual agricultural households,
Annual report on agricultural holdings’ and cooperatives’ own cattle.
Monthly report on circulation of agricultural products on the market.
Purchasing price of the raw materials, means of work and services in the agriculture
These researches provide quantitative and value data on: realised production by individual
agricultural products, output of the own production, purchase from the individual producers,
number of cattle in the reporting year, data on slaughtered cattle as well as the necessary
data on the calculation of the interphase consumption.
During 2003, an auditing of the current accounts of the Economic Account in Agriculture
(EAA) took place (for the 1998 – 2001 period) as well as on account on EAA for the 2002-
2003 period, according to the Manual on the Economic Account in Agriculture, EAA 1997
National Activity Classification harmonised and comparable to the European Classification
NACE Rev 1, in particular for the Sector A – Agriculture has been used for processing of the
Production, output, purchase, number of cattle heads, slaughtered cattle as well as input
Product-level data are gathered on the basis of the national Nomenclature of Agricultural
Products and Services, processed on the basis of the Classification of the Products by
Activities (CPA) and harmonised with the “lists of distinctive agricultural products” – Manual
for Economic Accounts in the Agriculture, EAA 1997 (audit 1.1)

page.text: In the Republic of Macedonia, the character/type of settlements is determined administratively.
Before the Law on Territorial Division of the Republic of Macedonia and the definition of the units of
local self-government (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 49/96 and 56/96) was enacted, there used to be a
classification of urban and rural settlements according to which all statistical data used to be
prepared, and was used for population sampling for surveys performed by the State Statistical Office.
The Law on Territorial Division of the Republic of Macedonia and the Definition of the Units of Local
Self-government (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 49/96 and 56/96) did not classify the settlements
according to the criteria for urban and rural areas, and thus created a legal vacuum, given the fact
that the previous classification was not possible to be used any more, because of separation of
certain settlements that used to be parts of the City of Skopje before, and migrated to municipalities
that were not parts of the City of Skopje. This vacuum was partially filled by the Spatial Plan of
Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 39/04), as well as by the new Law on Territorial
Organisation of the Local Self Government in the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM”
No.55/04), which should be brought into effect after the implementation of the local elections, at the
beginning of 2005. The data on the population (section “e”) is prepared based on the criteria of the
Spatial Plan of the Republic of Macedonia.

text.b: VII. FOOD LEGISLATION, PHYTOSANITARY, VETERINARY, AND ANIMAL NUTRITION
1. Provide flowcharts/organigrammes outlining levels of competencies and showing
management lines to describe the structure and organisation of the services in charge of food
safety. The division of competencies and the links between central, regional and local level
should appear clearly (degree of decentralisation/devolution of competence should be
defined). Please describe the current status and the foreseen evolution with a precise

page.text: Administrative bodies competent for food safety are the Ministry of Health, - Food Directorate and the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy: Veterinary Directorate , Plant Protection
The organigram and description of the Ministry of Health - Food Directorate is given under Chapter 1
Free movement of goods. (For more details see
The organigramms on competent administrative bodies within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry
and Water Economy, the structure of inspection services, as well as of authorised scientific and
specialised institutions (laboratories) are attached to the text of the answer of this question.
At present, the system of food safety is regulated by two basic laws and secondary legislation
Law on Safety of Foodstuffs and Products and Materials in Contact with Foodstuffs (“Official
Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No 28/98)
as well as other secondary legislation that has impact on the food safety chain, which are presented
in the competece description of the administrative bodies.
Pursuant to legislation, the food control system is integrated within two ministries, i.e. bodies
Food Directiorate is the competent body within the Ministry of Health, and the Veterinary Directorate
within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.

page.text: Veterinary Directorate is authority competent for safety of foodstuff of animal origin in all production
and marketing stages, pursuant to the Law on Safety of Food and the relevant provision referred to in
On the whole, the Veterinary Directorate is an administrative body with competencies and
responsibilities of a national veterinarian service. The competencies of the Veterinary Directorate
Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM No 28/98);
Law on Safety of Foodstuffs, Products and Materials in Contact with Foodstuffs (“Official
Law on Pharmaceutical Drugs, Supplementary Treatment Substances and Medical Devices
Law on Animal Identification and Registration (“Official Gazette of RM” No 69/2004).
In addition to the foodstuff of animal origin control, the following activities fall under the competence
of the Veterinary Directorate , in accordance with the abovementioned Laws: control of animal health
; control of animal diseases contageous to humans; veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of
products, raw materials and waste materials of animal origin; prevention in animal reproduction;
veterinary protection and improvement of the environment and nature; control of the minimum
compulsory scope of animal health protecion; organisation and conducting of acitivites in field of
veterinary meicines ; veterinary health inspection and control of feedignsstufss ; control of production,
circulation and usage of veterinary medicinal products; animal marking and identification and
In line with its competences derived from the above Laws, the Veterinary Directorate control covers
the entire chain of of foodstuff of animal origin. From the viewpoint of the safety of foodstuffs in the
narrow sense, the Veterinary Directorate has competence, as follows:
Inspection and control of: slaughter, animals fish, snails and toads; products and raw
materials of animal origin; and feedignstuffs . The Veterinary Directorate is also responsible
for inspection of veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of: products; raw materials of
animal origin; feeding stuffs ; water for animal nutrtion ; water in the production facilities;
storage, processing of products and raw materials of animal origin,.
control of animal communicable diseases contageous to humans (zoonoses);
veterinary-sanitary inspection and control at Borider Inspection Post of the consigment of
animals, products and raw materials of animal origin, and feedingstuffs.
veterinary-sanitary inspection and conrol of: establishments and equipment for slaughtering;
establishments and equipment for processing meat, milk, fish, snails, toads, honey and eggs;
establishments and equipment for their storage, chilling and freezing; raw materials and
additives used in processing of the products of animal origin.
veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of the transport means of animals, and products,
raw and waste materials, before loading and after unloading;
All the competences fallen under the Veterinary Directorate are centralised on the level of the
Directorate. The enforcement and execution are conducted by the state veterinary inspectors
assigned to the regional offices, and the state veterinary inspectors assigned to the Border Inspection
By separate agricultural laws, in the safety of food systems are included also:

page.text: Plant Protection Directorate is an administrative authority included in the safety of foodstuffs of plant
origin by conducting plants health care and performing control in the circulation, pursuant to the Law
on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette RM” No 25/98 and 06/00).
The competences of the Plant Protection Directorate stem from:
Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 06/00);
Law on Quality and Quality Control of Artificial Fertilizers (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 10/73).
Pursuant to the above laws, Plant Protection Directorate, regarding food safety, controls the network
of foodstuffs of plant origin, as well as materials used in the agricultural production process, and in
Safety check-up - control of agricultural and products of plant origin.
Health check-up of plants, safety control of products of plant origin, control of the transport
means and packaging on the location of forwarding for export, and issuing phytosanitary
Gives expert advises to the producers on correct usage of the protection materials and on
application of integral plant protection, by correct usage of the treatment equipment.
The role of the State Agricultural Inspectorate in the official control system is to indirectly monitor the
safety of foodstuffs of plant origin, in accordance with these applicable laws in the field of agriculture:
Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00);
Law on Quality and Quality Control of Artificial Fertilizers (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 10/73
Law on Organic Agricultural Production (“Official Gazette of RM” No 16/04);
Law on Wine (“Official Gazette of RM ” No. 69/04);
Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 61/97).
The State Agricultural Inspectorate controls the entire chain of primary production of foodstuffs of
plant origin, the animal nutrition , and performs inspection and control of consigment of plants,
products and plant protection materials on the border crossing.
As far as the foodstuff safety is concerned, the Inspectorate is indirectly competent for conducting
inspection supervision and control of: circulation of plants, products and plant protection materials;
contamination of agricultural land; processing procedure in each stage up to the finished product;
areas for storage and maintenance of the agricultural products; green markets and livestock fairs;
application of ecological materials in the wine production.
In a case of a suspicion on improper plant product, the inspector takes a necessary quantity of
samples in order to establish the standards and quality. If an irregularity comes up, the product is
As far as the administration and management of the State Agricultural Inspectorate are concerned,
they are conducted on a central level, i.e. neither regional nor local level of decision-making is taking

page.text: All employees in the Veterinary Directorate are part of the civil service, i.e. have a civil servant status.
Human resource issues are defined by the Rulebook on Job Classifications in the Ministry of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, according to which 89 positions have been established in
the Veterinary Directorate. 77 of them are fullfil, and the rest are vacant.
Detailed presentation of the human resources is given in the table:
For the purpose of enhancement of effectiveness in conducting the activities and functions of the
Veterinary Directorate, 54 doctors of veterinary medicine have been hired on the basis of contractual
Veterinary Directorate has satisfactory material resources at its disposal within the internal
organisational units: equipped premises including direct telephone lines; IT equipment including
internet connection; software systems (National epizootiological IT system); IT system for
identification and registration of animals; IT system for Border Inspection Post veterinary inspection;
motor vehicles and professional working equipment for the inspectors, provided in large portion by
Salaries and other finances regarding carrying out of regular activities and operations of the
Veterinary Directorate are allocated from the Budget of the Republic of Macedonia. Funds are
planned on an annual basis in coordination with the Ministry of Finance.
All employees in the Directorate are part of the civil service, i.e. have a civil servant status. Human
resource issues are defined by the Rulebook on Job Classifications in the Ministry of Agriculture,
Advisor for plant protection materials and
Works defined by the laws in the field of plant health protection and other relevant legislation, are
carried out by one advisor and five regional reporters.
The administrative procedures, registration of plant protection materials, registration of fertilizers with
no standard provision, and the registration of legal entities engaged in production and circulation of
protection materials, are carried out by one adviser in the Plant Protection Directorate.
The premises equipping of the Plant Protection Directorate is satisfactory, which is not a case with
the IT and laboratory equipment necessary for determining of the plant diseases and pests as well as
with other technical equipment in the regional centres.
A portion of equipment necessary for the Directorate activities was provided through the CARDS
Salaries and other finances regarding carrying out of regular activities and operations of the Plant

Employees in the State Agriculture Inspectorate have a civil servant status.
