page.text: The State Agriculture Inspectorate is managed by a Director, appointed by the Government of the
The 43 employees are assigned on the following positions: 1 director, 2 heads of departments,
1independent officer, 23 agriculture inspectors covering 33 regional units, and additional 16 covering
10 border crossing points. The inspections on 4 border crossing points are conducted on call.
Hiring new inspectors for plant protection on border crossing points is anticipated after introduction of
State Agriculture Inspectorate has official automobiles at its disposal, which are property of the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy. The computerisation is on a very low level.
Regional unit inspectors' disposition of personal computers is partial, with no internal network or
The equipment of the border crossing posts is unsatisfactory. The working conditions on all border
crossing posts are appropriate in terms of the office and laboratory rooms, but inappropriate in terms
of 24-houroperations. Due to the inadequate working conditions, the border crossing working hours
are limited to 12 hours a day. The laboratories at the border crossing posts have no adequate
laboratory equipment for fast determination of harmful organisms.
Salaries and other finances regarding carrying out regular activities and operations of the State
Agriculture Inspectorate are allocated from the budget of the Republic of Macedonia. Funds are
planned on an annual basis in coordination with the Ministry of Finance.

text.b: 3. The current structure has to be described as well as the evolution foreseen. Two sets of
organigrammes: one with the current structure and another one with the planned future
structure (the dates foreseen for the establishment of new entities should be indicated).

page.text: The Veterinary Directorate is an administrative body with competences and responsibilities of a
The competences and duties of the Veterinary Directorate are stemming from the Law on
Organisation and Operation of the Civil Service Bodies (“Official Gazette of RM ” No58/00 and
44/02), as well as from these lex generalis: Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No
28/98); Law on Safety of Food and Products and Materials Coming in Contact with Food (“Official
Gazette of RM ” No 54/02); Law on Drugs, Additional Medicines and Medical Accessories (“Official
Gazette of RM ” No 21/98); and Law on Identification and Registration of Animals (“Official Gazette of
In accordance with the above laws, the Veterinary Directorate has competence and is responsible for
conducting managerial and administrative activities, as well as supervisory and inspection activities,
derived from the above mentioned laws and secondary legislation relevant for: safety of foodstuff of
animal origin; animal health protection; control of animal diseases contagious to humans; veterinary-
sanitary inspection and controls of products, control of raw material and waste materials of animal
origin; prevention in animal reproduction ; veterinary protection and improvement of the environment
and nature; control of the minimal compulsory scope of animal health protection; organisation and
conducting of activities in field of veterinary medicines; veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of
feeding stuffs and other products in animal nutrition; control of production, circulation and usage of
veterinary medicinal products ; identification and registration of animals and welfare of animals.
In compliance with the Rulebook on Job Classifications in the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy, the following 6 departments have been established in the Veterinary Directorate:
Department for Animal Health, Department for Veterinary Public Health, Department for
Identification and Registration of Animals, Department for Veterinary Medicinal Products ,
Department for Veterinary Legislation, and Unit for State Veterinary Inspection.
A diagram on the current structure of the Veterinary Directorate of the Republic of Macedonia is
given in the supplementary document chart.
The Directorate is managed by a Director, appointed by the Government of the Republic of
Management and administrative activities are conducted by the departments within the Veterinary
1. Department for Animal Health is responsible for the following activities: monitoring of the
epizootiological situation in the country; elaboration and implementation of effective control
strategies; preparations of orders and prohibitions on imports and transit of consignments of
live animals, products, raw materials and wastes of animal origin, as well as of feeding stuffs,
artificial insemination semen , ovium and embryos; preparation of programmes for
monitoring, control and eradication of contagious and parasite diseases; issuing orders and
plans for prompt intervention in the event of extremely dangerous diseases outbreak;
monitoring the efficiency of the measures laid out by the annual order for measures for
prevention, control and eradication of animals contagious diseases; preparation of the
legislation and the secondary legislation; communication and collaboration with international
organisations (OIE, EU, FAO, WHO) in the area of animal health.
2. Department for Veterinary Public Health is in charge of the following activities: registration of
and approvals to the production establishments engaged in production of foodstuff of animal
origin; maintain records on production establishments ; rendering conditions, upon which
imports of products of animal origin are carried out; preparation of one-year plan on residues
control in the foodstuff of animal origin; contacts with other government bodies and institutions
3. Department for Veterinary Medicinal Products conducts the technical, normative legal, and
administrative affairs in accordance with the legislation relevant to veterinary medicinal
products and medical accessories applied in the veterinary medicine. The Department is
responsible also for conducting activities of the National centre related to monitoring of
undesirable effects of veterinary medicinal products, as well as for activities concerning
preparation of veterinary-sanitary requirements conditions for imports of feeding stuffs and
issuance of veterinary-sanitary permits for import of feeding stuffs and other products for
4. Department for Identification and Registration of Animals organizes, directs and coordinates
the operations related to identification and registrations and keeping records on animals and
performs activities for implementation of system of animal identification and registration, as
well as controls of performers of these operations and of record keeping.
5. Department for Veterinary Legislation organizes, directs and coordinates the operations
related to preparation of drafts, laws and secondary legislation relevant to veterinary
medicine, and participates in preparation of programmes, analysis, information and other
reports in field of veterinary medicine.
6. Department for State Veterinary Inspection coordinates, combines and directs the work of the
state veterinary inspectors, for the purpose of timely, legal and quality execution of the affairs
and tasks regarding implementation of established veterinarian health policy. Furthermore, it
conducts the activities and tasks that fall under competence of the veterinary inspection, and
monitors implementation of the veterinary health laws and provisions.
The affairs related to inspection supervision on enforcement of relevant laws and secondary
legislation are carried out by the veterinarian inspectors assigned to the regional offices , and the
state veterinary inspectors assigned to the border inspection post , all incorporated in the Department
More detailed description on the competences and activities of the veterinary inspection is given
The foreseen evolution of the Veterinary Directorate is given in the Business Plan for the Veterinary

national plant protection office. The competences and duties of the Directorate are stemming from
the Law on Organisation and Operation of the Civil Service Bodies (“Official Gazette of RM ” No
59/00) as well as from these laws:
Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” Nos. 25/98 and 6/00);
Law on Seeds, Planting and Multiplication Materials, Type Adoption, Certification and
Protection of Plant Variety (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 41/00),
Law on Quality and Quality Control of Artificial Fertilizers (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 10/73).
In accordance with the above laws, the Plant Protection Directorate has competence and is
responsible for conducting management and administrative activities, and control derived from the
above mentioned laws and secondary legislation relevant for: plant health care protection; safety
control on plants and products of plant origin; plant protection materials, seed and planting material;
registration of plant protection materials and of fertilizers.
In compliance with the Rulebook on Job Classifications in the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy, the Directorate is managed by a Director, appointed by the Government of the
Republic of Macedonia. Operations in the Plant Protection Directorate are coordinated through 1
advisor for plant health protection, 1 advisor for plant protection materials and fertilizers, and 5
regional reporters, accountable to the director.
The following operations are carried out in the Plant Protection Directorate:
plant health protection; monitoring of the outbreak and spreading, anticipating, diagnosing and
determining of certain significant plant pests on the basis of particular programmes; providing
producers with information and recommendations on optimal deadlines and adequate
protection; interventions in cases of quarantine or outburst; rendering regulations; issuing
permits for import of harmful organisms for scientific research purposes; preparation of
reports and analyses on health condition of plants and plant products, aimed at establishing of
appearance and spreading of pests in the country and abroad; establishing the degree of
infestation in cases of quarantine, as well as determining newly discovered pests; establishing
infected areas; keeping records; coordinating the operations of the institutions; exchanging
information related to emergence and spreading of pests, in accordance with the bilateral,
regional and international agreements. Scientific and professional institutions in the plant
protection field are also included, conducting scientific and technical operations throughout
Plant protection materials - preparation of regulations; administrative procedure on
registration of plant protection materials; processing of reports on biological (vegetation-
related) researches, physical and chemical (laboratory) researches, and of the producers'
files; co-ordination of the activities of the Committee for Plant Protection Material;
administrative procedure on registries for production, retail and wholesale; keeping registries
of legal entities pursuing production, retail and wholesale of plant protection materials (PPM);
registration procedure for fertilizers not included in the standard list; keeping records on
produced and circulated plant protection materials; international cooperation and information
A diagram on the current structure of the Plant Protection Directorate - Ministry of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy is attached to the answer of the question.
The implementation of the European Partnership Action Plan of the Government of the Republic of
Macedonia, which anticipates approximation of the legislation in the area of plant health protection
until 2007, will establish future organisational setup and functions of the Plant Protection Directorate.

The competences and duties of the State Agricultural Inspectorate are stemming from the Law on
Organization and Operation of the Civil Service Bodies (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 58/00) and the
Law on Agricultural Inspection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 38/04),as well as from these laws:
Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” Nos. 25/98 and 6/00);
Law on Seeds, Planting and Multiplication Materials, Type Adoption, Certification and
Protection of Plant Variety (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 41/00);
Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 61/97);
Law on Quality and Quality Control of Artificial Fertilizers (“Official Gazette of RM ” Nos. 10/73
Law on Organic Agricultural Production (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 16/2004);
Law on Wine (“Official Gazette of RM ” No. 69/04).
The State Agricultural Inspectorate is a body incorporated within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry
and Water Economy, authorized for conducting inspection supervision in the field of safety of food of
vegetable origin in the primary agricultural production, as well as for health control and inspections of
trade of agricultural and forest plants and products of vegetable origin. Furthermore, it is responsible
for: inspection of international consignments (imports, exports, re-exports and transits); issuance of
phyto-certificate on plants' health condition; taking samples; to order phyto-sanitary measures;
performing control on the compliance of the seed and planting material imports with national
regulations, and ISTA and OECD; control of the shipment's documentation of plant protection
materials imports in terms of permit, expiring date and labelling. The controls are performed at 14
border crossings and 11 loading locations, determined for health inspections by the Government of
The current structure of the State Agricultural Inspectorate incorporates two departments,
Department for Agriculture and Department for Plant Protection. The Inspectorate is managed by a
Director, and the departments by two Heads of departments and one independent officer. The
inspection supervision is conducted by 23 state agriculture inspectors in 33 regional units, and by 16
In accordance with the Law on Agricultural Inspection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No38/04), all
agricultural inspectors have university degree education, obtained at Faculty of Agricultural Sciences
The adoption of the Strategy for Approximation of the Macedonian Agro-Food Sector to the Common
Agricultural Policy of the EU will strengthen the responsibilities competences of the agricultural
inspection within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.

page.text: The Assembly of Republic of Macedonia is the supreme legislative institution of the country. Each
MP, the Government of the Republic of Macedonia or at least 10,000 voters (authorised law
proponents) have the right to propose adoption of a law. Bearers of the law drafting are the
The Assembly adopts laws by majority of votes of attending MPs, but not if less than one-third of all
MPs attend, unless particular majority is specified in the Constitution.
After adoption, laws are published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Macedonia.
Secondary legislation (rulebooks, orders, decisions) on specific areas, for whose adoption legislative
basis in respective lex generalis exists, are adopted by a competent minister on the basis of the
These secondary legislation acts need prior approval of compliance with the Constitution of Republic
of Macedonia and with other legislation, issued by the Secretariat of Legislation. After adoption, the
secondary legislation acts are published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Macedonia.
Draft laws, other regulations and the acts submitted by the Government within its competences to the
Assembly, contain compulsory analyses (review, summary) on their compliance with the EU
Pursuant to the Law on Organisation and Operation of the Civil Service Bodies (“Official Gazette of
RM ” No58/00 and 44/02), civil service bodies performing inspection tasks are obliged on mutual
collaboration in conducting inspection activities of mutual interest, as well as on collaboration with
other state administration bodies. More exactly, if an irregularity arises during inspection supervision,
they are obliged to notify the competent body, i.e. the inspection office, which undertakes adequate
measures within its competences further on.
Regarding food safety, the Food Law Safety and Materials coming in contact with food (“Official
Gazette of RM ” No.54/02) establishes a mechanism for coordination of competent ministries with an
aim to fully cover the food chain.
By the provisions of this law, for the purpose of thorough coverage of the food chain, direct
collaboration and co-ordination between Veterinary Directorate, Food Directorate, State Agricultural
Inspectorate and Plant Protection Directorate, Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning and
Ministry of Economy will be attained through Committee for Macedonian Codex on Food. This
Committee has been founded by the Ministry of Health, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy, Ministry of Economy and Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning, upon the
proposal of competent ministers, as well as of distinguished scientists and professionals, and

and enforcement and their respective responsibilities. Describe mechanisms of co-ordination

page.text: Specification of the competent authorities that are in charge of control activities and enforcement,
Administrative bodies in charge of performing control on activities and of enforcement of the
legislation in the area of food safety are the Ministry of Health - Food Directorate and the Ministry of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, through these bodies: Veterinary Directorate, Plant
Protection Directorate and State Agricultural Inspectorate.
The immidiate activities of inspection supervision, as well as of control on the enforcement and
implementation of lex generalis and secondary legislation stemming thereof, are conducted by:
1. State food inspectors within the Food Directorate
2. State veterinary inspectors from the Department of State Veterinary Inspection, within the
3. State Agricultural Inspectors and Inspectors at border crossings , within the State Agricultural
The Food Directorate is in charge of the enforcement of the general provisions from the Food Law
Safety and Materials in Contact with Foodstuffs (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 54/02), related to safety
of food and foodstuff of non-animal origin. Detailed description and chart of the Ministry of Health -
Directorate for Food is given under Chapter 1 Free movement of goods (see
The Veterinary Directorate is in charge of performing control of acitivites and application of the laws
concerning foodstuff of animal origin. The Directorate is also responsible for compliance with the
general requirements stipulated by the Law on Safety of Food and Products and Materials Coming in
Contact with Food (“Official Gazette of RM ” No.54/02), and with the provisions on veterinary health ,
derived from Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98); Law on Drugs, Additional
Medicines and Medical Accessories (“Official Gazette of RM ” No.21/98) and Law on Identification
and Registration of Animals (“Official Gazette of RM ” No. 69/04), as well as from secondary
The Plant Protection Directorate is in charge of conducting management and administrative activities
related to: plants health condition; import, export, re-export and transit of plants and plant products
shipments; seed and planting material, multiplication material and plant protection materials. The
Directorate is responsible for performing control of compliance of the above with the Law on
Protection of Plants (“Official Gazette of RM ” No.25/98 and 6/00) and the Law on Seed, Planting and
Multiplication Material and Protection of Variety (“Official Gazette of RM ” No.41/00). The Plant
Protection Directorate is in charge of performing control of activities from the area of plants health
condition, as well as on activities of authorised institutions engaged in particular operations.
The State Agricultural Inspectorate is in charge of inspection supervision of enforcement of
agricultural legislation. The scope of its responsibilities encompasses performing control of health
condition of plants and products of plant origin, as well as agricultural products and feeding stuffs
quality, in the primary production and in internal and foreign trade, within the competences derived
from the Law on Agricultural Inspection (“Official Gazette of RM ” 38/04) and the material laws from
Detailed description of the competent authorities is given under

largest portion of the process of harmonisation is supported by technical aid within CARDS
Programme through Structure and Legal Reforms Project of Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and

text.b: Legislation basis of the Republic of Macedonia:

page.text: Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00)
Rulebook on compulsory health control of plants and plant products that are crossing the
List of quarantine diseases and pests (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 9/69)
Order on the type of seeds that must be subjected to disinfection prior being put into
circulation, or for individual needs (“Official Gazette of SFRY ”No 4/78).
The Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00) regulates: the plant health
protection, the inland trade; the foreign trade on the border crossings and loading places, the
diagnostic reporting and the pesticide registration. For the purpose of the approximation of the
national with the EU phytosanitary legislation, the Law on Plant Health is in the adoption procedure,
and the Law on Plant Health Products is being drafted.
The largest portion of the existing national legislation is compatible with the EU requirements:
There is a list of quarantine harmful organisms;
There is also a regulation on compulsory plant health control of cross-border trade carried out
by inspectors for plant protection on the border crossing points;
The phytocertificate standards (the form) are accepted in line with FAO – IPPC;
The system for carrying out inspections on the border crossing points (BIP) is compatible with
EU acquis, and it comprises of inspection of documentation, identification, plant health check
(visual check, sampling, laboratory analyses, undertaking phytosanitary measures), and for
shipments aimed for export, issuance of phytosanitary certificate.
However, there are some incompatibilities, as follows:
Currently there are no regulations regarding introduction of plant passports;
Import licenses are issued for perennial plants planting material;
A large number of plant product shipments which are imported in line with the legislation of
the Republic of Macedonia must be accompanied by phytosanitary certificate and must be
inspected at the border point itself, but are not subjected to inspection check in EU;
There is a system of compulsory control implemented after the importation (post entry control)
for planting material shipments (vine and fruit);
Law prescribes compulsory health control of institutions engaged in production of seed for
reproduction and control of economically important pests in seed crops and planting material
The List of harmful organisms from Annex 1 Section 1 – 2000/29/EC may be compared with the
Macedonian List A from the List of quarantine diseases and pests (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 9/96),
which is partially compatible with the EU List.
The List of harmful organisms from Annex 1 Section 2 – 2000/29/EC is partially compatible with List
A 2 from the List of quarantine diseases and pests (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 9/96). A small part of
the Macedonian List is compatible with the EU List.
The List of harmful organisms from Annex 2 Part A Section 1 and 2 – 2000/29/EC is mostly
compatible with List A1 on quarantine diseases and pests. Comparison on plant varieties that must
not be affected by harmful organisms is not possible, since such list is not introduced in the
The List of harmful organisms from Annex 3A – 2000/29/EC is partly compatible with the Order for
prohibition of import and transit of particular plant varieties and ordering quarantine supervision on
particular plant varieties imported for growing (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 59/91).
Annex 3 B – 2000/29/EC is not compatible with the Macedonian legislation in terms of protection
The List of plant products from Annex 4 A – 2000/29/EC is partially harmonised. Special conditions
that must be met for particular plant varieties and products of plant origin are set. Order for
prohibition of import and transit of particular plant varieties and ordering quarantine supervision on
particular plant varieties imported for growing (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 59/91), the Order on
undertaking measures on import of potatoes in the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM ”
No 81/03) and Articles 11, 12, and 13 from the Rulebook on plant health control in the cross-border
Annex 4 B – 2000/29/EC – is not harmonised with the Macedonian regulations (protected zones).
Annex 5 A1 – 2000/29/EC is partially harmonised with the Article 22 of the Law on Plant Protection
(“Official Gazette of RM” No 52/98 and 06/00). The system for plant passports is not set; however,
seed material and plants coming from infected areas must possess a Certificate on plant health
condition in the inland trade, obtained prior to transportation from the production facilities.
Annex 5 A 2 – 2000/29/EC – is partially harmonised within the Macedonian regulations. Special
regulations referring to protected zones are not classified.
Annex 5 B – 2000/29/EC – is in a partial conformity with Article 2 of the Rulebook on compulsory
plant health inspection in the cross-border trade. All plants are subjected to health inspection, unless
the hazard of carrying harmful organisms is eliminated chemically, thermally, mechanically, or
Annex 6 – 2000/29/EC (plants on which special measures may be applied) – is partially compatible
with Article 27 of the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 06/00).
Annex 7 A and 7 B – 2000/29/Ec – phytosanitary certificate and re-export phytocertificate forms are
entirely identical, in line with the Rulebook on plant health control in cross-border trade (“Official
Gazette of RM ” No 59/91) Form 1 and Form 2.

No regulations are set out currently in the Republic of Macedonia. There is partial compatibility on the
account of the Law on Seeds, Planting and Multiplication Materials, Type Adoption, Certification and
Protection of Plant Variety (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 41/00), stipulating that all importers, finishers
and distributors of seed and planting material must be entered in a register. The registers are kept in
the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy - Seed and Planting Material Directorate.
Issuance of passports is partially compliant: plant passport system for movement within the market is
not established, however the planting material must be accompanied by a Certificate (plant passport)
for the health condition issued by a competent inspector, prior to its movement from the production
area to the planting or selling location.

There is no legislation in the Republic of Macedonia in compliance with EU Directive regarding
protected zones . On the basis of the existing Law, a Programme for monitoring of harmful organisms
has been established, determining whether they are present on any areas in the Republic of
Macedonia. This is coordinated by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy through
the Plant Protection Directorate, which authorises scientific institutions in the field of protection.

Description of the EU measures transposition:
Council Directive 91/414/EEC of 15 July 1991 concerning the placing of plant protection
products on the market and its amendments:
Legislative basis of the Republic of Macedonia
Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00)
The general provisions of the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and
6/00) contain a part compatible with the Directive, concerning responsibilities on
evaluation/inspection of documentation for plant protection products. The documentation is
submitted by the manufacturer to the competent Ministry, for official registration of the plant
The Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00) incorporates
provisions on the basis of which institutions are authorised for inspection of the
documentation, and for determining physical, chemical and biological features of the plant
protection products (on-site testing). The Law also includes provisions on plant protection
products users’ responsibilities, provisions on requirements imposed to the legal entities
involved in trade of plant protection products and on inspection supervision of the production,
trade and application of the plant protection products (post registration control).
However, the aforementioned provisions are not entirely compatible with the relevant provisions of
the Council Directive 91/414/EEC. This Directive and its amendments require more detailed and
precise information on the necessary documentation for registration of the plant protection products.
Furthermore, EU Directives require each member state to have only one competent authority for
coordination of the whole registration procedure of the plant protection products as well as for
cooperation with EU Commission and the other member states. On account of this, with the support
of the already approved CARDS 2001/2 reorganisation of the existing institutional capacities which
are now allocated in two Ministries and a number of authorised professional-technical institutions
shall start, aiming to define single authority as a chief coordinator, to redefine the existing
responsibilities, and to determine the necessary number of officers responsible for preparation and
adoption of regulations, and for registration of plant protection products.
Also within this Project, drafting of the Law on Plant Protection Products entirely harmonised with the
is underway. Part of the provisions referred to in the Directive, and in
particular its amendments and annexes shell be built in related regulations.

The Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00) and the
aforementioned Rulebooks provide for detailed terms on the procedure for registration of the
plant protection products as well as the documentation required by the producer to apply for
registration of the plant protection products, which shall be subject of the procedure. However,
the aforementioned EU Directives, acting as amendment and annex to the general EU legal
act on the plant protection products, include more comprehensive, precise and detailed
provisions regarding documentation required in applying for registration of the plant protection
The aforementioned Rulebooks include general provisions and do not cover all requests contained in
the aforementioned Directive. Therefore, drafting of new approximated regulations and
implementations of all provisions referred to in the Directive is anticipated to replace the existing
There is no table of correspondence.

Macedonia, the Law on Seed and Planting Material is under prepration. It is based on the general EU
legislation in this field. During 2005, the Law on Protection of New Plant Varieties shall be adopted.

text.b: i) Tarining of the various control inspectors and food operators;

page.text: Training of the official competent inspectors in the field of foodstuff control is carried out pursuant to
So far, training programmes and lectures from the field of epizootiology, good hygienic practice in the
production of products of animal origin, as well as training on the sampling method for BSE
diagnostics have been carried out in the Veterinary Directorate. The Programme (Fund) for Animal
Health Measures provides for funds intended for training of veterinary inspectors on good production
and hygienic practice, as well as on HACCP production principles, which shall be realised by the end
In 2004, TAIEX facilities have become accessible for Republic of Macedonia, and consequently a
number of training programmes in the veterinary field, thereof.
The educational upgrade of the Plant Protection Directorate personnel involved in the field of plant
protection is reduced to an annual seminar on plant protection, where, among other things, insight
into diffusion of certain pests in the country is acquired as well as into eradication measures. When
possible, the employees individually take part in workshops in the field of plant quarantine, organised
within foreign projects (Directive 2000/29/EEC and 91/414/EEC) and by the regional organisation
EPPO, as well as the Secretariat of the International Plant Protection Convention (IPPC).
Pursuant to the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00), The
Plant Protection Directorate organises for farmers advising sessions with professional
scientific institutions (included in monitoring, forecasting, diagnosing and determining
measures) regarding timely and appropriate protection – application of plant protection
The State Agriculture Inspectorate shall contribute in training of inspectors for particular programmes
and laws, relevant in their area of operation by provision of funds and participation in particular
projects. Thus, the inspectors will not only acquire familiarity with legal regulations, but also an
additional professional knowledge in relevant agricultural field.
Training programmes of border and agricultural inspectors and of all involved in the phytosanitary
system in line with the defined needs have been carried out within CARDS 2002 - NIPS Project.
In 2004, TAIEX facilities have become accessible for Republic of Macedonia, and consequently a
number of training programmes in the phytosanitary area, thereof.
The current training system for all three sectors is not satisfactory. Additional funds and organisation
for systematic and regular education programme and advance training are necessary.
The training of foodstuff operators is mandatory and provided for in Article 14 from the Law on Safety
of Foodstuffs, Products and Materials Coming in Contact with Foodstuffs (“Official Gazette of RM ”
Laboratory accreditation procedure is regulated by the Accreditation Law (“Official Gazette of RM ”
The accreditation procedure is carried out by the Accreditation Institute on the basis of the
Accreditation Law (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 54/02), other laws and in accordance with requests
included in relevant national, European and international standards and documents of the European
The procedure itself is performed on the basis of EN 17025 Standard, and is carried out in 4 stages:
request submission and processing, evaluation procedure, authorisation, and supervision.
Currently, none of the laboratories in the field of foodstuffs, veterinary medicine, phytosanitary
protection and animal nutrition are accredited on national or international level.
The laboratories authorised by the Ministry of Health for conducting analyses and super analyses of
foodstuffs and items for general purposes from the aspect of foodstuff safety are, as follows:
The existing authorised laboratories shall perform tests and analyses of foodstuffs, products, and
materials coming into contact with foodstuffs, until accreditation procedure of laboratories is

The Faculty of Agriculture Sciences and Food and the Institute of Agriculture – Skopje,
authorised for laboratory testing of: physical and chemical, entomological, phytopatological,
The Faculty of Forestry - Skopje, the Institute for Exotic Agricultural Products - Strumica and
the Institute for Tobacco - Prilep, authorised for laboratory testing of entomological,
phytopatological, and vegetative and biological testing;
The Faculty of Agriculture Sciences and Foodstuffs - Skopje and the Livestock Institute –
Skopje, authorised for laboratory testing on feeding stuff quality.
Diagnostics in the field of safety of foodstuffs and infectious diseases is carried out in the laboratories
of the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine.

text.b: iv) Procedures for registration and authorisation

page.text: Pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No.28/98) approval and
registration system for animal holdings, and establishments for production, storing and circulation of
products and raw materials of animal origin and feedingstruffs has been established in the Republic
Pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No.28/98), subject to registration
procedure are: establishments , plants and equipment for breeding of animals, ungulates and hoofed
animals with a capacity of over 20 conditional heads of cattle, horses, swine and sheeps , i.e. ten
conditional heads of poultry and rabbits, establishments for animal slaughtering, treatment,
processing, production, collection, storing, cooling and freezing as well as for trade of products and
raw materials of animal origin; establishments for production, treatment, purchase, storing and trade
of milk and dairy products; establishments for collection, packing and sale of eggs; establishments
for production of melange ; establishments and equipment for collection and harmless removal of
carcasses; confiscates and waste of animal origin; establishemnts (stations) for collection of stray
dogs and cats, fenced space for wild animals; rooms and equipment for production and storing of
animal semen, fertilized ovum and embryos, as well spaces for incubation of eggs and production of
day-old chicks; rooms and equipment for purchase, storing, trade and tanning of leather and fur;
establishments and equipment for animal trade (fairs, exhibitions, cattle markets, etc.);
establishments for disinfection, deratisation, disinsection, deodorisation, and decontamination of
vehicles, establishments of veterinary enterprises, import facilities and equipment; establishments
for purchase, treatment, processing, storing, and trade of honey and honey products; rooms for wax
melting and production of honeycomb, and fishponds for breeding and production of fish.
Requirements to be fulfilled regarding facilities, plants and equipment are detailed in special
Registration procedure is carried out in three phases:
In the first two phases in the administrative procedure, the fulfilment of conditions regarding place
and location is checked, and the technical and technological documentation is approved.
1. The Veterinary Directorate renders an opinion on technical and technological conditions of the
2. The Veterinary Directorate issues veterinary-sanitary Permists for establishments
construction, add on and reconstruction. The investor is obligated to submit a request for
veterinary-sanitary approval and technical and technological documentation prepared in
accordance with veterinary-sanitary and technical and technological requirements prescribed
3. In the third phase, on the basis of prior on-site inspection and opinion from the Commission
set by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, the Director of the Veterinary
Directorate issues a veterinary-sanitary license for the establishments upon fulfilment of
The Veterinary Directorate keeps records on the registered establishments.
There are two types of authorisation models as regards the laboratories in which testing is carried
Pursuant to the Law on Safety of Foodstuffs, Products and Materials in Contact with Foodstuffs
(“Official Gazette of RM ” No 54/2002), testing is carried out by accredited laboratories. Accreditation
of laboratories is performed in accordance with regulations in the field of accreditation.
Pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98) and the Law on
Drugs, Additional Medicines and Medical Accessories (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 2/98)
testing of products and raw materials of animal origin, feedingstuffs and veterinary medicinal
products is carried out in institutions authorised by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy, on the basis of prior on-site inspection and Commission opinion.
Pursuant to the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00), legal
entities engaged in production, retail and wholesale of plant protection materials and in
disinsection, disinfection and deratisation of the storage facilities and vehicles for transport of
agricultural plants and products of plant origin, are subject to registration procedure.
The registration procedure is carried out in three phases:
The first phase includes inspection of the technical documentation of the facility regarding conditions
of the facility location and construction; working conditions regarding protection of workers;
documentation of the professional staff regarding production, disinfection and disinsection of plants,
and premises deratisation, as well as trade with the plant protection materials.
In the second phase, the Commission set by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy carries out on-site inspection on whether the conditions are fulfilled. Representatives from
the Ministry of Health and Ministry of Environment and Physical Planning are also included in the
In the third phase, upon positive inspection outcome, a license for production, retail and wholesale,
as well for plant disinsection and disinfection and premises deratisation is issued by the Minister of
Registries for issued licenses to legal entities are kept in the Plant Protection Directorate.
The conditions required by the legal entities for conducting of the above activities are detailed in the
Rulebook on conditions to be fulfilled by legal entities regarding equipment, devices, and facilities for
production, wholesale and retail of the plant protection products, and on Registry of legal entities
Rulebook on the conditions to be fulfilled by storehouses and other spaces for keeping plants and by
legal entities engaged in plant disinsection, disinfection and premises deratisation (“Official Gazette
Registries of producers, finishers, importers and retailers of seed and planting material are kept in the
Seed and Planting Material Directorate. They are established on the basis of the provisions referred
to in the Law on Seeds, Planting and Multiplication Materials, Type Adoption, Certification and
Protection of Plant Variety (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 41/00).
The conditions required by the producers and importers of seed, planting and multiplication material
to be entered in the registry are provided for in the Law.
Pursuant to the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00),
laboratories performing identification of plant pests, physical and chemical analyses and
biological and vegetation researches are authorised by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry
This procedure is performed in the Plant Protection Directorate by approving conditions in laboratory
Upon the issuance of the confirmation by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, it
is published in Official Gazette of the Republic of Macedonia.
The conditions are detailed in the Rulebook on the conditions to be fulfilled by legal entities with
regard to equipment, plants, and facilities for testing of plant protection materials (“Official Gazette of
On the basis of the Law on Trade of Poisons (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 13/91), the Institute
for Preclinical and Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology (IPCPT) and the Institute for Applied
the Toxicology Department (TD) are authorised by the Ministry of Health to perform
assessment of the poisonous substances in plant protection materials and assessment of the
The Rulebook on the conditions regarding professional qualification of the employees, premises and
equipment that have to be fulfilled by medical and other legal entities for carrying out analyses and
super analyses of foodstuffs and consumer goods (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 54/2001) stipulates
the issues regarding residues of plant protection materials as a basis for registration and
authorisation of the laboratory to perform residue control. The Minister of health sets up a
commission for determining laboratory working conditions. The Minister of Health also issues an
authorisation certificate to the laboratories which fulfil the conditions.
Prior to laboratory authorisation, the State Agriculture Inspectorate carries out inspection on
the basis of the Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 61/97) and establishes the
factual situation. Consequently, it proposes to the Agriculture Department within Ministry of
griculture, Forestry and Water Economy to undertake administrative procedure, if the
conditions stipulated by the Law are fulfilled.

text.b: v) Present and planned resources (personnel, budget and inspection equipment)

page.text: The existing resources of the Department of State Veterinary Inspection are given under
The Strategy for Integrated Border Control of the Government of the Republic of Macedonia
anticipates establishing of six first category veterinary Border Inspection Post, providing 24 hours/7
days non-stop veterinary-sanitary inspection and control ; and three second category veterinary
Border Inspection Post, providing 16 hours/5 days veterinary-sanitary inspection and control, and on-
call supervision on weekends. This Strategy foresees employment of 26 new veterinary inspectors on
Border Inspection Post and one advisor for border veterinary inspection within the State Veterinary
Pursuant to the new Law on Veterinary Health , scheduled for adoption in 2005, the Veterinary
Directorate anticipates introduction of an institution “authorised veterinarian”, who shall be
hierarchically responsible to the State Veterinary Inspection Unit and shall have particular
competences as of the state veterinary inspectors. The number of authorised veterinarians shall be
determined on the basis of the Veterinary Directorate needs. In the process of harmonisation, the
Inspectorate’s staff number and structure shall be adjusted to the requests referred to in the
European Union legislation. In this respect, veterinary inspection equipping and staff training shall be
realised in compliance with the European Union standards.

text.b: Plant Protection Directorate and State Agricultural Inspectorate

page.text: The present resources of the Plant Protection Directorate and the State Agricultural Inspectorate are
detailed in the answer to the question
Within the implementation of the European Partnership Action Plan of the Government of the
Republic of Macedonia, approximation of the legislation in the field of plant protection is scheduled by
2007. The organisational structure and function of the Plant Protection Directorate shall be also laid
down. The adoption of the Law on Plant Protection and its implementation shall introduce
phytosanitary monitoring throughout the Republic of Macedonia.
The activities of the border plant protection inspection, agricultural inspectors, regional reporters,
professional staff in laboratories and other competent experts and institutions shall introduce the
need for more intensive mobility, provision of additional equipment as well as permanent educational
training, all aimed to perform according to the EU member states standards In this respect,
equipping and professional advancement of the inspection, regional reporters and competent experts
and institutions in line with the EU standards will take place.
The Inspection does not possess appropriate equipment necessary for carrying out inspection
operation. Upon the completion of harmonisation of the national with the EU legislation, this
inspectorate will work in line with the standards applied in European Union, which will increase the
The funds for a part of this equipment (information and communication technology, hand-held
equipment necessary for visual inspection) are provided within the CARDS 2001/2002 - Projects.
Fulfilment of the new phytosanitary requirements will also have an funding impact. Therefore, it is
necessary to obtain aid from future CARDS Programmes as well as allocation in the Budget of the

text.b: vi) Present (and planned ) frequency of controls; planning of inspection activities;

page.text: Veterinary inspectors carry out veterinary - sanitary inspections and controls on daily basis, either in
their line of their duty, on their own initiative or on complaint by legal and natural entities. .
Particular veterinary-sanitary inspection and controls are carried out on monthly or annual basis,
according to the programmes and operation plans set by the Veterinary Directorate (Veterinary -
sanitary control and inspection and manner of keeping record on residues and certain substances in
raw materials, live animals and products of animal origin; the Order for undertaking measures for
animal protection from diseases na deadlines for their implementation) or on the basis of special
The inspection and control of plants and products of plant origin intended for export are carried out
on predefined loading points. Thus, the monitoring of plant health condition, locations for primary
agricultural production, warehouses, and etc. will be conducted more attentively, and consequently,
the inspections in the primary agricultural production carried out by experts will be intensified.
State agricultural inspectors carry out controls on regular basis, in accordance with the regulations,
upon reports by legal and natural entities, and upon complaints and appeals submitted by citizens
Inspectors on border crossing points carry out inspections and controls on regular basis on all
imported plants and products of plant origin, and in case of suspicion of quarantine pest infection,
samples are taken and sent for laboratory analysis. Only plants on which the possibility of carrying
plant pests is eliminated by chemical, mechanical or other methods are not subject to inspection.
A large number of products of plant origin subject to phytosanitary inspection are not subject to
control in EU member states. Samples of imported potato seed are taken to compulsory laboratory
analysis on regular basis, in order to confirm or reject the presence of potato ring or brown rot.
Regular check and control of imported perennial seed material are conducted either in the countries
of export (pre control), or on the planting locations, by agricultural inspectors (post entry control).
With the gradual introduction of the harmonised regulations, only particular types of plants according
to the Directive shall be inspected on the border crossing points, thus the level of import inspection

text.b: vii) present (and planned) procedures for encouraging the development of guidance

page.text: The Veterinary Directorate sets the Instructions for work (procedures and activities) with regard to
particular work issues, if need be, on the basis of scientific recommendations, opinions, guidelines,
international standards and EU legislation (Instructions on sampling, sending material for control of
residues from certain substances, veterinary medicinal products and contaminants in live animals
and foodstuffs of animal origin; Instructions on the method and procedures to be applied in animal

text.b: Plant Protection Directorate and State Agricultural Inspectorate

page.text: The existing rules do not implicate a need for instructions to be applied in the work of state inspectors
and experts involved in the phytosanitary system.
There are guidelines (Vademecum) drafted with the help of the EU technical assistance. There are
no other systematized instructions in line with the existing regulation, however, there are specific
instructions regarding particular control procedures, drafted by the Plant Protection Directorate with
assistance of local experts and approved by the Director.
Pursuant to EU regulations, the inspectors should perform their activities in line with the national and
EU instructions (EU Plant Health Vademecum). Within the CARDS 2002 - NIPS Project rendering of
instructions on the basis of approximated regulations is provided for, where individual procedures
would be explained in a simpler and more acceptable manner.
The existing regulations that cover issues of plant protection materials, include provisions on
sampling and methods for carrying out particular procedures.
Since the EU regulations do not contain such provisions, but specific instructions on procedures, i.e.
technical manuals and guidelines are rendered, the instructions in the new rulebooks shall respect
these principles and standards. The instructions will be prepared on the basis of the existing
manuals, rendered by the international organisations engaged in the plant protection materials and
residues field (FAO, EPPO, EU, WHO).Technical assistance is expected for preparation of

text.b: viii) Methods for the evaluation of the control services (existing or planned audit system)

page.text: The Head of of the State Veterinary Inspectorate Department and the Director of the Veterinary
Directorate perform the evaluation of the control inspection services operations. The audit implicates
analysis of the monthly reports delivered by the inspectors, direct control over the inspectors’
operational methods and direct meetings with them.
The Law on Civil Servants stipulates that as of January 2005, mandatory evaluation of civil servants
on the basis of established criteria will take place.
In addition there is external audit on the work of the control services, carried out by the Administrative
Inspectorate within the Ministry of Justice.
The Director of the Plant Protection Directorate performs evaluation of the control services work. The
audit includes analysis of the reports delivered by the regional reporters as well as direct control over
the inspectors’ operational methods and direct meetings with them.
There are no elaborated evaluation methods for the control services in the area of plant health
protection (quarantine). Technical aid in this area is expected within the future CARDS Programme
There are no systemically elaborated methods for control services evaluation in the area of plant
protection materials and plant protection material residues. On the account of the insufficient expert
knowledge in this area, the plan and methods elaboration is possible only with technical assistance.
The Head of the Department and the Director of the Inspectorate perform the evaluation of
inspectors’ operation. The audit consists of analysis of the monthly reports delivered by the
inspectors, direct control over the inspectors’ operational methods and direct meetings with them.
The Law on Civil Servants stipulates that as of January 2005, mandatory evaluation of civil servants
on the basis of established criteria will take place.

text.b: ix) Management of complaints and crisis; legal action and appeals; control of imported food

page.text: The Veterinary Directorate, the State Agricultural Inspectorate, and the Plant Protection Directorate
carry out the administrative procedure on the basis of material regulations in the relevant area.
Legal and natural persons, pursuant to the Constitution of the Republic of Macedonia have a right to
submit appeals or complaints to an administrative body, which is obliged to reinvestigate and
undertake appropriate activities and to inform back the complainer on the activities undertaken.
The Veterinary Directorate, the State Agricultural Inspectorate and the Plant Protection Directorate
carry out the administrative procedure; the party has a right to appeal to the Minister of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy, or to the Second Instance Commission competent for agriculture,
forestry, water economy and veterinary within the Government of the Republic of Macedonia upon
the decision and the legal advice thereof. If the party is not satisfied with the decision of the second
instance authorities, they have a right to bring up a lawsuit to the Supreme Court of the Republic of
Macedonia. The judgement of the Supreme Court is final.
The Law on Protection and Promotion of Environment and Nature (“Official Gazette of RM ”
No 69/96, 13/99, 96/2000, 41/2000, and 45/2002), the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official
Gazette of RM ” No 28/98), the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98
and 6/00), and the Law on Safety of Foodstuffs, Products and Materials in Contact with
Foodstuffs (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 54/2002) provide for procedures, measures and
activities in contingencies, such are crisis that might induce environmental disaster or threats
to human, animal or plant health.
Bearing in mind that the bodies responsible for overcoming contingency crisis are included in several
regulations rendered by several Ministries, co-ordination of procedures and responsibilities between
state bodies is necessary in adopting amendments or drafting of new regulations.
The control of food import is carried out on border inspection posts, which are established with
Decision by the Government of the Republic of Macedonia, as well as upon unloading of the
commodities in the internal organisational units according to the modes and procedures provided for
This issue is detailed in Phytosanitary Control, in the answer to the question
The control system of imported food is detailed in the answer to the question

a) total number of establishments, including current output (tonnes) and capacity;
b) number of establishments authorised for export to EU, including current output (tonnes)
i) Slaughterhouses (redmeat, poultrymeat, gamemeat and fish);
ii) meat cutting plants (redmeat, poultrymeat, gamemeat and fish);
iii) cold stores (redmeat, poultrymeat, gamemeat and fish);
v) milk and milk processing factories;

page.text: The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No28/98) in the Republic of Macedonia
establishes a system of authorisation and registration of animal holdings and facilities for production,
storing and trade of products and raw materials of animal origin, and of feeding stuffs. Pursuant to
the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/92), establishments, plants and
equipment for animal slaughtering, treatment, processing, collecting, cooling, freezing as well as
circulation of products, raw materials of animal origin, establishments for production, processing,
purchase, storing and circulation of milk and dairy products, establishments for collection, sorting,
packing, storing and sale of eggs, establishments for production of melange, establishments for
purchase, treatment, processing, storing, circulation of honey and honey products must be arranged
so that are not hazardous for animal and human health, to prevent diseases carrying and spreading,
and provide hygienic safety production and marketing, as well as to prevent pollution of environment
The Veterinary Directorate gives opinion on technical and technological conditions of the places
where the establishments shall be located and constructed. The Veterinary Direcotrate issues
veterinary approval licence on establishment construction, adding on, and reconstruction. A
establishment may not be constructed without veterinary-sanitary approval issued by the Director of
the Veterinary Directorate , upon opinion of a commission set up by the Minister of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy , upon inspection of the documentation of the applicant – producer and
The following documentation shall be enclosed to the request for obtaining veterinary-sanitary licence
for use of a relevant production establishment::
2. Water, steam and electric power supply system plan as well as sewerage system plan;
3. List of technological-technical characteristics of the equipment;
4. Raw material balance and product assortment, description of technological
5. Review of activites arrangement in the facility and labour force balance;
6. List of sanitary facilities and measures applied for sanitary protection of the facility,
7. Review of the organisation of the veterinary inspection of the establishment.
The Rulebook (“Official Gazette of SFRY ”No 53/89) provides for detailed conditions to be fulfilled
regarding establishments for slaughtering, treatment, processing and storing of products of animal
origin, and the description of the method and procedure for facility registration under the Veterinary
Directorate competence is detailed in the answers to questions
Pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No28/98), slaughtering, collection
and production of products and raw materials of animal origin aimed for export is permitted only in
export establishments, for which, the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, upon
proposal of expert commission set up by him, shall determine fulfilment of conditions prescribed by
this Law, or conditions for the relevant countries.
The Veterinary Directorate keeps register of establishments for production of products of animal
origin as well as of export establishments in the Republic of Macedonia.
Export establishments which produce products of animal origin shall possess export control number,
whereas the establishments which place their products on the domestic market do not possess
permission number, which shall be accomplished in the following period, according to production
group, or pursuant to the relevant EU Directives.
Currently in the Republic of Macedonia operate 143 establishments for production and storing of
products of animal origin, for which the Veterinary Directorate has issued veterinary-sanitary license.
Detailed insight of the type of facility, production, total capacity and current daily average production
is provided in the following table:

text.b: a) General architecture of the legal basis; organisation and powers of different institutions
b) Respective fields of responsibilities of competent authorities concerned.
c) Please provide a clear table of all the framework acts that cover or impinge upon the
veterinary domain with an explanation of their coverage as far as the EU veterinary acquis is
concerned. Please indicate whether you envisage adopting new framework acts.

page.text: The Basic regulation in the veterinary field in the Republic of Macedonia is the Law on Veterinary
Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98) , which regulates animal health protection from diseases,
protection from animal infectious diseases transmittable to humans; veterinary-sanitary inspections
and control, veterinary protection and improvement of environment and nature; minimum compulsory
volume of animal health protection from diseases; compensations and expenses on animal health
protection; organisation and carrying out of activities in field of veterinary medicine and other issues
in the field of veterinary health. Among other things, this Law defines the competences of the
veterinary service as a whole, as well as the rights and duties, and responsibilities of each of the
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy is the highest authority for implementation
of the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98) and other regulations in this
Internal organisational setup of the Veterinary Directorate as a ministerial body allows direct
implementation of provisions of the regulations, as well as performing control on the implementation.
This is carried out through Veterinary Inspection, which, according to the hierarchical order, is part of
The Veterinary Directorate is also competent for implementation of the provisions stemming from:
Law on Safety of Foodstuffs, Products and Materials Coming in Contact with Foodstuffs
(“Official Gazette of RM ” No 54/02), in the area of foodstuffs of animal origin;
The Law on Animal Identification and Registration (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 69/04);
The Law on Pharmaceutical Drugs, Supplementary Treatment Substances and Medical
Devices (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 21/98) (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 21/98), in the
section referring to drugs, additional drugs and medical accessories for application in
As well as from the secondary legislation thereof.
As a state administration body, Veterinary Directorate is included in the Ministry of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy, which carries out particular administrative, professional and other
activities under the competence of the Ministry. The Directorate is managed by a Director, who is
personally responsible for his/her work and for the Directorate operations to the Government and
The Veterinary Directorate includes the following 6 Units, managed by Heads of Units.:
The structure and competences of the Veterinary Directorate and its units are detailed in the answer
Veterinary inspectors carry out inspection control over implementation of regulations in the veterinary
Pursuant to the Law on Civil Servants (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 59/2000), veterinary inspectors
are professional civil servants, who professionally, politically impartial and objectively carry out
activities related to state functions compliant with the Constitution and the Law.
A veterinary inspector may be a doctor of veterinary medicine who had passed professional exam,
and has not less than two-year working experience in the veterinary field. They are recruited within
the Veterinary Directorate through the internal organization in the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy, and subordination is carried out through the Unit of state veterinary inspection
Veterinary inspectors carry out mandatory veterinary-sanitary control of animals, holdings , animals
on exhibitions, markets, fairs, sports competitions and other public places, establishments and
equipment for production, treatment, processing, finishing and trade of products, raw materials, and
waste materials of animal origin, shops and other selling facilities for sale of products of animal origin,
feeding stuff, water in the production process and in watering of animals, production of animal
reproduction materials and its trade. They also carry out control on implementation of measures for
animal health by veterinary enterprises (as regards, in particular, animal health protection of public
interest), control of veterinary enterprises establishments and trade of veterinary medical products.
Veterinary inspectors, competent for undertaking measures for animal health protection as well as for
carrying out control and supervision in inland trade and production, are organised in 30 regional
offices of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy. Thus, they cover strictly
determined epizootiological areas (areas of a number of neighbouring municipalities) and are
responsible for supervision of the territory of the region. A total number of 40 inspectors carry out
inspection control on the territory of the state.
Veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of import, export and transit of consignments in the
veterinary border inspection post of the Republic of Macedonia are carried out by veterinary
inspectors on the border inspection post . The veterinary sanitary inspection and control of the
consignments of animals, products, raw materials and waste materials of animal origin, artificial
insemination material , feeding stuffs , stable manure, urine, compost and other items that may carry
infectious disease, are mandatory in the border inspection post particularly on the account of
humans and animals health protection and prevention of potential hazard of transmitting and
The obligation of the Republic of Macedonia to provide compulsory veterinary sanitary inspection and
control on Border Inspection Posts is stemming from:
The Law on Veterinary Health and applicable secondary legislation;
Control on consignments of animal origin is permitted only on Border Inspection Posts determined by
the government of the Republic of Macedonia. Veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of
consignment of animal origin is carried out on the following Border Inspection Posts:
Bogorodica and Megitlija on the border with Republic of Greece;
Cafasan on the border with Republic of Albania;
Blace on the border with Kosovo;
Tabanovce on the border with Serbia and Montenegro;
Deve Bair, Delcevo and Novo Selo on the border with Republic of Bulgaria.
A total of 10 veterinary inspectors on the Border Inspection Post carry out veterinary-sanitary
inspection and control and are in direct subordination to the State Veterinary Inspection Unit within

text.b: Organisation and carrying out veterinary-health activities

page.text: The Animal Health protection, in respect to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ”
No.28/98), includes the following veterinary health activities:
animal health protection from infectious and other diseases determined by law;
detection, prevention, treatment and eradication of infectious diseases in animals;
monitoring and studying epizootiological situation as regards occurrence of infectious and
detection, prevention, treatment and eradication of other diseases in animals;
laboratory diagnostics and researches of materials-samples of infected animals;
specialist, clinical, pathological, x-ray and other diagnostic researches;
carrying out surgical and other interventions on animals;
Veterinary sanitary inspection and control of animals for slaughter, fish, crawfish, shells, snails
and frogs, products, raw materials and waste materials of animal origin and feeding stuffs
inspection of safety of products, raw materials and residues of animal origin, feeding stuffs,
reproductive material, animal drinking water in production and in production establishments,
storing, processing of products and raw material of animal origin, and waste waters from the
production process of products, raw materials and waste materials of animal origin;
prevention of contamination of animals, products, raw materials, and waste materials of
animal origin, feeding stuffs and water with radiological, biological, and chemical
contaminants, in order to determine the disease ethiopathogenezes;
prevention of environment and nature contamination with agents and carriers of infectious
diseases and with other harmful materials, non-hazardous elimination of carcasses,
confiscates and waste materials of animal origin;
ecological measures for sanitation of waste waters, stable manure, urine and compost;
désinfection, désinsectisation, dératisation, deodorisation and décontamination;
protection of animals from inhuman treatment;
veterinary medical education of the animal owners and the population;
other matters in the field of veterinary health set by a law.
Animal Health protection covers also the animal health protection of public interest, carried
out on the basis of license; and it presents a complexity of particular veterinary health
The conduct of veterinary health activity is organised in such way to ensure permanent and
continuous access of all animal owners to veterinary services and their exercise of the right to
minimum compulsory volume of animal protection from infectious diseases, stipulated in the Law on
Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98). For the provision of minimum compulsory
volume of animal protection from diseases, as a significant segment of the entire animal health
protection, the state provides instruments in line with terms and conditions referred to in law.
Pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98), the veterinary health
activity is carried out by veterinary enterprises (veterinary ambulance, veterinary station and
veterinary hospital) as well as scientific research and high educational institutions. Veterinary health
practice can be: primary, secondary and tertiary animal health protection.
Primary veterinary health practice is carried out by veterinary enterprises : veterinary ambulance,
veterinary station and veterinary hospital, whereby particular Articles regulate the reguirements to be
fulfilled for establishing and registration of veterinary enterprises as well as the scope of their
Secondary veterinary health activity is carried out by a Veterinary institute, set up in line with the
provisions referred to in the Law on Scientific Research Activity.
Tertiary veterinary health activity is carried out by the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine and the
Veterinary enterprises may be established by domestic legal and natural persons, under conditions
determined in law. Veterinary enterprises may be established as: veterinary ambulance , veterinary
station and veterinary hospital, and among other things, there is a distinction regarding activities they
are entitled to carry out, as a part of the primary veterinary health practice.
Particular veterinary health activities are considered as veterinary health practice of public interest,
and they are carried out by veterinary enterprises on the basis of license issued by the Government
of the Republic of Macedonia, pursuant to this Law and the Law on Public Enterprises.
Veterinary enterprises, in fact, present the base in imposing animal health protection measures,
taking into consideration that particular enterprises are also responsible for carrying out veterinary
Veterinary enterprises that fulfill the conditions for carrying out veterinary health operation of public
interest, may apply for obtaining license from the Government of the Republic of Macedonia for
conduct of such practice in particular epizootiological area, or epizootiological unit to an open
competition, announced by the Minister of agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy. The selection of
the most favourable offers for execution of the works is carried out by a commission set up by the
Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy in a particular time limit, and the Minister on
behalf of the Government, concludes a contract with the veterinary enterprises for execution of the
works issued on public announcement. This license issued by the Government of the Republic of
Macedonia is valid for a period of five years The veterinary enterprises, which have been issued a
license, compose a network of veterinary enterprises set by the Government pursuant to particular
legal criteria. The network performs activities of public interest in field of veterinary medicine.
On the other hand, the Government of the Republic of Macedonia provides carrying out of activities
of public interest for which no license is issued to any veterinary enterprise, by setting up public
Veterinary wholesale pharmacies are engaged in trade of veterinary medicinal products, and work in
line with the Law on Drugs, Additional Medicines and Medical Accessories. (“Official Gazette of RM ”
The Veterinary institute carries out secondary veterinary health activity provided for in the provisions
from the Law on Veterinary Health, and also carries out particular works within the tertiary activities
defined in the same Law. A Veterinary institute may be established in line with the provisions referred
to in the Law on Scientific Research Activity (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 13/69 and 29/2002).
For the needs of the Veterinary Directorate and pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health and the
Annual Order for measures for prevention, control and eradication of animals contagious diseases ,
the Veterinary Institute carries out laboratory and field diagnostics aimed for detecting, prevention
and eradication of infectious and parasite diseases stipulated in the Order, and implements the state
The Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, as a high education institution, performs particular operations
within the tertiary veterinary health activity referred to in the provisions of the Law on Veterinary
The Macedonian Veterinary Chamber (MVC) is an association of Doctors of Veterinary Medicine
aiming for protection and development of the professional and ethic responsibilities and rights,
improvement of the quality of veterinary health practice and protection of interest of the vocation. The
Chamber is in capacity of a legal entity and the membership is voluntary. The Chamber brings up a
statute, which determines its operation, management bodies, organisation and method of operation.
The chamber executes its works autonomously in line with its statute and the Law on Veterinary

Defining the competence of the Ministry of
In the past period a detail analysis of the extent of approximation and the need for approximation of
the legislation in the field of veterinary medicine is carried out. It focuses towards the need for
drafting laws and secondary legislation compatible with the European legislation. The analysis is
carried with technical assistance by EU through the CARDS Project for strengthening of veterinary
service – Harmonisation of veterinary legislation with Acquis Communautaire. This technical
assistance was in function of defining the process of approximation of the legislation and necessary
The process of approximation is carried out, as follows:
General Veterinary Law and secondary legislation in function of unimpeded circulation of
Law and secondary legislation on safety of meat and meat products;
Law on secondary legislation on safety of milk and diary products;
Law and secondary legislation on safety of other products of animal origin;
Law and secondary legislation on veterinary medical products;
Law and secondary legislation on animal welfare;
Law and secondary legislation on residues, contaminants and veterinary aspect of feeding
Law and secondary legislation on by-products and confiscates of animal origin (including TSE
Technical assistance is provided by CARDS Programme 2004 – Project for structural and legal
reforms of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.
According to the Action Plan for European Partnership and the National Programme for
Approximation of the Macedonian Legislation with EU Legislation, this process is foreseen to finish

Law on By-products, Waste Material and TSE-agents
The System of control of live animals and products of animal origin is regulated by the provisions
referred to in the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98) regarding obligations
and methods of veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of inland trade. Control over the mentioned
system is carried out by state veterinary inspectors.
The System of control of live animals is based on breeder’s obligations, census and registration of
animal holdings, identification and registration of animals and veterinary-sanitary inspection and
Breeders and owners of animals due to prevention and protection from infectious diseases in animals
are obliged to undertake measures for provision and maintenance of health conditions in the animal
holdings and to observe veterinary-sanitary order of public places. Breeder’s obligations regarding
provision of general satisfactory preventive measures in animal breeding are detailed in the answer
Owners of animals, legal and natural persons who breed animals, legal persons who carry out
production, processing, storing, trade and sale of feedingstuffs as well as breeders of dogs, animals
in zoos, queen bees, and fish are obliged to report to the Ministry of Agriculture Forestry and Water
Economy the animals, objects and equipment as well as any changes therein within eight days, due
to their evidence in a register of the animal holdings and establishments for production, processing,
storing, trade and sale of feedingstuffs.
The method and procedure of registration of the establishments under competence of the Veterinary
Directorate is detailed in the answer to question
Animals identification and registration is regulated by the Law on Animals Identification and
