Registration (“Official Gazette of RM” No 69/04) as a obligatory obligation of the animal breeder, thus
improving control and eradication of infectious diseases in animals, improving supervision and
efficiency of veterinary control in the course of import and export of animals, improvement of
monitoring of animals and animal holdings regarding the measures of epidemiological supervision
and control of residues. The system of animal identification and registration is detailed in the answer
Regarding inland trade, the owner of the animals species such as ungulates, hoofed animals, poultry,
room pet birds, rabbits, fish from fishponds, bee swarms and queen bees, live game for hunting,
precious fur bearing animals, dogs and cats, is obliged to keep and to display upon request of a
competent person a veterinary certificate on animal health condition.
This certificate proves that in the place of animal origin or dwelling do not exist infectious disease that
can be transmitted by those animals, that all preventive measures and other diagnostic examination
are undertaken, and that animal for slaughter are covered by planned inspections on biological
residues and disease causing agents in animals, or that animal sent for slaughtering in the course of
the last three weeks are neither cured with veterinary medicinal products nor feedingstuffs with food
This validity period of Certificate is ten days. It must not be issued if an existence of infectious
disease which may be carried over by the animal species in question is determined in the place of
the animal origin. Animals must be marked due to particular way of determination of their health
This Certificate is issued by a veterinary enterprises licensed by the Minister of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy for carrying out veterinary health activity of public interest (carrying out
preventive measures in epizootiological area). The determined veterinary enterprises keeps
evidence regarding issued certificate and executed changes.
The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98) also determines the control
system for production and trade of products and raw materials of animal origin.
The control system includes obligatory registration of slaughter establishments, establishments for
production, processing and storing products of animal origin, and obligatory veterinary-sanitary
inspection and control of slaughter animals, and of production and trade of products of animal origin.
Pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No 28/98), establishments,
machines, and equipment for animal slaughter, for treatment, processing, production, collection,
storing, refrigerating and freezing as well as for trade of products, raw materials of animal origin,
establishments for production, processing, repurchase, storing and trade of milk and diary products,
establishments for collection, sorting, packing, storing and trade of eggs, establishments for
production of melange, establishments for repurchase, treatment, processing, and storing, trade of
honey and honey products must be structured so that they are not hazardous for animals and people,
to prevent entering and spreading of diseases, to provide hygienically suitable production and to
prevent pollution of the environment and nature.
The obligation to register the establishments for animal slaughtering, treatment, processing,
production, collection, storing, refrigerating, freezing and trade of products and raw material of animal
origin is laid down in the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No 28/98) Chapter 3 –
veterinary-sanitary prevention in trade and production.
Veterinary-sanitary inspection and controls are obligatory for ungulates, hoofed animals, poultry and
rabbits prior to slaughtering as well as for ungulate, hoofed animal, poultry, rabbit and game meat,
milk and eggs, meat, fish, diary and egg products, crawfish, shells, snails and frogs and crawfish,
shell, snail and frog products aimed for public consumption.
The obligatory inspection and control is carried out also on establishments and equipment for:
animal slaughter; processing and treatment of meat, milk, fish, shellfish, shells, snails, frogs, honey
and eggs; storing, refrigerating, freezing of the above, as well as on raw materials and additives used
in processing and treatment of products of animal origin in those establishments.
Veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of slaughter animals as well as of the above-mentioned
products and raw material aimed for public consumption are carried out in slaughter houses or
production facilities, whereas inspection control of products and raw material of animal origin is
carried out in the storing facilities, shops, markets and other sales places.
The veterinary inspector maintains official evidence on carried out inspections and controls.
Ungulates and hoofed animals must be inspection prior to and after slaughtering, game - after being
shot when their meat is aimed for public consumption, cattle, buffalos and ungulates - when their
meat is aimed for individual household consumption, and in the case of epizooty of infectious
disease, the inspection is obligatory also for sheep, goats and pigs prior and after slaughtering when
their meat is aimed for individual household consumption or animal feeding. If ungulates and hoofed
animals are forcibly slaughtered, the inspection is obligatory after slaughtering even though the meat
is aimed for individual household consumption or as animal feed.
The users of games in hunting grounds are obliged to inform a veterinary inspection prior to hunting,
and its control is carried out on examination points, located at hunters’ association meeting places.
The veterinary-sanitary inspection of slaughtered animals, products and material of animal origin
determines their compliancy (safety) for human consumption. Production and processing of diary
products, eggs and honey are not subject to veterinary-sanitary inspection and control when those
products are aimed for human consumption within their own household.
If a veterinary inspector determines that the products are safe for human consumption on the basis
of the inspection and other analyses , such products are properly marked and their circulation for
public consumption, treatment, or processing is permitted. The unmarked, or products put into
circulation for public consumption without prior veterinary-sanitary inspection and control are
considered as non safe for human consumption.
Controls in slaughter houses are carried out on regular basis during animal slaughtering, whereas in
the establishments for production of meat, milk and other products as well as in storehouses, the
control is in proportion with the production – volume of production.
The method and procedure of veterinary-sanitary control of the products of animal origin is detailed in

i.b: Veterinary-sanitary examination and control in the inland trade

page.text: Veterinary-sanitary control is obligatory during loading, re-loading and unloading of consignments of
animals; products (excluding cans), raw materials and waste materials of animal origin, carcasses,
confiscates of animal origin, stable manure, urine and compost transported out of epizootiological
area as well as ungulates and hoofed animals which are herded out of epizootiological area.
On the basis of 24-hour prior submitted application by the client, the state veterinary inspector in
epizootiological area carries out veterinary-sanitary inspection. If animals, products, raw materials
and waste material of animal origin, carcasses and stable manure are transported to another
epizootiological area, verifies inspections and seals on the back of the veterinary certificate on
animal health condition (transport certificate), whereas for shipping of products of animal origin,
veterinary certificate on health condition of the shipping is issued
It is forbidden to load, re-load, unload and move consignments of ungulates and hoofed animals if in
the course of the obligatory veterinary-sanitary inspection is determined or doubted that the
consignment : is infected with infectious disease, originates from infectious area; does not possess
veterinary certificate on the health condition; is transported in transportation means that does not fulfil
the prescribed veterinary-sanitary conditions; does not fulfil prescribed hygienic and technical
Trade and unloading of consignment shall be forbidden if it is determined, in the course of the
obligatory veterinary-sanitary inspection and control, that: the consignments has no veterinary
certificate on animal health condition or other confirmation on compliance; the veterinary certificate
and confirmation provided have drawbacks or irregularities when filled in or verified, are illegible and
do not enable identification of the animals or the products of animal origin; the certificate or
confirmation have been issued by an unauthorised person; the loading list has not been, at all, or has
been irregularly verified in the course of the loading of animals, the consignment has been brought
from unknown epizootiological area, or it originates from a region with unknown epizootiological
Veterinary workers, animal owners and legal and natural persons - owners of establishments , are
obliged to conduct prescribed preventive measures aimed at protection of the products, raw materials
of animal origin and feedignstuffs from harmful substances.
If irregularities are determined, state veterinary inspectors pursuant to the existing legislation may
proceed administrative or court procedure, or impose mandatory penalty. The penalty actions
include imposing fines and/or abeyance of activity.

text.b: a) bovine animals (including central bovine database);

page.text: Identification and registration of animals is regulated by the Law on Animals Identification and
Up to 2004, identification of animals was regulated to certain extent by the Law of Veterinary Health
referred to in the provision regarding individual timely identifying of animals (cattle and small
ruminants), within carrying out of the activities stipulated in the Annual Order for measures for
prevention, control and eradication of animals contagiousus diseases.
Since the adoption of the Law for Identification and Registration of Animals, the Veterinary
Directorate has so far carried out the following activities:
Defining the necessary hardware and its procurement (servers, computers for the
Identification and Registration Unit, PDA handheld computers);
Defining the necessary I&R software and its procurement;
Defining, design and supply of printed documents (cattle passports, documents for
registration of a new born calves, documents for registration of movement, farm register, and
Cattle holding census and establishing of Central Holding Register;
Drafting Law for Identification and Registration of Animals;
Drafting Book of Rules for identification and registration of bovine animals.
The Veterinary Directorate was working on testing of I&R software (central and PDA I&R software),
and the software application was ready for use in mid-November 2004, and pilot tagging campaign in
3 testing municipalities is going to begin soon. If this testing provides positive results, a national wide
campaign for identification and registration of cattle is planned 14 days later.
The Law for Identification and Registration of Animals (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 69/2004) covers
all species of domestic and other animals. This Law has been harmonised with the existing EU
legislation referring to animal identification and registration.
The System for identification and registration of farm animals comprises of:
Central Holding Register for animal species: cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs;
Means for individual identification of animal species: cattle, sheep, goats, and equide;
Holding Register for animal species: cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs, kept on each holding;
Documents for reporting the movements of animal species: cattle, sheep, goats, and equide;
Computer data base for animal species: cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs.
The Veterinary Directorate has established and kept Central Holding Register for animal species:
sheep, goats, pigs. It also registers all holdings for “other animals”, if needed.
The Central Holding Register contains in particular the following information for each holding:
the identification code of the holding;
the animal species as well as the number of animals kept on the holding;
Each animal keeper shall register the holding with the Veterinary Directorate, which shall issue a
unique identification code for the animal holding.
Each holding shall remain registered in the Central Holding Register within a period not shorter than
3 years after the last animal has left the holding.
The number of animals kept on a holding shall be updated at regular intervals.

text.b: 2. Identification and registration of bovine animals

page.text: Each bovine animal shall be identified by an ear tag, approved by the Veterinary Directorate and
applied to each ear. The keeper is responsible for timely tagging and registration of the animals. Ear
tags approved by the Veterinary Directorate have the same unique identification code which makes it
possible to identify each bovine animal individually as well as the holding on which it was born. Any
imported animal of the bovine species which has passed the veterinary checks at border inspection
posts shall be identified on the first holding of unloading in the Republic of Macedonia and in any
event before leaving the holding. The original identification established by the country of origin shall
be recorded in the computer data base as well as in the holding register. Any animal imported
originating from a country which applies the identification and registration system for bovine animals
of the European Union shall retain its original ear tags. Ear tags shall not be removed or replaced
without the permission of the Veterinary Directorate. Where the ear tags are illegible, severely
damaged or have been lost, the keeper shall report this to the Veterinary Directorate as soon as
possible, but not later than seven days after noticing the event. The Veterinary Directorate shall issue
a replacement bearing the same code within 30 days of notification only if it can be proven that the
ear tag belonged to that animal. In addition to the code and distinct from the previous one, the
replacement must bear a mark with the version number of the replacement.
Each keeper of animals of the bovine species shall keep an up-to-date holding register in manual or
computerised form containing all information concerning the origin, identification and, where required,
destination of animals, which he has owned, kept, transported, marketed or slaughtered. The keeper
shall report to the Veterinary Directorate all movements to and from the holding and all births and
deaths of animals on the holding, along with the dates of these events as soon as possible but not
longer than seven days. The holding register shall be available at all times on the holding and to the
Veterinary Directorate, upon request. The data from the holding register shall be kept in a period
determined by the Veterinary Directorate but which may not be less than 3 years after the last animal
has left the holding. In order to register the movements of bovine animals from the holdings to the
pastures located in mountain areas during the period from 1st May to 15th October, each pasture
located in mountain areas shall be given a special registration code and shall be registered in the
computer data base. The person responsible for the pastures shall keep a list of the bovine animals
which are put out to summer grazing in those pastures. The list has to be confirmed by the veterinary
inspector responsible for that area. The person responsible for the pasture shall notify to the
computer database the information contained in the list as well as every event occurring in the period
while the animal is on the pasture at the latest period of seven days after the date when the animals
are moved to the pasture and when the event occurs.
For each bovine animal which has to be identified, the Veterinary Directorate shall issue a passport
within 35 days of the notification of its birth or, in the case of an imported bovine animal, within 35
days of the notification of its re-identification.
In cases when the imported animals are identified under the regulation for identification and
registration of bovine animals of the European Union, the passport accompanying the animal on its
arrival shall be handed down to the Veterinary Directorate, which shall return it to the issuing country.
Whenever a bovine animal is moved, it shall be accompanied by a passport. In the case of death of
an animal, the passport shall be returned by the keeper to the Veterinary Directorate within 7 days
after the death of the animal. If the animal is sent to the slaughterhouse, the slaughterhouse shall be
responsible for returning the passport to the Veterinary Directorate.
In the case of bovine animals exported, the passport shall accompany the animal to the country of
destination. In the case of a lost, damaged, illegible, destroyed or stolen passport, a keeper of a
bovine animal shall request a duplicate passport not later than 7 days of noticing the event. The
Veterinary Directorate shall issue a duplicate passport, in the shortest possible period, but not longer
than seven days, which shall contain the number of the duplicate, while the original passport shall no
longer be valid. Any damaged and illegible passport shall be returned to the Veterinary Directorate. If
a calf under 42 days of age is moved from one holding to another, and if the passport has not yet
been issued, a temporary document containing the information set out for the passport shall be
issued by the Veterinary Directorate. The keeper is obliged to hand over the temporary document to
the Veterinary Directorate when the animal is 42 days old, or within seven days, if the animal dies
before it is 42 days old. Where the calf is still alive, the Veterinary Directorate shall issue a passport
within 14 days of the receipt of the temporary document. The passport must show information of all
movements as recorded on the temporary document.
The Veterinary Directorate sets up a computer database which contains the information for each
The data base must provide, at any time, the following information:
The identification code of all animals of the bovine species kept on each holding;
A list of all changes of holdings for each animal of the bovine species, starting from the
holding of birth or the holding of importation.
The data shall be kept in the data base for a period not shorter than 3 years from the death of the
bovine animal or after the last animal has left the holding.

text.b: 3. identification and registration of animals of the ovine and caprine species

page.text: Each animal of the ovine and caprine species shall be identified by an ear tag approved by the
Veterinary Directorate. Animals under the age of 6 months shall be identified by an ear tag, applied to
one ear, while animals of the age of 6 months and older shall be identified with an additional ear tag
on the other ear. The ear tags for the ovine and caprine animals under the age of 6 months have to
be applied in a period not longer than 30 days from the birth of the animal and in any case before the
animal leaves the holding on which it was born. The ear tag, approved by the Veterinary Directorate
shall bear the code of the holding on which it was born. For the ovine and caprine animals of the age
of 6 months and older, besides the existing ear tag, an additional ear tag shall be applied to the other
ear within a period not longer than 30 days after the animal has passed the age of 6 months. The
additional ear tag approved by the Veterinary Directorate shall bear the unique identification code
which allows each ovine and caprine animal to be identified individually. The keeper is responsible
for the timely tagging and registration of the animals. Any imported animal of the ovine and caprine
species which has passed the veterinary checks at border inspection shall be identified on the first
holding of unloading in the Republic of Macedonia within a period not longer than 30 days after
undergoing the checks at the veterinary border inspection, and in any case, before leaving the
holding. The original identification established by the country of origin shall be recorded in the
computer data base and in the holding register, together with the identification code allocated to it
upon arrival at the first holding of unloading in the Republic of Macedonia.
Each animal imported originating from a country applying the identification and the registration
system for ovine and caprine animals of the European Union retains its original ear tags. No ear tags
may be removed or replaced without the permission of the Veterinary Directorate. Where the ear tags
are illegible, severely damaged or have been lost, the keeper of the animal shall report this to the
Veterinary Directorate as soon as possible but not later than seven days after noticing the event. The
Veterinary Directorate shall issue a replacement bearing the same code within 30 days of notification
only if it can be identified that the ear tag belonged to that animal. In addition to the code and distinct
from the previous one the replacement may bear a mark with the ordinal number of the replacement.
Each keeper of ovine and caprine animals shall keep an up-to-date holding register in manual or
electronic form, containing information on the holding, on each of the animals of the ovine and
caprine species kept, and of controls carried out by the Veterinary Directorate.
The holding register shall be kept in manual or electronic form, and be available at all times on the
holding and to the Veterinary Directorate, upon request. Each keeper shall supply the Veterinary
Directorate, upon request, with all information concerning the origin, identification and where
required, the destination of animals which he or she has owned, kept, transported, marketed or
slaughtered. The data in the holding register shall be kept in a period not less than three years, after
the last animal has left the holding.
Whenever an ovine or caprine animal is moved, it shall be accompanied by a movement document
issued by the Veterinary Directorate and completed by the keeper. For the animals identified in
accordance with the Law, simplified movement documents for batches of animals may be used.
The keeper of the holding of destination shall keep the movement documents for a period not shorter
than three years from the slaughtering or death of the animal.
The Veterinary Directorate has established a computer data base pursuant to the Law on Animals
Identification and Registration (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 69/2004), which includes data for each
ovine and caprine animal and each holding. The data base shall be able to supply the following
information at any time: the identification code of all animals of the ovine and caprine species kept on
each holding, A list of all changes of the holding for each animal of the ovine and caprine species,
starting from the holding of birth or the holding of importation. The data shall be kept in a data base
for a period not shorter than 3 years from the death of the animal or from the departure of the last

text.b: 4. Identification and registration of porcine animals

page.text: The identification and registration of porcine animals may be done by registration of holdings and of
movements of porcine animals from the holding of birth and movements from and to all other
holdings in a computer database. The data shall be kept in a data base for a period not shorter than
3 years from the death or the departure of the last animal from the holding
The identification and registration of equide species (horses, donkeys, hinnies and mules) shall be
made on the basis of the movement document issued by the Veterinary Directorate.

text.b: 6. Identification and registration of other animals

page.text: The system of identification of other animals allows recording the identity of these animals, the
holdings on which they are kept, and their movements. The system of identification and registration
of other animals includes the species such as pet animals kept by natural persons and traders,
animals kept by zoological gardens, fairs and circuses, and all other animals that may pose a threat
to animal health and human health.

text.b: 7. Data access and protection, and control of the system

page.text: The funds for establishment of system for animal identification and registration and its application are
provided from the Budget of the Republic of Macedonia, donations and other sources. The funds
intended for maintenance of the system for animal identification and registration until 2008, are
provided from the Budget of the Republic of Macedonia, by gradual transfer of the costs onto keepers
until 2011, and from 2011 on, they will entirely be borne by the keepers.
The data on the keepers of animals and animal holdings kept in the registers and databases under
this law are strictly confidential and shall be protected in accordance with the provisions for personal
The Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy lays down the minimum number of
inspection controls for proper implementation of the animal identification and registration system
provided for in the Law on Animal Identification and Registration (“Official Gazette of RM ” No
69/2004). These inspection controls shall cover at least 10% of the holdings on the territory of the
Republic of Macedonia annually. The minimum rate of controls shall be increased where it has been
established that the animal identification and registration is not in accordance with the Law.
When the computer database is fully operational, the inspection controls may be reduced to at least
The Veterinary Directorate carries out the controls based on risk analysis, where all important factors
will be taken into consideration, including the number of animals on a holding and the number of
animals identified on a holding, human health, animal health, significant changes in comparison to
the previous years, results of the controls carried out during the previous years, especially keeping
the registers on holdings, proper keeping of the animal passports on holdings and proper
communication with the Veterinary Directorate and other criteria prescribed by the Minister of
In principle, the checks are not announced in advance, but in case of announced checks, the
deadline of 48 hours shall not be exceeded.
For each inspection control carried out, a standardised report is prepared setting out the results of
the controls, the reason for the controls and the unsatisfactory findings.
In principle, all animals on a holding should be covered by these controls, however, if for practical
reasons this is not possible, the Veterinary Directorate may provide for an appropriate sampling
system, provided that a reliable level of control is ensured.
The I&R Cattle System is entirely harmonised with the EU legislation, whereas I&R System for other
animal species shall be gradually harmonised with the EU legislation, for which purpose the Table of
Correspondence to the Law on Animal Identification and Registration is enclosed see

text.b: 4. Financing of veterinary inspections and controls (Council Directive 85/73/EEC).

page.text: The Veterinary Inspection is part of the public administration of the Republic of Macedonia and the
funding of its activities is provided from the Budget of the Republic of Macedonia.
Pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No 28/98) veterinary inspectors
charge the animal owners fee for the conducted veterinary-sanitary inspection and control. The funds
generated from the fees are income of the Budget of the Republic of Macedonia. The amount of fee
depends on the type of the inspection and control, and is determined by the Government of the
Republic of Macedonia in accordance with these by-laws:
1. Decision on the amount of fee charged for veterinary-sanitary inspection examination of
consignments of animals, products, raw materials and waste materials of animal origin,
semen for artificial insemination, fertilised ovum’s for reproduction of animals, and other items
with a potential to transmit diseases into Republic of Macedonia by crossing the border
(“Official Gazette of RM” No 36/94) and Decision on Amendment of the Decision (“Official
2. Decision on determining the amount of fee charged for issuing veterinary certificate on health
condition of animals and the amount of fee charged for veterinary-sanitary inspection (“Official
Veterinary enterprises within the primary veterinary health activity are authorised on the basis of
public bidding procedure to carry out a minimum compulsory volume of animal health protection from
infectious diseases, which is a measure of public interest. The veterinary enterprises are also
authorised for issuance of certificates on animal health condition. They charge fee for issued
certificates in line with the Decision on determining the amount of fee charged for issuing certificate
on health condition of animals and the amount of fee charged for veterinary-sanitary inspection
(“Official Gazette of RM” No 21/02). Pursuant to the Law, 80% of the funds generated from the fees
are income of the Budget of the Republic of Macedonia, and 20% are income of the authorised
veterinary enterprises, intended for covering the costs on issuance of certificates on animal health

text.b: 5. Veterinary checks of live animals and products entering the European Union from third
countries, including Border Inspection Posts (BIPs). Please provide clearly separate
information on checks carried out in the Republic of Macedonia before export (currently as a
third country) and checks and controls on consignments presented at external borders on
import into or for transit through the Republic of Macedonia.
Veterinary-sanitary inspections and control performed in the Republic of Macedonia before

page.text: The provisions of the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) and the
secondary legislation adopted on the basis of it, as well as other relevant legal regulations, describe
and regulate in greater detail all the procedures concerning inspections and control before
consignments of animal origin are exported.
The secondary legislation regulates issues of animal health related to diseases, animal health
measures related to animal diseases transferable to humans (zoonoses), veterinary-sanitary
inspection and control, veterinary protection and improvement of nature and environment, the
minimal compulsory level of animal health measures against diseases, compensations and
expenses for animal health measures, organization and implementation of activity in the field of
veterinary medicine and other issues related to veterinary field.
The system of control of live animals and products of animal origin is regulated with the provisions of
the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), related to the requirements and
type of veterinary-sanitary inspection and control in the inland trade. The control over the mentioned
system is performed by the state veterinary inspectors.
The veterinary-sanitary inspection and control in the inland trade is compulsory at loading, re-loading
and offloading of consignments of animals, products (except canned food), raw material and waste
materials of animal origin, animal corpses, confiscates of animal origin, stable manure, animal urine
and compost which are delivered by transport means out of the epizootiological area, as well as
ungulates and hoofed animals led out of the epizootiological area.
The state veterinary inspector in an epizootiological area, based on an 24-hour previously submitted
request by a client, performs a veterinary-sanitary inspections, and if the animals, products, raw
materials, waste materialss of animal origin, animal corpses or stable manure are shipped into
another epizootiological area, he/she confirms the inspection, verifying it with a stamp and facsimile
(transport certificate) put at the back of the veterinary certificate; as far as the consignments of
products of animal origin are concerned, the inspector issues a certificate of the veterinary health
condition of the consignments . A more detailed description of the system of control of live animals
and products of animal origin in the domestic trade is given in the answer to the question
In accordance with the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), poultry and
fish stocking for reproduction, production of eggs for reproduction, animal slaughtering , collection
and production of products and raw materials of animal origin and intended for export is allowed only
in establishments for export, for which the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy,
based on a proposal from an expert committee appointed thereby, confirms the compliance with the
requirements required by this Law, or the reguirements required by certain countries.
The Veterinary Directorate maintains a register of establishments for production of products of
animal origin, as well as a register of the export establishments in the Republic of Macedonia.
A more detailed description of the system of registration of establishments for export is given in the
The export establishments are under a constant supervision of a state veterinary inspector. If the
veterinary inspector determines that the export establishments no longer fulfills the required
conditions, or if the previously determined irregularities that harmfully affected the safety of the
production have not been eliminated during a certain period of time, or if he/she determines that the
export establishments used to export products or raw materials of animal origin that have not been
produced in the export establishments, he/she makes a decision for exclusion of this export
establishments from the register of export establishments, which terminates the right for utilization of
the export control number. The importing country is then informed on this decision, as well as the
competent committee of the European Union, and the veterinary inspectors at the Border Inspection

text.b: The procedure of veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of export

page.text: After the completion of inspections, the veterinary inspectors for export of healthy animals and safe
products of animal origin issue an international veterinary certificate for safety of the consigment .
The veterinary inspectors at the Border Inspection Post also perform a veterinary-sanitary inspection
and control of consignments of animal origin that are exported, and they either approve or disapprove
the export. International veterinary certificates are prepared and printed out by the compentent
services of the Veterinary Directorate . They are prepared in accordance to the relevant Directives of
the European Union regulating the certification and models of certificates for certain and specified
types of consignments of animal origin.
Veterinary-sanitary inspection and control at import into or transit through the Republic of Macedonia
Veterinary-sanitary inspection and control in the cross-border trade through the Republic of
Macedonia is performed on consignments of animals, products, raw materials and wastes of animal
origin, consignments that contain components of animal origin, artificial insemination material,
fertilized ovums s and embryos, feedingstuffs , stable manure, animal urine, compost or other means
by which a contagious disease can be transferred, that are exported, imported or are being transited
through and are loaded, re-loaded or offloaded in legal way.
\Veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of consignments that are imported, exported or being
transited is performed by a veterinarian inspector at the Border Inspection Post. Veterinary-sanitary
inspection and control of consignments of animal origin at import, export or transit are compulsory
because of proper protection of human health and animal health, control of facilities at the Border
Inspection Posts and transport means through which animal contagious diseases can be transferred.
The imported consignments, besides the veterinary-sanitary inspection at the border, have to
undergo an inspection at the customs procedure site, at the offloading site and at the facilities
The consignments of animal origin have to be individually marked in a proper way, and the
containers, palettes, packages with products and raw materials of animal origin, ponds with live fish,
packages with loaded frogs, snails, crabs, turtles, leaches, silkworms, shells and urchins, have to be
marked according to the provisions of this Law, with a legal label with imprinted stamp of the
veterinary inspector and veterinary control number of the facility in which they have been produced,
In accordance to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), veterinary-
sanitary inspection and control is not performed on products of animal origin that are personally
carried by passengers or are shipped in packages of weight of up to one kilogram, intended for
personal consumption, if they originate from a country or a country region from where import or
transit are not prohibited. In case of emergence of a contagious disease in certain country,
veterinary-sanitary control is also performed on products of animal origin in personal passenger
baggage, and personal baggage of the owner of the transportation vehicle that arrives from that
country. The passengers and the owner of the transportation vehicle are required to report the
products of animal origin in their personal baggage to the veterinarian inspector at the Border
Inspection Post so they can perform a veterinary-sanitary inspection and control.
The importer, freight-forwarder and the transporter that perform the transport utilizing railroad, a ship,
airplane or other mean of transportation, have to submit an individual request for each shipment of
animal origin to the veterinarian inspector at the Border Inspection Post for proper implementation of
mandatory veterinary-sanitary inspection of the consigment.
Consignments of animal origin at import, export or transit, have to be accompanied by a international
veterinary certificate, in a form that is in accordance with the legislation of the EU. It has to be
originally issued at the day the consignment has been loaded, for certain type of animals, products
or raw material of animal origin, for one importer, verified in a proper way, marked with a serial
number, written in the language of the country from which the consigment originates, or in the
language of the country of the final destination of the consignment.

text.b: Permit for veterinary-sanitary conditions for import, transit and warehousing

page.text: The import, transit and warehousing of consignments of animals, products, raw materials and waste
materials of animal origin, feedingstuffs , artificial insemination material, fertilized ovums and
embryos, stable manure, animal urine, compost and other items, by which a contagious disease
could be transferred, is approved by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy with a
permit, for which in each individual case he determines that there are no veterinary and sanitary
obstacles for their import, transit or warehousing according to the provisions of this Law. The permit
defines the veterinary and sanitary conditions for import and transit and it instructs the importer to
give it for inspection or to keep the consignment in quarantine, or to undertake other preventive
measures. The import and transit of consignments of animal origin is not approved if there is an
emergence of a contagious disease in the exporting country or in the countries through which the
shipment transits, or if there is a danger that the contagious disease could be transferred to the
For import of non-indigenous animals that live free in the wild, the importer has to obtain a prior
Import of live pathogenic microorganisms for the animals (bacteria, viruses, fungi, ectoparasites and
endoparasites) is forbidden. Only under an exception, the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy can approve import of pathogenic microorganisms for scientific and research purposes, to
It is not allowed to import products of animal origin that have not been produced in export facilities
registered by a competent authority of the exporting country.
If the veterinary inspector at the Border Inspection Post, during the inspection, suspects the safety of
the consignment , he/she is obliged to take samples of products, raw materials, and waste materials
of animal origin and feedingstuffs that are imported, without any compensation, for laboratory
analyses and determination of the safety of the consignment. The veterinary inspector at Border
Inspection Posts takes samples from consignments for which the Veterinary Directorate has issued
Import, transit and export of consignments of animal origin are only allowed at Border Inspection
Posts determined for that purpose by the Government of the Republic of Macedonia.
The importer is required to keep the imported animals in quarantine, in which all the inspections will
be performed and other conditions will be fulfilled, as regulated in the permit for import and permit for
quarantine. The quarantine site, type of inspection and quarantine duration, as well as the veterinary
enterprises which will implement the quarantine measures, are determined by the Director of the
With the exception of animals imported for attendance/participation in sport events, circus and other
events, exhibitions or fairs, dogs and cats or other pets accompanied by their owners residing in the
country for not longer then 15 days, as well as the ungulates, hoofed animals, poultry and rabbits
imported for immediate slaughter after the import, the permit can allow that animals do not have to be
quarantined, if the epizootiological condition in the exporting country is such that there exists no
threat of importing contagious diseases into the Republic of Macedonia. Animals imported for
slaughter have to be slaughtered within a time period not shorter than 24 hours and not longer than 3
days from the import into the Republic of Macedonia, in a slaughterhouse for imported animals which
fulfills the technical and technological conditions regulated by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and
The products, raw material and feedingstuffs in the free and customs zones and customs
warehouses are stored, packed and processed under a veterinary and sanitary control of the
veterinarian inspector at the Border Inspection Post.
The expenses incurred due to utilization of the measures related to import, export and transit of
animals, products, raw material and waste materials of animal origin, feedingstuffs, artificial
insemination material, fertilized ovum for animal reproduction and other items with which a
contagious disease could be transferred, the quarantine expenses, extended quarantine and the
measures associated with utilization of quarantine actions are paid by the importer, exporter, or the

text.b: State Veterinary Inspectors at Border Inspection Post

page.text: Veterinary inspectors are independent in performing their job duties, and therefore they have special
authorizations. Based on the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), The
veterinary inspector at the Border Inspection Post, during the inspection supervision, has the
to perform veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of consignments and accompanying
documentation, according to the provisions of this Law;
to verify the veterinary sanitary certificate for international trade for the export consignments;
to take samples of products, raw material and waste materials of animal origin, as well as
feedingstuffs without compensation for their value, for laboratory analyses and determination
to review the documentation of the legal entities and natural persons for cross-border trade
with consignments through Macedonia, related to utilization of the provisions of this Law;
to collect data and information from competent persons, witnesses, experts and other
individuals, if they are relevant to successful accomplishment of their duties;
to report criminal procedures and misdemeanor procedure when a particular performed act is
to maintain records on the exported, imported and transited consignments any time they cross
to perform control of the imported, exported and transit consignments and the warehouses at
to control the disinfection of vehicles, the equipment at the Border Inspection Posts, customs
warehouses, the free and customs zones;
to monitor the emergence and trend of animal contagious diseases in neighboring countries
and report to the Veterinary Directorate, and to perform other duties regulated by the Law on
Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) and by the regulations based on this
In performing the tasks determined by this Law and other regulations, the veterinary inspector at the
Border Inspection Post has the right and duty to instruct or undertake the following measures:
to forbid export, import and transit of consignments, regardless of where they come from,
where they are directed to and for what purpose, if the shipment or the transportation vehicle
do not fulfill the legal conditions, if he/she determines that the consignment is contagious,
suspects the consignment is contagious or if it origins from contagious area, determines that
the consignment is not safe and endangers the health of humans and animals, determines
that the consignment does not have the legal international veterinary-sanitary certificates or
other necessary documents, and if the products intended for human nutrition contain
hazardous material above the allowed limit;
to temporarily suspend the import, export and transit of consignments, if there are defects that
need to be removed from the consignment, or if they are related to the documentation;
to order warehousing of consignments, if the safety of the consignment needs to be
to confiscate the animals, products and raw material of animal origin from individuals who
cross the border of the Republic of Macedonia and to destroy them in a safe way, if such
measure is made contingent under regulation issued by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry
to order other animal health’s measures in accordance with this Law and obligations that
come from international agreements related to animal health;
to order disinfection of vehicles, facilities and equipment that are used for trade of
to forbid utilization of facilities at Border Inspection Posts, if they do not fulfill the legal
to forbid use of feedingstuffs , straw or other material intended to be used as pad, if they do
not fulfill the legal conditions regulated by this Law;
to forbid utilization of vehicles for transport of consignments, if they do not fulfill the legal
to order elimination of other irregularities in trade of consignments at the Border Inspection
Posts and to confiscate consignment that is subject to punishment in certain way;
The Customs Administration officer at the Border Inspection Post is required to report every
consigments of animals, products, raw material and wastes of animal origin, artificial insemination
material and fertilized ovum , fish, crabs, shells, snails and frogs and related products, wild animals,
feeding stuffs and feed additives , at import, export or transit to the veterinarian inspector at the
Border Inspection Post and is not allowed to start the customs procedure without his presence. The
officer of the Ministry of Internal Affairs and the officer of the Customs Administration within the
domain of their competence disallow illegal transfer, i.e. transport of consignments outside the
The consignments of animal origin that are headed towards the territory of the Republic of
Macedonia outside the allowed Border Inspection Posts, are kept by the official authorities of the
Ministry of Internal Affairs and the Customs Administration, and they report to the competent
veterinary inspection or direct them to a specified Border Inspection Post, if the transporter had been
heading to the wrong Border Inspection Post from ignorance or other justifiable reason.
Consignments of this type are treated according to the provisions of the Law on Veterinary Health
(“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) and relevant international agreements.
Based on the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), the Republic of
Macedoina covers entirely the expenses for the following:
1. Minimum compulsory level of animal health measures against contagious diseases, for:
Systematic and preventive vaccination against certain contagious diseases;
Field and laboratory pathological and anatomic diagnostic when suspecting emergence of
Prevention and eradication of contagious diseases during natural and other disasters, or
during emergence of particularly dangerous contagious diseases in the neighboring countries
or in the Republic of Macedonia, as well as laboratory examination and diagnostics of
contagious disease when the contagious disease or the cause for death needs to be
Exploring the epizootiological condition, adoption and introduction of new laboratory methods
for diagnostics and monitoring, new veterinary achievements, regulations, procedures and
Preparation of epizootiological study on risk of importing contagious diseases from other
countries and a study on economically optimal measures for elimination and eradication of
Secure a stock of vaccines, disinfection and other means for prevention, diagnostic and
Organized veterinary and medical education of animal owners;
Secure a continued field and laboratory diagnostic of contagious diseases, for which the
contagious disease or the reason for death should be immediately defined;
Equipping the veterinary inspection for field work and protection at work.
2. Compensation for damage due to euthanased or slaughtered animals in eradication of
contagious diseases, which are killed or slaughtered, as well as for products or raw material
of animal origin or items that are damaged, spoiled or destroyed while implementing
measures for eradication of contagious diseases;
3. Eradication of rabies, including the expenses for extraordinary vaccination of dogs and other
animals, performed in case of emergence of rabies;
4. Prevention, diagnostic and eradication of contagious diseases of the list “A” of the
International Organization for Animal Health OIE, and certain diseases from “B” list;
5. Mandatory examinations of ungulates for existence of glanders, and the expenses for
prevention and eradication of this disease;
6. Taking, packaging and shipping of material (blood and other) for laboratory analises , and for
the laboratory analises of the animal diseases as well;
7. Execution of dogs and cats, ordered during eradication of rabies and echinococosis;
8. Sanation of pastures contaged with the “fluke pastures” parasites;
9. Disinfection, disinsection and deratisation during eradication of animal contagious and other
10. Re-tuberculinisation of the positive or suspected bovine reactive components; and
11. Secure a stock of medicines and other auxiliary medical means.
The Government also accepts 50% of the expenses for the following:
Prevention and eradication of the following diseases: classical swine fever, New Casstle
Disease , sheep lung strongylosis, gangrenous mastitis in sheep, echinococosis,
enterotoxaemia in sheep and epidemic diarrhoea in lambs, bovine strongylosis, contagious
caprine and sheep agalactia, equine influenza, viraemia vernalis of carp and trichinellosis.
The Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, at the end of each year, issues Annual
Order for measures for prevention, control and eradication of animals contagiousus diseases for the
following year, against certain contagious diseases, and determines deadlines for implementation of
theoreder (Annual Order). The Annual Order is published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of
The funds to be withdrawn from the state Budget of the Republic of Macedonia, necessary for
implementation of activities in accordance with the Annual Order, are regulated by the Programme
(Fund) for Animal Health Measures . This programme is prepared by the Government of the
Republic of Macedonia for each year, and is published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of
Macedonia. The amount of these funds planned in this programme depends on the needs, in
accordance with the Annual Order and the funds available.
A special provision regulates that the expenses for preventive vaccination, diagnostic examination
and other expenses associated with the implementation of measures of the Annual Order are to be
charged to the animal owner, except in cases when these expenses, in accordance with the Law on
Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) are covered by the Budget of the Republic of

text.b: 7. Animal disease control measures, including contingency plans for list A diseases.

page.text: The control of animal diseases in the Republic of Macedonia is regulated by the Law on Veterinary
Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), and the following acts of the secondary legislation:
Rulebook on the way, procedure, and measures for prevention and eradication of the foot and
mouth disease (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No. 5/70; 32/70);
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of classical swine fever (“Official
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of Typhus (Salmonellosis) in poultry
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of Salmonellosis in poultry (“Official
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of animal Leptospirosis (“Official
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of New-Castle disease in poultry
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of animal tuberculosis (“Official
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of brucelosis of cattle, sheep, goats
and pigs (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No. 22/89);
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of Trout Furunculosis (“Official
Rulebook on the measures for prevention and eradication of Trout lentospiriasis (“Official
The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) defines the following:
The contagious diseases the prevention and eradication of which are of interest to the
The measures for detection and prevention of contagious diseases
The obligations of animal owners and breeders/keepers
The measures for prevention and eradication of animal contagious diseases
The minimal mandatory level of animal health protection from diseases
The operational plans for control over and eradication of certain contagious diseases.
The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) also defines and lists the animal
diseases. The diseases are defined in the following groups: especially dangerous contagious
diseases (the diseases of the list “A” of the OIE) and other contagious diseases. In case of
emergence of a contagious disease which is not listed in the Law or the carrier of which has not been
determined yet, the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy will order the measures of
the Law to be implemented and aimed at prevention agains this disease.

text.b: Measures for detection and prevention against contagious diseases

page.text: The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) defines the measures for
detection and prevention against emergence of contagious diseases. In order to perform detection
and prevention against contagious diseases, depending on its nature and level of danger, the
Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy can order one or more of the following
3. Determination of causes of disease and death;
5. Laboratory analysis of raw leather of anthrax;
7. Laboratory analysis of feedingstuffs in production;
8. Disinfection, disinsectin, deratization, deodorization, and decontamination;
9. Implementation of zoo-hygienic, zoo-technical and isolation measures;
10. Control of animals, products and raw material of animal origin in production and trade;
11. Control of animals at fairs, markets, pastures, exhibitions, auctions, animal stock markets and
12. Control over facilities for animal breeding and keeping;
13. Control over transportation means and conditions for transport of animals, products, raw
material and wastes of animal origin;
14. Control over facilities for animal slaughter, processing, warehousing and trade of products,
raw material and wastes of animal origin;
15. Collection and safty elimination of animal corps, confiscates and wastes of animal origin;
16. Control over the production, trade, utilization and storage of artificial insemination material,
17. Animal marking because of animal health reasons ;
18. Special conditions, limitations or ban on import and transit of animals, products, raw material
19. Limitations or ban on trafficking of people and animals;
20. Veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of feeding stuffs in production, trade and use for
21. Veterinary and medical education of owners of animals;
In order to get better acquainted with animal diseases, their prevention and eradication, the Ministry
of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy organizes training courses, publishes brochures, and
disseminates information related to animal diseases prevention, through public media, for the
owners of animals and people who are in direct contact with animals, products, raw material, wastes
of animal origin, animal corpses and confiscates.

text.b: Obligations of the owners and keepers of animals

page.text: For better prevention and protection against animal contagious diseases, the owners of animals are
obliged to undertake the following compulsory general preventive measures:
Secure safe drinking water for animals;
Secure and maintain healthy conditions in the facilities intended for animals keeping, in other
facilities where animals are collected, and in the sites where animals reside as well as in their
Secure hygienic conditions for animal milking and animal delivery;
Maintain the veterinary-sanitary order at public sites where animals are collected and sold, in
the animal transportation means, products, raw material and wastes of animal origin and
feedingstuffs , in facilities for animal keeping and pastures, as well as fulfill the technical and
technological conditions in the facilities for proper collection and slaughter of animals,
processing, storage of products, raw material and waste materials of animal origin and
Secure veterinary-sanitary conditions for production and trade of safe products and raw
Prevent import of animal disease carriers in facilities where animals are kept;
Undertake veterinary and sanitary measures in the technology for intensive/ animal breeding;
Safe elimination of animal corpses, confiscates and wastes of animal origin, garbage, animal
Implementation of preventive disinfection, disinsection, deratisation, deodorization and
decontamination in the keeping facilities and transportation vehicles;
Animal marking for animal health reasons; and
Other measures provided for by this Law.
The establishments , installations, and equipment for keeping of animals, ungulates and hoofed
animals with a capacity larger than 20 conditional animal head, and for poultry and rabbits with a
capacity larger than 10 conditional ainmal head , facilities for collection of street dogs and cats,
secured area for wild animals, facilities and equipment for production and storage of animal semen,
fertilized ovums for reproduction and embryos, as well as facilities for egg incubation and production
of one-day broilers, facilities and equipment for trade in animals, (fairs, exhibitions, animal stock
markets etc.), ponds for fish production and keeping, they all have to be arranged in such a way so
they do not represent a danger for human and animal health, to prevent import and spread of
diseases, to secure hygienic safe production and trade and to prevent environment and nature
Owners of animals, legal entities and natural persons that keep and breed animals, the legal entities
that perform production, processing, storage, trade and sale of feedingstuffs, as well as dog
breeders, animals in zoos, bee honeycombs and fish, are required to report animals, facililies and
equipment, and any change related to them, within 8 days, to the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy, for their proper recording in the register of facilities for animal keeping and facilities
for production, processing, storage, trade and sale of feedingstuffs.
The way and procedure for registration of establishments that are under the competence of the
Veterinary Directorate , is described in greater detail in the answer to the question

text.b: Measures for control over and eradication of animal contagious diseases

page.text: According to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), the owner of animals
is required to protect human and animal health from contagious diseases that are transferrable
among animals, as well as among humans and animals. In case the owner suspects possible
emergence of a contagious disease, he is required to report it to the veterinary inspector, or a
veterinary enterprises authorised for that specific epizootiological unit. If the suspicion is confirmed,
the veterinary inspector will order certain preventive measures, till the suspicion of possible disease
is confirmed or disregarded. The veterinary enteprises is required to take samples for laboratory
examination. If the veterinary enterprises does not do this, than the veterinary inspector will do this
action at the expense of the veterinary enterprises. The owner of animals is required to allow for
implementation of, or to implement himself all the measures regulated by law, and ordered by the
veterinary inspector, for control over and prevention of spread of contagious diseases.
If the suspicion is confirmed with the laboratory analisis, the veterinary inspector, depending on the
danger from the level of spread of the disease, will order one of the following measures:
separation of healthy animals from diseased or suspected ones;
Isolation of diseased and suspected animals;
Isolation of diseased or suspected yards or holdigns and ban for adding in or taking out of
animals in or out of the yards or holdings that have contagious disease or suspected to have
Ban or limitation for trafficing and trade (sale) of animals;
Ban or limitation for trafficing or trade with products, raw material and waste materials of
animal origin, feedingstuffs, raw material used for production of feedingstuffs, and other items
with which a contagious disease could be transferred;
Ban for holding and attending fairs, markets, exhibitions, sport contests and other public
Slaughter or euthanasia of diseased or suspected animals;
Ban for slaughter of diseased or suspected animals;
Ban for slaughter of ungulates, hoofed animals, poultry and rabbits;
Ban for issuance of animal health certificates;
Inventory and marking of animals for animal health reasons;
Ban or limitation for keeping and breeding of animals in certain/specified facilities for a
Ban or limitation for production, warehousing, trade and utilization of artificial insemination
material and fertilized ovum and egg incubation;
Ban for artificial insemenation and castration of diseased or suspected animals;
Preventive vaccination, diagnostic examinations and medical treatment of animals;
Taking under control diseased or suspected flocks of animals that are fed on pastures;
Ban, limitation for, or enlarged shooting of wild animals;
Systematic eradication of carriers of contagious diseases;
Euthanasia of street dogs and cats;
Termic processing of products, raw material and waste materials of animal origin that are
contaminated or suspected to be contaminated with carriers of contagious diseases;
Destroying contaminated items, products, raw material and waste materials of animal origin
and feedingstufs with which contagious diseases could be transferred;
Ban for utilization of contaminated facilities and equipment; and
Disinfection, disinsection, deratisation, deodorization and decontamination of facilities for
animal keeping, the folds, yards, rooms with incubators in them, facilities for processing,
storing and trade in products, raw material and waste materials of animal origin, as well as
other sites on which there used to exist diseased or dead animals or items that had been in
The above mentioned measures can be oredred in cases when there is a direct threat of emergence
of a contagious disease as well.

text.b: The minimum compulsory level of animal health care against diseases

page.text: According to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), the Republic of
Macedonia is required to secure the “minimum compulsory level of animal health measures against
Systematic and preventive – vaccination against certain animal contagious diseases;
Taking, packaging and shipping of material (blood and other) for laboratory examination for
Field, pathological, anatomic and laboratory diagnostics when suspecting emergence of
Prevention and eradication of contagious diseases in cases of natural and other disasters, or
in cases of emergence of particularly dangerous contagious diseases in the neighboring
countries or in the Republic of Macedonia, as well as laboratory examinations and diagnostics
of contagious diseases when the type of contagious disease or the cause of animal death
Examination of the epizootiological condition, adoption and introduction of new laboratory
methods for diagnostics and supervision, new veterinary and medical achievements,
regulations, procedures and methods for professional development;
Mandatory veterinary and sanitary inspection and control regulated by this Law;
Preparation of epizootiological studies on risk of import of contagious diseases from other
countries and study for cost-effective measures for prevention and eradication of animal
Issuance of certificate for animal health condition, certificate of origin and safety of products,
raw material and waste materials of animal origin, veterinary referral for animal slaughter
Secure a stock of vaccines, disinfection and other means for prevention, diagnostic and
Organized veterinary and medical education of the owners of animals;
Secure continued field and laboratory diagnostics of contagious diseases, for which the
contagious disease or the cause of animal death needs to be defined immediatelly;
Professional enhancement of veterinary officers, and
Equipping the veterinary inspection for field work and protection at work;
The Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, at the end of each year, for the following
year, orders animal health measures against certain contagious diseases and determines deadlines
for the implementation of these measures. (Annual Order for measures for prevention, control and
The Annual Order specifies the diseases, type of preventive measures to be applied for their
control/eradication and the deadlines before which these measures will be implemented. The
diseases included in the Annual Order are those that are believed to cause significant consequences
to human health (zoonoses) and animal health, and that cause significant economic damage.
These preventive measures are implemented by veterinary enterprises that, based on a public
procurement , are authorized to operate by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy
for a period of 5 years. Each year, the veterinary enterprises sign an agreement with the Ministry of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy for implementation of the measures. For implementation of
the measures specified in the Annual Order, the Government of the Republic of Macedonia prepares
an annual Program (Fund) for Animal Health Measures .
For animal health protection against certain diseases, the Government of the Republic of Macedonia
can prepare a multi-annual program for prevention and eradication of the disease.

text.b: Contingency plans for the diseases of list “A”

page.text: The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), defines the activities and
obligations related to the control over and eradication of the particularly harmful contagious diseases.
In case of emergence of large-scale natural disasters or epidemics that can cause disease to a larger
volume of animals, the Government of the Republic of Macedonia can propose declaration of state of
emergency on the territory of the Republic of Macedonia or one region of it, and therefore it can
propose one or more of the following measures:
Mobilization of veterinary officers and other citizens for implementation of the legal measures
Confiscation and utilization of medicines, equipment and transportation means in accordance
with the special regulation and temporary utilization of land and facilities for implementation of
the regulated measures for animal health protection ; and
Special tasks for the veterinary enterprices and other legal entities and natural persons, for
implementation of the legal measures for animal health protection, as well as involvement of
the units of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, units of the Civil Protection Services and the units
of the Army of the Republic of Macedonia.
As far as prevention from import of contagious diseases from other countries is concerned, the
Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy can order one or more of the following
Putting a section of the border of the Republic of Macedonia under a constant veterinary-
sanitary supervision and implementation of certain measures in the nearby municipalities;
Limitation or ban on import or transit of consigments of animals, products, raw material, waste
materials of animal origin and other items through the territory of the Republic of Macedonia,
by which a contagious disease could be transferred, or if there exists a threat that the disease
could be imported into the Republic of Macedonia with the import or transit of a consigments ;
Disinfection of the vehicles that enter the Republic of Macedonia, and for the passengers,
mandatory passage through a disinfection barrier; and
Limitation or ban for trafficing of people at the state border in both directions, in coordination
with the Minister of Internal Affairs, if a particularly dangerous contagious disease emerges in
the nearby border municipality of the Republic of Macedonia or in the neighboring country.
There exist no other more detailed operational and contingency plans for prevention from contagious
diseases, given that the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) does not
provide basis for development of contingency plans for certain contagious diseases. Such basis is
planned to be established in the new Law on Veterinary Health which is under preparation, and
which, in accordance with the Action Plan for European Partnership, should be enacted in the first

text.b: 8. Animal health – trade in live animals and animal products

page.text: The animal health – trade in live animals and products of animal origin is regulated by the Law on
Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98). This Law determines the obligations and
responsibilities of all entities in the production of and trade in animals and products of animal origin:
the obligations of owners and keepers of animals; identification and registration of animals; and
provisions for veterinary-sanitary inspection and control in the internal/domestic trade.
According to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), only trade in healthy
Legal provisions also regulate the obligations of animal keepers and the system for identification and
The owners and keepers of animals, for efficient prevention and protection against animal contagious
diseases, are required to undertake measures for securing and maintaining of healthy conditions in
the animal holdings , and to adhere to the veterinary sanitary order in public places. Detailed
descriptions of the animal keepers, related to securing satisfactory general preventive measures in
animal breeding are given in the answer to the question
The identification and registration of animals is regulated by the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official
Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), and the Law on Identification and Registration of Animals (“Official
Gazette of RM” No. 69/04), as a mandatory obligation of animal keepers aiming at improving the
control and eradication of animal contagious diseases, improving the supervision and efficiency of
veterinary control at import and export of animals, improving the monitoring and surveillance of
animals and holdings related to the measures for epidemiological supervision and control of
residues. A detailed description of the system for identification and registration of animals is given in
In case of animal sale or another way of animal alienation, or taking animals to pastures out of the
borders of a given epizootiological area, the owner of animals has to get a veterinary sanitary
certificate of the animals. This certificate on animal health condition confirms that it has been
determined that there exists no contagious disease at the site where the animals reside or originate
from, that these animals could potentially transfer further, and that the ordered preventive measures
and other diagnostic examinations have been implemented as stipulated in the Annual Order for
measures for prevention, control and eradication of animals contagiousus diseases. A detailed
description of the way and procedure for issuance of the Veterinary Sanitary Certificate of the

text.a: animals is given in the answer to the question

page.text: For the purposes of organizing contests, exhibitions, evaluations, getting animals into zoos, various
events associated with trafficking animals (circus, trafficking zoos, etc.), and for organizing animal
sales (fairs, animal stock markets etc.), as well as for sale of products, raw material and waste
materials s of animal origin out of the business premises, it is necessary to obtain a prior permit from
According to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), the veterinary-
sanitary inspections and control are compulsory for the ungulates, hoofed animals, poultry and
rabbits before slaughter, as well as for the meat of ungulates, hoofed animals, poultry, rabbits and
game, fish, milk and eggs, products made out of meat, fish, milk and eggs, honey, crabs, shells,
snails and frogs and products made out of crabs, shells, snails and frogs intended for public
Hoofed animals and ungulates have to be examined before and after the slaughter, the game after it
has been shot, in cases when their meat is intended for public consumption, then, the cattle, buffalos
and ungulates in cases when their meat is intended for own family consumption.
In cases of spread of contagious diseases, the inspection is also mandatory for sheep, goats and
swine, before and after the slaughter, when their meat is intended for own family consumption or for
Establishments , installation and equipment for animal slaughter, processing, production, collection,
storage, cooling and freezing, as well as trade in products and raw material of animal origin,
establishments for production, processing, purchase, storage and trade in milk and dairy products,
establishments for collection, sorting, packaging, storage and sale of eggs, establishments for
production of melange, estabblishments for purchase, processing, storage and trade of honey and
honey based products, they all have to be arranged in such a way that they do not represent a threat
to human and animal health, to prevent import and spread of diseases, to secure hygienic safe
production and trade and prevent possible contamination of the environment and the nature.
If the veterinary inspector, based on the inspection and other assessments, determines that products
are safe for human nutrition, those products are marked in a legal way and they are allowed for sale
for public consumption, or further processing. Products released for trade for public consumption,
without previously performed veterinary-sanitary inspection and control, and if they are not marked in
a legal way, are considered to be unsafe.
A more detailed description of the way and procedure for veterinary-sanitary control of products of
animal origin and the conditions that they need to fulfill for safety is given in the answer to the

text.b: Veterinary-Sanitary inspection and control in trade

page.text: The veterinary-sanitary inspection is compulsory at loading, re-loading and offloading of
consignments of animals, products (except canned products), raw material and waste materials of
animal origin, animal corpses, confiscates of animal origin, stable manure, animal urine and compost
that are shipped by means of transportation out of the epizootiological area, as well as for ungulates
and hoofed animals that are moved/guided out of the epizootiological area.
It is forbidden to load, re-load and offload consignments, trafficking of ungulates and hoofed animals
if during the compulsory veterinary-sanitary inspection it is determined or suspected that: the
consigment is infected with contagious disease, originates from contagious region; if there is no
veterinary certificate for the health condition; if the transportation vehicle does not fulfill the legal
veterinary-sanitary requirements or if the consignment does not fulfill the legal hygienic-technical
The transportation means with which the consignments are transported before loading and after the
offloading, have to be cleaned and disinfected under a veterinary-sanitary supervision.
Trade and offloading of consignments will be forbidden, if during the mandatory veterinary-sanitary
inspection and control, it is determined that: the consignment does not have a veterinary sanitary
certificate of the animals, or other certificate related to safety of the consignment, regulated by this
Law; if the certificates have defects, i.e. if they are incorrectly filled out or verified, hard to read and
do not make it possible to identify the animals or the products of animal origin; if the certificates are
issued by an unauthorized official, if there is no or incorrect verification of the freight bill at the loading
of animals or if the consignment originates from an area with an unknown epizootiological condition.
A more detailed description of the way and procedure for veterinary-sanitary control in the internal
trade, i.e. during loading, re-loading and offloading of consignments of animals, products (except
canned products), raw material and wastes of animal origin, animal corpses, confiscates of animal
origin, stable manure, animal urine and compost, is given in the answer to the question

text.b: 9. Public health sector, including the situation of agri-food establishments:
a) red meat with a link to large farmed game meat;
b) poultry meat with a link to rabbit and small farmed game meat;
e) minced meat and meat preparations;
