g) fish and fishery products, including fishing vessels;
j) “Balai-products”, animal products not listed in a-i.

page.text: The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), in its Chapter 3 – veterinary-
sanitary prevention in trade and production, regulates the responsibilities related to veterinary-
sanitary inspections and control in trade and at animal slaughter, products and raw materials of
animal origin intended for human consumption, as well as the responsibility for registration of animal
slaughter establishments, processing, production, collection, storage, cooling, freezing and trade in
products and raw materials of animal origin.
The secondary legislation that defines the above field in greater detail includes:
Rulebook on implementation of veterinary-sanitary inspections and control of animals for
slaughter, as well as products of animal origin (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No. 68/89);
Rulebook on conditions that have to be fulfilled by establishments for animal slaughter,
processing and storage of products of animal origin, related to construction, technical
arrangement, equipment, performance, technical personnel and hygiene (“Official Gazette of
Rulebook on safety of drinking water (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 57/2004);
Rulebook on methods of loading, re-loading, offloading of consignments of animals, products,
raw materials and waste materials of animal origin, on conditions that the transportation
vehicle has to fulfill, on the hygiene and technical conditions that the shipment has to fulfill
and the form of the veterinary sanitary certificate of the consignment(“Official Gazette of
Rulebook on performing veterinary-sanitary inspections and control, as well as records
keeping on residues and certain substances in raw material, live animals and products of
animal origin (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 8/2002);
The establishments for animal slaughter, processing and storage of products of animal origin are
Establishments for processing and cutting of game meat;
Establishments for meat processing and preparation of products of animal origin;
Establishments for cooling, freezing and storage of products of animal origin.
With regard to construction, technical equipment, capacity, methods of operation and organization of
veterinary inspection, they are classified as follows:
Establishments with larger production capacity industrial establishments;
Establishments with smaller production capacity crafting establishments;
Establishments (rooms) in households for milk processing and preparation of dairy products,
processing of honey and collection, sorting and packaging of eggs.
The above establishments have to fulfill the general conditions that are common for all
establishments, and are related to location, its yard, roads, water supply and drainage of waste
water, material used in facility construction, equipment, ventilation, lights, premises for equipment
sanitation, premises for general needs of personnel and veterinary inspection, and hygiene of the
employees. The special conditions are dependant on the type and scale of production.
The competences of the veterinary inspector for inspection and control in the segment of public
veterinary health are specified in the Law, according to which, besides the other, he/she performs the
Veterinary Sanitary Inspections inspection of animals, products, raw materials and waste
materials of animal origin, premixtures, feedingstuffs , water for animal nutrition and water in
the production process for hygiene safety, taking and forwarding material for laboratory
Regular inspections of products and raw materials of animal origin, feedingstuffs, water for
animal watering and water in the production process as well as presence of harmful
Prohibition of loading, re-loading and offloading of animals, products, raw material and waste
materials of animal origin and feedingstuffs if they do not fulfill the regulated and specified
Prohibition of usage of vehicles for transport of animals, products, and drinking water if they
do not fulfill the specified conditions;
Prohibition of trade and consumption of products and raw materials of animal origin through
which it is possible to transfer diseases from animals to humans;
Confiscation and destroying of products, raw materials of animal origin and feedingstuffs, that
Definition of ways for utilization of conditionally usable products and raw materials of animal
origin, feedingstuffs, or for reprocessing for other purposes;
Ordering elimination of irregularities in the production and trade of animals, products and raw
materials of animal origin and feedingstuffs;
Taking samples of products, raw materials and waste materials of animal origin,
feedingstuffs, water for animal nutrition and for the production process with a purpose to
examine if they meet the requirements for safety;
Prohibition of operation and sealing of working premises, equipment and items, that are under
his control, if they do not fulfill the regulated conditions;
Prohibition of animal slaughter, collection and processing of raw materials for production of
products of animal origin, if they do not meet the specified conditions;
Ordering elimination of organizational, hygiene-technical and other defects that cause
inadequate product quality or competence in performance.
The control in slaughter houses is permanent during the animal slaughter, while in the
establishments for production of meat, dairy and other products, as well as in the warehouses, the
control is proportional to the production and scale of work, and to the need.
At the site of production and storing of products of animal origin, the veterinary-sanitary control,
performed by the competent veterinary inspector should determine the following:
To make sure that the raw material intended for processing into a product, based on a prior
examination, is assessed to be safe for human consumption, or safe only for processing,
and that also refers to other raw materials and additives that are contained in the product,
through control of accompanying documentation – a certificate by competent body for
performed examination of products of animal origin at the production site and certificate of the
safety of the consignment of products of animal origin that is shipped with transportation
vehicles in the internal trade; organoleptic; and laboratory examination as required.
To make sure that the facility yard, premises, equipment and tools are clean, before and
Implementation of disinfection, disinsection and deratization;
Efficiency of thermal processing of products, and functioning of thermal processing
equipment, control of compactness of joints/stitches, as well as control of securing of
necessary temperature in establishments with thermal regime;
Only employees that have undergone sanitary examinations are allowed to participate in the
production process, so that they would not harm the product;
safety of the water in production process and its chlorination;
Control of warehousing conditions and transport of products.
In the trade, the control of products of animal origin includes control of accompanying documentation,
safety of products and hygiene conditions for warehousing and sale.
If the veterinary inspector, during the veterinary-sanitary control, suspects the safety of the products
of animal origin, he takes samples for microbiological and other laboratory examinations, temporarily
suspends the utilization of products for human consumption and defines the site and details of storing
of those products till a decision is made on their safety for human consumption. If, based on
organoleptic and/or laboratory examinations, it is determined that the product is not suitable for
human consumption, it is then necessary to order its safe elimination.
In the trade, the control of products of animal origin includes control of accompanying documentation,
safety of products and hygiene conditions for warehousing and sale.
If the veterinary inspector, during the veterinary-sanitary control, suspects the safety of the products
of animal origin, he takes samples for microbiological and other laboratory examinations (biological
remains, radionuclide), he temporarily suspends the utilization of products for human consumption
and defines the site and details of storing of those products till a decision is made on their safety for
If, based on organoleptic and/or laboratory examinations, it is determined that the product is not safe
for human consumption, it is then necessary to order its safe elimination.

text.b: a) Read meat, related to large game farms
Control of production of read meat

page.text: The animal keeper (cattle, sheep and goats, swine, ungulates) reports the slaughter to the competent
body at latest 12 hours before the slaughter occurs. By exception, it is not mandatory to report the
slaughter of swine, sheep and goats, if the animals are healthy, and the meat is intended for
consumption within the own household and the slaughter is not performed in a slaughterhouse.
Along with the report for slaughter, one needs to submit a veterinary sanitary certificate /condition of
the animals that are shipped to a slaughterhouse for slaughtering.
The slaughter establishments, depending on the type of animals for slaughter, the type of operations
inside and type of production, for proper technological and functional operation, are obliged to have
Receipt and temporary accommodation of animals for slaughter;
Production of fat and melting of tallow;
Cleaning, washing and disinfection of transportation vehicles.
Inspection of animals before the slaughter is performed at offloading of the animals in the
slaughterhouse, during their presence in the slaughterhouse and right at their heading for slaughter,
with which it can be determined if the animals are ill or suspected to be ill from diseases because of
which slaughter is forbidden, or diseases that can turn the meat into unsafety for consumption, if the
animals used to be treated with substances with special pharmacological effect, or if animals are
Animals that are suspected to have contacted a contagious diseases or some other disease, or show
unclear symptoms of possible disease – increased body temperature, if they are not in condition to
get up and move, animals with subcutaneous edemas, abscess or other changes, cryptorchid, have
to be isolated in separate room for suspected animals, in which they would be thoroughly examined
and monitored till a decision is made.
Confiscating and killing animals is performed if the inspection before slaughter reveals that the
animals exhibit symptoms of some of the contagious diseases (Anthrax, Black leg and other gas
edemas, rabies, glanders, Rinderpest, Pleuropneumonia contagiosa bovum, listeriosis, African swine
fever, Classical swine fever, Pestis Equorum, foot and mouth disease, Swine vesicular disease ,
porcine viral encephalomyelitis, Rhushiopatihe suum, sheep pox, melitococcosis and acute
salmonellosis); further, symptoms of diseases because of which, after the post-mortal inspection, the
carcasses and organs have to be removed/eliminated, the suspected animals that still have
increased temperature after 24 hours period of time, condition of agony or contusion of high degree,
eye epithelioma or symptoms of diseases of the orbital area, eyes are damaged or unclear with
neoplasmatic tissue, intensive infection, festering necrosis with unpleasant smell and cachexia.
Besides the above, slaughter is not allowed if there has been no veterinary sanitary certificate
submitted for the animals, if there are female animals in third grade of gravidity or if they are no older
then 8 days after delivery date, tired animals, disturbed or injured, dirty, or animals with no expired
prohibition for use after a treatment with veterinary medicines.
Before slaughter, the animals are stunned in a human and expert way, with a gunpowder gun or
pneumatic gun that hits the brain but does not destroy the brain tissue, or with electricity, then follows
urgent bleeding of the stunned animals and further processing of slaughtered animals after the full
When the veterinary inspector determines inappropriate construction of the equipment, inhuman
treatment of animals, or incorrect animal stunning, he forbids any further slaughter till the defect is
During the animal slaughter and processing of carcasses of slaughtered animals, any possible
contamination of meat and organs should be prevented.
The meat and organs of slaughtered animals are properly marked with paper signs/indications, till the
veterinary-sanitary inspection is over, so it can be clear what carcass they belong to (for bovine,
beef, calf, bulls and ungulates – with five-sectioned paper signs with corresponding numbers for parts
of carcasses and organs that are with appropriate size and color; for slaughtered pigs, they use four-
sectioned signs, and for slaughtered small animals the marking is performed as in the previous
cases, but with as many signs with numbers as there are organs or parts of the carcass at the
In cases when during the inspection a decision about the safety of the meat and organs can not be
made, they are marked with a special label that reads “retained” and are kept in isolated chamber for
retained meat, till the moment the final decision concerning their safety for human consumption
No part of a slaughtered animal may be removed or processed before the veterinary inspection of the
Veterinary-sanitary inspection of the carcasses and organs of slaughtered animals is performed
visually (by watching), by touching-feeling (palpation), notching meat, organs and lymph nodes
(incision), and if needed, with microbiological and other laboratory analises. It includes inspection of
the blood, carcass, head, tongue, alimentary canal, trachea and lungs, heart, liver, spleen, gaster,
intestines, abdominal wall, kidneys, diaphragm, pleura, peritoneum, fat, tallow, visible bones, pelvis,
joints/ankles, large lymph nodes, udder, reproductive organs, urinary bladder, pancreas and other
For determination of Cysticercosis in bovine, beef and bulls, it is necessary to perform incision of the
external and internal chewing muscles, tongue, heart, alimentary canal, inspection of the surface of
all muscles, in particular the muscular part of the diaphragm, and ribs muscles; in sheep, goats and
swine, it is performed by watching/observation of the visible muscles of the carcass, head, the heart
and the muscular part of the diaphragm.
A special inspection is performed on heads of ungulates for determination of possible existence of
glanders, by inspection of the mucous membrane of the nose and nostrils.
For slaughtered swine, it is necessary to perform inspection for possible trichinellosis, with a method
of compression or artificial digestion of collected samples of meat.
Based on the inspection, as well as on the results of possible laboratory analises, the meat and
organs of slaughtered animals are regarded as:
Marking the safe meat of slaughtered animals after the completed inspection is done with a seal that
reads the following text format: Veterinary inspection, name of municipality and date of inspection,
and for the export-registered slaughterhouses, the export control number. The seal is dipped in
permanent and safe color for human safety (usually with violet color), as follows:
For the bovine, swine and sheep meat, the seal is of oval form with dimensions 6.5
For meat of buffalos, goats and ungulates, a round seal with a diameter of 5 centimeters,
inside which it reads the type of meat.
The seal is put on certain places, in such a way that every part of the meat forwarded from the
slaughterhouse has to be marked with a seal.
For processed meat or organs, the seal has to be put on a label that is attached to the packaging, or
printed on a label or packaging in a way that secures seal damaging when the packaging is open.
After the inspection, the meat and organs of the slaughtered animals need to be cooled so that they
deep in the muscle tissue, and a temperature of +3
If the meat needs to be frozen, the freezing process is performed at a temperature of at least -12
for frozen meat, and at least -18
The veterinary inspector in the slaughterhouse maintains records keeping, as follows: records on
inspection of animals for slaughter after their arrival in the slaughterhouse depot, records on
inspection of animals before slaughter, , records on inspection of animals before slaughter
suspected to be ill, records on confiscated carcasses of dead animals, records on usability of
examined meat and organs at the slaughter line, records on the findings at the slaughter line, records
on the confiscates at the slaughter line, records on retained carcasses, meat sides (half) and organs
at the slaughter line, records on conditionally safe carcasses, meat sides and organs at the
slaughter line, records on meat inspection for trichinellosis.
In the Republic of Macedonia, there are 21 slaughterhouses for animal slaughter, for read meat, 9 of
which are with large scale production and 12 with smaller production scale. Seven (7) establishments
The procedure for veterinary-sanitary inspection of farmed game would be equivalent to the
To date, there has been no registered establihsment in the Republic of Macedonia for game farming.

text.b: b) poultry meat, related to small game farms and rabbit meat;
Control of production of poultry meat

page.text: Poultry intended for slaughter is subject to inspection by the veterinary inspector in the site of origin
24 hours before it is shipped to the slaughterhouse, and he issues an appropriate veterinary sanitary
certificate. The inspection has to be repeated if more than 24 hours have passed since the first
At latest 12 hours before the slaughter of poultry, the slaughter needs to be reported to the
The inspection before slaughter is done in slaughterhouse, with an aim to determine the health
condition (contagious diseases transferable to humans or animals, and if there are symptoms that
suggest a possibility for emergence of such diseases; presence of symptoms of other diseases or
disorders of the general condition that could make the meat hygienically unsafe for human
consumption; presence of symptoms that suggest that the poultry has been fed with substances with
certain pharmacological effect, or other material that remains in meat or organs as biological
residue), changes that occur during transport, where special attention is paid to breathing obstacles
and difficulties, emergence of cyanosis, apathy, motion difficulties, diarrhea, as well as secretion from
Slaughter will not be allowed without previously submitted veterinary sanitary certificate; next, if
during the inspection, they determine signs of agony or heavy health disorder from whatever reason;
if the poultry suffers from or is suspected to suffer from general form of diphtheria, salmonellosis,
avian influenza and new castle disease, ornitosis, psittacosis, haemorrhagic septicaemia of fowls,
rabies and geese influenza – diseases for which slaughter is forbiden if their existence is proven, and
if intoxication with any poison is determined; if poultry has been treated with antibiotics,
sulphonamide, or coccidiostatics or has been treated with these substances for prophylactic
purposes or nutritional purposes and there have been no sufficient time for elimination of these
substances out of the animal organism as prescribed on the manufacturer using instruction; if the
feedingstuffs that has been served to poultry contained substances of arsenic; if poultry intended for
slaughter has been in contact with poultry infected with one of the diseases for which slaughter is not
allowed; if healthy poultry intended for slaughter encounters in same slaughterhouse other poultry
that suffers from disease for which slaughter is not allowed; if there is a suspicion that the meat or
organs of the poultry can not be safe for human consumption.
Before slaughter, the poultry is stunned with electricity; then the neck blood vessels are cut for fast
bleeding; during the processing the carcasses of slaughtered poultry have to be cleaned of feathers,
they have to be without blood remaining or skin damages, and the limbs must not be messed up with
Inspection of slaughtered poultry is performed with a visual inspection of the head, external and
internal surface of carcass and internal organs, and if needed, with palpation and notching, as well as
laboratory analises. If during the inspection, any pathological changes are determined, the carcass
and organs are retained and inspected in greater detail afterward.
Based on the inspection and outcome of possible laboratory analyses, the meat and organs of
slaughtered poultry are evaluated as safe for human consumption, not safe for human consumption,
For the poultry carcasses evaluated as safe for human consumption, their parts or internal organs,
the sign for safety of the meat for human consumption is printed on a plastic folium or a bag inside
which they are folded, or a label with specially printed seal is put on the packaging, with an oval form
and dimensions 6.5 x 4.5 centimeters and text that reads the following format – veterinary inspection,
name of municipality, date of slaughter, and for the export slaughterhouses, the export control
After the inspection, the carcasses of the slaughtered poultry, the consumable parts and internal
organs need to be cooled so that deep in the carcass muscular tissue, the temperature should drop
, and for the consumable parts and organs it should drop to +3
If the meat of the slaughtered poultry is frozen, the freezing process is done at a temperature of at
for frozen meat, and at least -18
The veterinary inspector in the slaughterhouse maintains records keeping the same way as it is done
In the Republic of Macedonia, there are 2 registered slaughterhouses for poultry, and both of them
The inspection of (domesticated) rabbits (inspection at farm, inspection before slaughter, inspection
of meat and organs), labeling and cooling is similar to the one for poultry, but there is no farming of
rabbits in the Republic of Macedonia, norr there is farming of small game intended for human
The Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98) regulates that the veterinary-
sanitary inspection of hunted game should be performed at a special site determined for inspection ,
at gathering sites of hunting clubs.
Hunted game is reported to the competent veterinary inspector for an inspection that needs to occur
within 12 hours of the moment of kill.
As far as large game is concerned, internal organs need to be removed right after the kill – the heart,
lungs, liver and kidneys, then they need to be packed in plastic and marked bags, so their relation to
the carcass is declared, and they have to be kept till the inspection is complete.
Skin removal and further cutting of the hunted game is not allowed at the hunt site.
After the internal organs have been removed, a label is put on the hunted game, which contains data
about the hunt site and date of hunt.
When removing internal organs of hunted game, one should search for changes that suggest a
suspicion or presence of contagious disease transferable to humans or other animals, diseases or
changes of the general condition, based on which the game meat could be declared to be not safe
for human consumption, or signs that suggest that the game has been treated with substances with
pharmacological effect, or that the game has been consuming other material contained in the meat
because of which it could be not safe for human consumption or that there is a justifiable suspicion
for presence of biological residuals or other toxic material.
Carcass of hunted game has to be cooled to a temperature of +7
and within 24 hours it needs to
be forwarded to a facility for inspection, processing, in which it could be also evaluated and marked.
If the outside temperature does not make it possible to quick enough lower the temperature of the
, then the carcass needs to be put in an appropriate cooling device as soon as
possible, and no later then 10 hours after the hunt.
The inspection of the meat and organs of the game is done visually, and if needed, with palpation
and notching, as well as appropriate laboratory analyses if needed.
The inspections aims at determination of presence of possible diseases transferable to humans and
animals, malign and multiple swellings, multiple abscesses, presence of parasites in the
subcutaneous area or in muscles, intoxications, signs of natural death, slaughter or hunt/kill in agony,
injuries, bleeding or swellings, signs of decay, in particular in cases of late location of hunted game,
deviations in color, smell or taste, or consistency, in particular dilution and special sickliness, or
dirtiness that can not be removed even with thorough notching.
The meat of wild pig and bear has to be examined for determination of possible presence of larva of
Based on the performed inspection, the game meat is evaluated as safe for human consumption or
Marking the game meat is done with dipped seal, with dimensions 6.5 x 4.5 cm or with oval label on
After the inspection is completed, the game meat that is safe for human consumption has to be
cooled so that deep in the muscle tissue the temperature should drop to +7
frozen it should drop to at least -12
for frozen meat, and to at least -18
In the Republic of Macedonia, there has been no registered facility for game meat processing.
Besides fulfilling the general conditions that are common for all establishments intended for
processing of products of animal origin, the establishments for meat processing and production of
meat products, depending on the type of meat that is processed, the method of work and type of
production, have to have technologically arranged, functionally related and technically equipped
Production of chopped and shaped meat;
Durable, semi-durable and ready made food;
Warehousing and packaging of ready made food;
Warehousing of spices, additives and packaging material;
cleaning and disinfection of transportation vehicles.
The air temperature in establishments where meat is processed (cutting, bone removal, pickling,
The veterinary-sanitary controls performed at receipt of meat and during the meat processing and
development of meat products is exhibited in the general section.
In the Republic of Macedonia, there are 37 establishments for meat processing and production of
meat products, 8 of them are with large scale production, and 29 with lower production scale. Out of
The production conditions and controls are the same as it is shown in the response to the question d)
The milk and dairy products are safe for human consumption if they originate from healthy animals
and if during its production, processing, storing and transport, the regulated conditions are fulfilled.
The milk intended for human consumption can be produced only out of healthy animals examined by
the competent veterinary service and examined for possible presence of contagious diseases
(brucellosis, tuberculosis and other diseases, as well as mastitis caused by streptococcus and
The veterinary inspector controls the performed examinations of animals, the record keeping, the
milk production and dairy products, and if he/she determines that the animals are healthy, and if the
regulated legal conditions for the production establishments in which the milk and dairy products are
produced and warehoused are fulfilled, he/she allows the milk production as well as the dairy
The production establishments for milk processing and warehousing, as well as the vessels and
equipment in contact with the milk during the production process, processing and transport, have to
fulfill the hygienic and other required conditions. The veterinary inspector performs a control of
whether these conditions are fulfilled, through the following:
Inspection of the hygienic conditions during milk production and transport to the collection site
At milk delivery stage in the collection station, samples are taken from each milk producer, for
examination of presence of microorganisms and number of somatic cells, as well as possible
infestation with brucellosis at least twice annually, i.e. four times a year from the producers
that supply their products directly to the market.
Visual inspection of containers, milk tanks, milk vessels and other equipment, as well as
Control of efficiency of thermal processing of milk – each list for temperature registration –
thermograph before the thermal processing should be marked with date and verified with a
seal of the veterinary inspector. During the thermal processing, the thermograph is locked,
and after the thermal processing is completed, the data on the amount of thermal processed
milk is taken from the thermograph, as well as possible temperature changes and the time of
thermal processing, which is verified by the competent body with a signature and seal, and
keeps it for 12 months after the day of the thermal processing.
The efficiency of thermal processing is controlled by proving existence of phosphates and peroxides
If at the production site milk is kept for up to 24 hours, it has to be cooled to a temperature of 80 C,
and if it is retained for up to 48 hours, the temperature should be up to 40 C, after the pasteurization
is completed it could be up to 50 C, and during the transport, the temperature must not be higher
Based on the organoleptic or appropriate laboratory analyses, the milk or dairy products are
evaluated as: safe for human consumption, non safe for human consumption and conditionally safe
Safe for human consumption are the milk and dairy products that originate from healthy animals,
examined by competent veterinary service and examined for contagious diseases (brucellosis,
tuberculosis and other diseases like mastitis caused by streptococcus or staphylococcus).
Non safe for human consumption is milk that originates from milking cows that suffer from or are
suspected to suffer from tuberculosis, as well as milking cows that react positively to tuberculosis;
cows that are infested with brucellosis, suffer from leptospirosis, listeriosis, Q fever and cow pox;
cows that suffer from or are suspected to suffer from Rinder Pest, Pleuropneumonia Contagiosa
Bovum , foot and mouth disease, anthrax, Black leg , haemorrhagic septicaemia, rabies, infectious
bulbar paralysis, sheep pox, enterotoxaemia and melitocosis or are suspected that are infected with
these diseases; further, cows that are vaccinated with live rabies virus, and have not made 14 days
after the vaccination time, infected with salmonella or have become permanent extractors of this
bacteria; cows that suffer from acute or chronic udder mastitis, and the milk contains Streptococcus
agalactiae or Staphilyococcus aureus; cows whose health condition is in serious disorder; cows that
extract fester out of the reproductive organs; cows that serve for production of vaccines, during this
production and after it, while they extract pathogenic bacteria or viruses; cows that have been treated
with veterinary medicinal products that are applied to milk during the treatment and/or there has
been no sufficient time after the last treatment for its extraction out of the organism, according to the
user instructions of the manufacturer; if they are contaminated with carriers of human contagious
diseases: Vibrio cholerae, Corinebacteerium diphteriae, Strptococcus scarlatinae, Enteropatogeni e.
coli, Shigelae, mycobacterium tuberculosis, S. Typhi et paratyphi A, B and C viruses of hepatitis,
virus of polyomielitis; if in 1 ml. it contains more than 500.000 cells; if it is visibly polluted with dirt, if it
is preserved with chemical means, i.e. it contains other additives and bio-stimulators; if the color,
smell, flavor or structure are changed; if they do not correspond to the provisions of the Rulebook for
conditions for microbiological safety for foodstuffs in trade, if they do not correspond to the provisions
of the Rulebook for quantities of pesticides and other toxic material, hormones, antibiotics and
mycotoxins that can be contained in foodstuffs (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No. 59/83 and 79/87); if he
determines contamination with radionuclide above allowed level of activity; as well as the residues of
the milk cleaning; milk residues in containers after pouring and residues of vessel washing
Conditionally safe milk for human consumption is milk that originates from healthy milking cows that
have been kept in a stable in which an infestation has been detected or a stable that is suspected to
have milking cows infested with salmonellosis, tuberculosis, brucellosis, Q fever or cow pox; further,
milking cows that exhibit suspicious reaction to tuberculin test; milking cows up to 14 days of
vaccination against anthrax, and 14 to 90 days after vaccination against rabies.
The conditionally safe milk has to be pasteurized, sterilized or boiled under control of veterinary
inspector, after which it is safe for human consumption.
The conditionally safe milk is allowed to be transported to a dairy facility for thermal processing only
separated from milk that is safe for human consumption. On the container, tank or other packaging in
which the conditionally hygienically safe milk is transported, there has to be a clearly visible label in
the form of the letter “T” in red color, with a height of 25 centimeters.
If a thermal processing is impossible to perform, the conditionally safe milk is not safe for human

text.b: Thermal processed milk and dairy products are evaluated as hygienically unsafe for human

page.text: consumption if they are contaminated with carriers of contagious diseases that are transferable
among humans through foodstuffs, or contaminated with carriers of zoonoses, or are mechanically
contaminated with ingredients that could be harmful for human consumption, contain additives in
amounts higher that the allowed or forbidden additives, their content and organoleptic properties are
changed because of chemical, microbiological or other processes, if they do not fulfill the provisions
of the Rulebook for conditions related to microbiological safety that have to be fulfilled by the
foodstuffs in trade, if they do not fulfill the provisions of the Rulebook for quantities of pesticides and
other toxic materials, hormones, antibiotics and mycotoxins that could be contained in foodstuffs;
and, if contamination with radionuclide is above the allowed level of activity.
If milk Is assessed as unsafe for human consumption, the veterinary inspector will not allow trade of
that milk, nor processing into any other dairy product intended for human consumption.
Milk processing establishments in which dairy products are produced, according to their production
type, are divided into establishments for production of consumable milk, butter and cream, fermented
dairy products, milk powder, fermented cheese, cheese fondu and ice cream. Besides the general
premises, the above establishments have to provide technologically arranged, functionally related
and technically equipped rooms for appropriate purposes: receipt of milk, thermal processing and
cooling of milk, production of dairy products (by types), filling and packing, cooling and warehousing
of final products, shipping, storing packaging material and laboratory.
In the Republic of Macedonia, there are 70 establishments for milk processing and production of
dairy products. Six (6) of them are with larger scale of production, 53 are with lower production scale,
and 11 are household businesses. Six (6) of the establishments are registered for export.

text.b: g) Fish and fish products, including fish production ponds;

page.text: Fish intended for human consumption have to be reported to the competent veterinary inspector at
latest 12 hours after they have been caught, because of inspection.
Inspection of fish is performed with visual inspection of their skin, eyes, gills, anus and meat, and if
needed with notching, and fish that are suspected to be in process of decay, need to be opened for
inspection of their internal organs, and with laboratory analises if necessary (boiling test,
microbiological examination, chemical examination, examination of their radioactivity or presence of
substances of heavy metals and biological residues).
Based on the inspection, the fish are assessed as safe for human consumption or as unsafe for
Fish without organoleptic changes are declared as safe for human consumption.
Unsafe for human consumption are barbell with roe during fish spawn (March - April); fish ill from
contagious diseases in acute form; if when due to disease they exhibit visible changes of skin and
muscles; if fish head, eyes or gills are removed before the inspection; if fish gills are colored with
blood or color; if fish releases smell that is not typical for fresh fish and is a consequence of decay; if
they are attacked by parasites or parasite development forms; if they are clearly weak; if their eyes
are deepened and unclear; if their gills are covered with milky-white mucilage and if they release non-
typical smell; if their skin is covered with sticky mucilage; if their meat is so soft that it can reflect
fingerprints; if their anus is bulging, with gray color, and it releases the content of intestines; if fish
internal organs are removed and the internal membrane is unclear and covered with sticky mucilage;
if they are poisoned or dead because of a chemical material or killed by an explosive; if their
digestive system is damaged with a stab; if their organs show signs of decay, and the intestine
content is dispersed throughout stomach; if they do not fulfill the provisions of the Rulebook for
conditions for microbiological safety of foodstuffs in trade, if they do not fulfill the provisions of the
Rulebook for quantities of pesticides and other toxic material, hormones, antibiotics and mycotoxins
that can be contained in foodstuffs; if contamination with radionuclide above allowed level of activity
As far as supply of fresh fish on the market is concerned, there is a fresh lake fish and fresh fish from
fish ponds in the Republic of Macedonia .
Frozen fish on the markets in the Republic of Macedonia is always imported.
Before releasing for trade, by inspecting defrosted samples of frozen fish, it is necessary to
determine whether there have been changes during warehousing, because of which fish is no more
Unsafe for human consumption are those frozen fish and frozen parts of fish, which after the
defrosting exhibit the following: colored stains on their skin; fish meat is with changed color, smell,
flavor and structure; fish meat that contains parasites or their development forms; fish meat that does
not fulfill the provisions of the Rulebook for conditions for microbiological safety of foodstuffs in trade,
if they do not fulfill the provisions of the Rulebook for quantities of pesticides and other toxic material,
hormones, antibiotics and mycotoxins that can be contained in foodstuffs; fish meat contaminated
with radionuclide above allowed level of activity.
It is forbidden to freeze again once defrosted fish, except when it is intended for processing, and only
under supervision of a competent body.
For production of fish products, it is possible to use only prior examined raw material assessed as
To date, there have been no registered establishments for fish processing in the Republic of
In the Republic of Macedonia, there exists neither production nor catch of crabs or shells for human
Safe for human consumption are only frog legs without skin, and more specifically legs of the green
frog and of the brown small frog. In the Republic of Macedonia, there is no production of frogs.
Only the big garden snail and those related to it are allowed for human consumption; they have to be
alive, without damaged shell or conserved by freezing (they are frozen and stored at temperature of -
, after they have been separated from the shell and mucilage).
The establishments for snail processing, besides general premises, have to have technologically
arranged, functionally related and technically equipped rooms for receipt of raw material with
reception ponds; vessels or other appropriate type of equipment; for notching and primary
processing, cooling, freezing and warehousing, conserving and thermal processing, warehousing of
final products, packaging and shipment, non-eatable products and confiscates, cleaning, washing
There are two establishments for snail processing in the Republic of Macedonia, and both are
The producer reports for inspection to the competent veterinary inspector no later then 12 hours
before eggs are released for trade.
Eggs can be released in trade for human consumption only if the veterinary inspector that has
inspected the production site has issued a certificate for their safety.
Eggs are inspected visually for determination of their surface cleanliness as well as their shape, and
with illumination, and if necessary, by breaking and inspection of their content, as well as with
Based on the inspection, eggs are assessed as:
Safe for human consumption – they originate from healthy laying hens and are
Unsafe for human consumption – they contain carriers of tuberculosis, salmonellosis,
substances with pharmacological effect, harmful material, microbiological contamination, color
of yolk originating from synthetic colors, eggs in process of decay; eggs with mould, eggs that
contain external particles and bloody stains, the yolk and albumen are mixed, exhibit strange
smell and flavor, if embryo is visible at illumination, and if they have been incubated for more
Conditionally safe for human consumption are duck eggs and eggs that originate from a site
that is suspected to have salmonellosis. The packaging in which duck eggs are packed has to
carry the following label: “Duck eggs”, as well as a caution that they have to be boiled for at
safe for processing are eggs that are deformed or cracked, if at illumination it is determined
that the yolk touches the internal wall of the eggshell, eggs that are vastly dirty or have been
Eggs are stored in warehouses (coolers) at an air temperature of -0,50
for inspection which is performed before and during the warehousing, and for which record keeping is
maintained, that must reveal the date when eggs are stored in the cooler and the date of shipping.
Annual production of eggs in the Republic of Macedonia is 8.500.000 kilograms.
For production of egg products, it is allowed to use safe eggs, conditionally safe and safe for
Egg products are inspected in organoleptic way, and by need, in laboratory.
Unsafe for human consumption are egg products contaminated with carriers of zoonoses; that
have been in contact with persons infested with contagious diseases that could be transmitted with
these products; if they are mechanically contaminated; if they are colored or conserved with
forbidden preservatives; if they exhibit organolepticaly changed properties; if they do not fulfill the
provisions of the Rulebook for conditions for microbiological safety for foodstuffs in trade, if they do
not correspond to the provisions of the Rulebook for quantities of pesticides and other toxic material,
hormones, antibiotics and mycotoxins that can be contained in foodstuffs; if the inspector determines
contamination with radionuclide above allowed level of activity.
Two establishments are registered for production of egg products, and both of them are registered for

text.b: j) Balai-products, products of animal origin that are not listed in items

page.text: The beehive in which the honey is made, as well as the establishments for collection, storage and
packaging honey, are under control of the veterinary inspection.
Honey inspection is done in organoleptic manner and if needed, in laboratory.
Based on the inspection, the honey is assessed as:
Safe for human consumption – made by swarm of bees that has not contracted bee
contagious diseases, if it is organolepticaly unchanged and safe;
Unsafe for human consumption is honey made in beehive in which it is determined existence
of Pestis Apium, Akarosis (Honey Bee Tracheal Mite), Nosemosis, it is made of flowers of
vegetables of type Azalea, Rhododendron, Oleander and Mountain bay tree, mechanically
contaminated with admixtures, colored or conserved with chemicals for reduction of acidity;
honey with mould; honey in process of acetic fermentation; if it exhibits inappropriate smell or
flavor; which is microbiologically unacceptable and if it contains harmful substances.
Production of honey in the Republic of Macedonia is performed by individual producers organized in
bee keepers farmer associations, with various number of beehives, from just a few to as many as fifty
(50). Annual production of honey in the Republic of Macedonia is approximately 400.000 kg.
Produced honey intended for human consumption is purchased by three registered establishments
for processing and packaging of honey, out of which two are registered for export.

text.b: Approximation of the sector to the EU standards

Establishments for production of egg products
A detailed description of the number of production establishments for processing products of animal
origin, their capacity and average current production volume is given in the response to the question
With regard to compliance with the requirements of the relevant European legislation (Council
Directive 64/433 EEC; Council Directive 71/118 EEC; Council Directive 92/45 EEC; Council Directive
77/99 EEC; Council Directive 94/65 EC; Council Directive 92/46 EC; Council Directive 91/493 EC;
Council Directive 89/437EC; Council Directive 89/437EC), the industrial establishments need minor
investments for full approximation, whereas the crafting (smaller) establishments need larger actions.
There is a common need for adequate treatment of waste water and safe elimination of wastes and
confiscates that come from slaughter and processing.
According to the European Partnership Action Plan of the Government of the Republic of Macedonia,
it is foreseen that by the end of 2007, the Government will have enacted the following laws and
secondary legislation, with which the field of veterinary public health will be approximated with the
Law on By-Products, Wastes and TSE Agents
Law on safety of other products

text.b: 10. Common measures, including residue monitoring and zoonosis.

page.text: Residue monitoring is aimed at discovering prohibited medical treatment of animals, and determining
whether the conditions for maximum permitted quantities of residues of veterinary medicinal products
, pesticides and contaminants in the products of animal origin are fulfilled.
Residue monitoring is carried out in line with the Rulebook on the Method Used for Veterinary
Sanitary Inspection and Control and the Method of Recordkeeping of Residues and Particular
Substances in Raw Materials, Live Animals and Products of Animal Origin (“Official Gazette of RM ”
The abovementioned Rulebook prescribes the method for carrying out veterinary-sanitary inspection
and control and the method of recordkeeping of residues and particular substances, such as:
Forrbiden substances in raw products, live animals and products of animal origin:
Group A – substances which have anabolic effect and banned substances
1. Stilbene, stilbene derivatives, their salts and esters
Group B – veterinary medicinal products contaminants
1. Antibacterial substances including sulphonamide and quinoline
Chapter 1 from the Rulebook details general provisions and terms applied.
Chapter 2 from the Rulebook details the plan for residue monitoring according to which the
processes of production of animals for slaughter and products of animal origin are monitored for
possible determination of existence of residues in:
live animals and their excrement, body liquids and tissues;
The Veterinary Directorate develops the plan by 31 March during the course of calendar year, and
informs the EU commission on it, as well as on the plan implementation of the previous year,
monitors and coordinates the activities carried out by state veterinary inspectors regarding realization
of the plan, collects, processes and analyzes data out of the realized plan.
The plan for residue monitoring and detection determines residues of certain substances which are
inspected depending on the type of animals and products in accordance with the provided Appendix
2 in the Rulebook, in particular, regarding live animals, their excretes and body liquids, in animal
tissues and in products such as beef, pork, sheep, lamb, poultry meat, fish, milk – cow’s and sheep
milk, eggs, honey and wild animals as well as certain substances in drinking water and cattle feed in
facilities where they are kept and breed.
The plan is developed based on the achieved production of previous year. The volume and
frequency of sampling is detailed in Appendix 2 and 3 of the Rulebook.
1. Method of use of substances in Appendix 1 of the Rulebook;
2. Method of carrying out on-site control;
5. List of substances to be detected, analytical methods, standards for interpretation of the
6. Number of official samples to be taken, relative to slaughtered animals during previous
year, by type of animal, and in accordance with the volume and frequency of taking samples,
detailed in Appendix 3 of the Rulebook;
8. Measures that may be undertaken by an authorized person in case of determined presence
Chapter 3 from the Rulebook details controls carried out by legal entities and natural persons
engaged in the production of animals and products of animal origin. Allowed for trade are only
animals, which are not fed with forbiden substances or animals that are not improperly treated; or
animals, which are fed with approved substances for which the ordered prohibition for use has
expired as well as products originating from the above-mentioned animals. The doctor of veterinary
medicine keeps record of the method of treatment, type of administered drug, marking of treated
animals and duration of the prohibition for use of the animals he/she has treated. The owner of
animals may operate veterinary medicinal products only under control of a doctor of veterinary
medicine, adhering to the instructions of the veterinary medicinal products producer and duration of
Section 4 determines periodical control measures, not included in the plan, which may be carried out
in any time without prior announcement, and may cover the total chain of production of foodstuffs of
animal origin, feedingstuffs , as well as veterinary medicinal products during the production and their
Chapter 5 determines the control of animals and products of animal origin intended for export.
Chapter 6 determines the measures to be taken in case of disallowed action. If presence of residues
is confirmed, testing is carried out to determine the reason for the presence of disallowed quantity of
residue, and each carcass or product of animal origin where the quantity of tested residues is over
the maximum permitted level is pronounced un safe for human consumption, and animals treated
with prohibited substances are marked, recorded and safely removed. The farm or production facility
where the positively tested animals/products originate from, are subject to intensified monitoring and
control within the following 12 or 6 months.
The above mentioned Rulebook is in compliance with the Directive of the EU Council 96/23/EC.
Control and eradication of zoonoses is one of the measures of animal health protection, as well as
protection of humans from diseases that may be transmitted from animals. Elimination of zoonoses
is regulated by the Law on Veterinary Health and relevant secondary legislation.
The Minister of Agriculture, Forestry, and Water Economy, by the end of each current year, orders
undertaking measures for animal health protection regarding particular contagious diseases and
determines a timetable for carrying out those measures during the next year. (Annual Order for
measures for prevention, control and eradication of animals contagiousus diseases)
For proper implementation of these measures, the Government of the Republic of Macedonia adopts
annual Programme (Fund) for Animal Health Measures.
The Annual Order, which is carried out each year, covers the following zoonoses:
The Annual Order assumes mandatory vaccination of all dogs older than 4 months. As far as game,
all dead animals as well as animals suspected to have contracted Rabies must be compulsory
brought to laboratory testing for confirmation or rejection of the suspicion. Heads of all shot foxes and
wolves, packed in double polyvinyl sack, need to be sent to laboratory testing for Rabies, to the
In all residential sites where Anthrax has emerged within the last 20 years, mandatory vaccination of
all cattle, sheep, goats, and horses need to be performed. If the Anthrax emerges, besides
vaccination, other preventive measures to prevent spreading of this disease are also applied.
The Annual Order assumes diagnostic examination of cattle, sheep, and goats, for determination of
the carrier of Bovine Spongiform Encephalopatie presence.
The Rulebook on veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of the method and procedures to be
applied to animals slaughtering regarding Bovine Spongiform Encephalopatie, prepared by the
Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 85/2004),
precisely details the method of veterinary-sanitary inspection and control, in particular, during the
process of cattle slaughter, slaughter of sheep and goats, and appropriate procedures for elimination
and collection of particularly risky material, as well as taking and delivering samples for laboratory
The measures regarding this disease are described in greater detail in question
In herds where, during the previous year, Tuberculosis was diagnosed, tuberculinization of all cattle
for breeding older than 6 weeks is mandatory to perform. In the rest of epizootiological units, in
accordance with the plan of veterinary inspector, tuberculinization of all cattle older than 6 months is
carried out in 1/3 of settlements. An animal which indicates positive results to simultaneous
tuberculinization with bovine and avian tuberculin is considered positive. The owner of positively
diagnosed animals is compensated for the damage pursuant to Article 78 of the Law on Veterinary
If Tuberculosis is diagnosed during the course of the regular cattle slaughtering, the veterinary
inspector in the slaughterhouse informs the veterinary inspector in the epizootiological area from
which the infected animal originates from, who will take measures assumed in the Law –
tuberculinization of the cattle in the yard where the tuberculosis-infected slaughtered cattle originates
In holdings where Tuberculosis is diagnosed, simultaneous tuberculinization of the rest of the cattle
shall be carried out 2 months following the elimination of tuberculosis-infected cattle. As of the
moment negative results are obtained for all present cattle, simultaneous tuberculinization shall be
carried out after a period of 6 months.
Only cattle which had previously been tuberculinizated and had tested negatively for Tuberculosis
may be used for reproduction of herds.
In case of sale or any other transfer, animals must be previously tested, indicating negative test

text.b: Brucellosis in sheep, goats and cattle

page.text: In order to control and eliminate Brucellosis in sheep and goats, blood for serological testing is taken
from sheep and goats older than 6 months. All sheep and goats that move from winter to summer
pasturing and back, from one to another epizootiological area, are tested for Brucellosis before their
movement. Their movement is conditioned by the result of the test, which shall be proven with animal
health certificate. Doctors of veterinary medicine are obliged to deliver blood for laboratory testing
after each abortion. Animals which do not leave their epizootiological area during one year shall be
tested for Brucellosis only once. Prior to sale or any other kind of animal transfer, they must be tested
for Brucellosis and give negative result.
Sheep and goats that have tested positively for Brucellosis, following the results, shall be
euthanatized. The owner of the diseased animals, pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health, is given
Only sheep and goats indicating negative test results may be used for regeneration of the initial herd.
The total costs of blood taking and laboratory testing are financed by the Programme (Fund) for
In cattle, sheep or goat herds where Brucellosis occurred the previous year as well as in those where
Brucellosis has been diagnosed in sheep or goats during the current year, blood shall be taken from
In the rest of epizootiological areas where Brucellosis was not diagnosed the previous year,
according to the veterinary inspector plan, serologic testing shall be done on all breeding cattle older
Doctors of veterinary medicine are obliged to deliver blood for laboratory testing after each cow and
Animals that tested positively for Brucellosis shall be mandatory slaughtered after results are
obtained. The owner of diseased animals, pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health, is given a
In case of sale or any other kind of transfer, animals must be tested indicating negative test results
for Brucellosis. Only cattle that previously tested negative for Brucellosis may be used for
reproduction of the initial herd . The total costs of blood taking and laboratory testing are financed by
the Programme (Fund) for Animal Health Measures .
Eggs for consumption or eggs for reproduction may be may be released for trade or incubation, only
if they originate from chicken flocks free of Salmonellosis i.e. if they have health condition certificate
issued by a competent laboratory, and based on laboratory findings.
To prove Salmonellosis infection in domestic poultry, blood and smear from cloacae and carcasses
(laying hens and day old chicks) are taken in farms with over 500 heads of poultry. Sampling is
carried out in accordance with the following scheme:
For parental flocks - from each facility with over 500 heads of poultry, blood and cloacae smear is
taken from 30 heads of poultry or dead poultry (daily mortality), once monthly.
In incubation stations - one combined dust sample from all machines, immature eggs in embryo
stage and weak chicks (up to 30 smears) and 20 smears from the equipment and rooms once
For a day-old chicken (parental or commercial) - at acceptance on the farm, one sample of basis
from transport boxes shall be taken per every 1000 chicken (up to 10 samples), dead chicken during
transport, and during the first three days (up to 60 chicken each day).
For broilers during fattening - from each holdings with over 500 heads of poultry, cloacae smears
shall be taken from 20 heads of poultry and dead poultry, no later then one week before the end of
For broiler hybrids for egg production - from each holdings with over 500 heads of poultry, collective
feces samples and dead poultry shall be taken in the fourth week of farming and two weeks prior to
any movement or release for trade.
For laying hen flocks for production of eggs for consumption - from each facility with over 500 heads
of poultry cloacae smears and blood tests from 20 heads of poultry and dead poultry shall be taken
Components of animal origin used in poultry nutrition: samples from all consigments .
Sampling and their transport to the laboratory shall be done in accordance with the Sampling
50% of blood taking and laboratory testing is funded by the Program (Fund) for Animal Health
A mandatory trichinelloscope check of pork slaughtered in the private sector as well as of the pork
slaughtered in slaughterhouses, originating from swine farms, shall be done applying artificial
digestion and trichinelloscope methods, for control in order to eradicate and eliminate trichinelloscope
in domestic animals and game. Initial examination are done in slaughterhouses and veterinary
enterprises . Suspected and positive cases are delivered to the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, for
Hunters’ associations, concessionaires of hunting areas and National Parks shall deliver samples
(muscle segment of the diaphragm, segment of the masseter and/or intra-rib musculature) to the
Faculty of Veterinary Medicine, for Trichinellosis testing of shot wild pigs.
Total costs of all examinations are fully charged to the owners.
A more detailed description of the general measures for monitoring, control and eradication of
zoonoses, within the measures for monitoring, control and eradication of other animal contagious
diseases, is given in the answer to the question

page.text: The Annual Order for measures for prevention, control and eradication of animals contagiousus
diseases in 2004 (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/2004) (Annual Order) rendered by the Minister of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy on the basis of the Law on Veterinary Health , anticipates
diagnostic tests on cattle, sheep, and goats aimed at establishing the presence of the cause of
animals that indicate central nervous system disorder, thus the suspicion of Spongiform
encephalopaties in cattle cannot be eliminated;
animals that originate from the same breeding group, where the presence of Spongiform
encephalopaties in cattle has been established;
animals that descent from the heads in which the presence of Spongiform encephalopaties in
cattle has been established, born two years before or after the occurrence of the first clinical
all the cattle heads have been sent to regular slaughtering.
Diagnostic tests aimed at establishing the presence of the cause of Scrapie in sheep and goats
indicate clinical signs of the central nervous system disorder and changes in behaviour lasting
at least 15 days, which cannot be eliminated by medical treatment;
indicate signs of weakness, with no signs of infectious and traumatic diseases;
The Instructions for veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of the method and procedures of
animal slaughtering, which concern the Transmisive Spongiform Encephalopaties, rendered by the
Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water economy (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 85/2004), precisely
state the veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of the particular requirements in the course of
cattle, sheep and goats slaughtering. They also establish adequate procedures on disposal and
collection of the specific risk material, as well as sampling and delivery of material for TSE laboratory
tests. Regular slaughtering inspection covers all cattle heads over 30 months old, and 10% of sheep
over 18 months old. Due to the developing stage of the whole procedure, in the period from 17
August 2004 to 1 November 2004 the inspections on cattle over 24 months old had covered only
three larger slaughterhouses in the Republic of Macedonia. However, from 1 November 2004, the
measures and procedures regarding TSE as well as sampling for diagnostic testing of all slaughtered
cattle over 30 months old and 10% of sheep over 18 months, are applied to regular ruminants
TCE samples are taken by the state veterinary inspectors, and delivered by fast courier service in
cool condition to the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine – diagnostic laboratory for transmisive
TCE is diagnosed by the diagnostic method BioRad.

3-1 PRINCIPLE OF PrP DETECTION BY EIA
The TeSeE Detection Kit is an immune-enzymatic technique (sandwich format) using 2 monoclonal
antibodies for the detection of the abnormal prion protein, resistant to proteinase K i CNS (Central
Nervous System) of infected animals. The kit contains sufficient reagents to assay 192 tests.
The solid phase is composed of 13 strips of 8 polystyrene wells coated with the first monoclonal
antibody. The second monoclonal antibody is bound to peroxidase.
The assay comprises the following reactive steps:
1. Distribution of negative (R3) and positive controls (R4), samples prepared with the reagents
of the TeSeE Purification Kit (Ref.: 355 1144) in the wells of the micro plate coated with the
3. Washing, then distribution of the peroxidase-labelled antibody.
5. Washing, then revelation of enzymatic activity bound to the solid phase by addition of the
6. Stopping of the colour development, determination of optical density at 450 nm – 620nm
(bichromatism mode) and interpretation of the results.

For the automatic processing of the detection protocol, refer to the TeSeE Key 2 operator’s manual.

The test must be repeated if more than one of the negative control lies outside of this limit.

The mean of the positive control optical densities (R4 Ods) must be higher than or equal to 1.000.
The test must be repeated if the mean of the positive control optical densities (R4 Ods) is strictly
Samples with an optical density lower than the cut-off value are considered to be negative according
However, results situated just below the cut-off value (cut-off value – 10%) must be interpreted
cautiously, and the corresponding samples should be retested in duplicate, starting from the original
Samples with an optical density greater than or equal to the cut-off value are considered to be initially
reactive according to the TeSeE Detection Kit and should be retested in duplicate, starting from the
original homogenate, before the final interpretation.
After repeating the test, the sample is considered to be positive according to the TeSeE Detection Kit
when at least one of the 2 measurements is positive (greater than or equal to the cut-off value). The
sample is considered to be negative according to the TeSeE Detection Kit when these two values are
Samples retested in duplicate and found to be negative according to the TeSeE Detection Kit, but if
one of the 2 values is close to the cut-off value (cut-off value – 10%) must be interpreted cautiously.
Pursuant to the Annual Order in 2004, in case of TCE suspicion in cattle regardless of the age, which
indicate disorder in the central nervous system, and therefore the suspicion of spongiform
encephalopaties cannot be eliminated, or in case of death from any reason of cattle over 24 months
old, or sheep and goats over 12 months old, which indicate clinical signs of disorder in the central
nervous system and changes in the behaviour lasting at least 15 days, which cannot be eliminated by
treatment, indicate signs of weakness with no signs of infectious and traumatic diseases or indicate
other painful progressive changes, diagnostic testing is carried out.
In case of positive results, diagnostic testing is carried out in cattle descending from the same
breeding group where the presence of Spongiform encephalopaties has been established, and
animals that descend from the heads in which presence of Spongiform encephalopaties, born two
years before or after the occurrence of the first clinical signs of the disease in infected mother cow.
In case of finding positive results during regular slaughtering, the Veterinary Directorate is
immediately informed, and each part of the infected animal carcass is confiscated and destroyed in
an unharmful manner. The same is done with the carcasses which came into contact with it
(particular group of carcasses, or the carcass placed in front and the two carcasses following the
positive carcass on the slaughtering line)on account of possible cross-contamination, as provided for
in the Instructions on veterinary-sanitary inspection and control on the method and procedure of
animal slaughtering, concerning transmissive spongiform encephalopaties.
Besides the abovementioned, the procedure referred to in the Law on Veterinary Health regarding
undertaking measures for prevention and eradication of infectious diseases in case of suspicion or
establishment of infectious disease is applied. The animal owners are obligated to report a suspected
infectious disease immediately, as are the veterinary enterprises located in the respective
epizootioligical units. These enterprises, along with the veterinary inspector, take spreading
prevention measures – prohibition on putting into circulation, diagnostic tests, and other activities
and measures. The Veterinary Directorate, veterinary enterprises , the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine
monitor and study the epizootioligical status in the Republic of Macedonia and undertake measures
in line with the responsibilities laid down by the International Office of Epizooties.
According to the Instructions for veterinary-sanitary inspection and control of the method and
procedures of animal slaughtering, which concern the
rendered by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy (“Official Gazette of RM ” No
85/2004), there are several critical stages in the process of slaughtering and cutting up of cattle,
sheep and goat carcasses, when tissues or organs, which may indicate a high degree of infection
must be disposed from the food chain, and as specific risk material (SRM) to be removed and
The following parts of the carcasses are referred to as Specific Risk Material:
Skull, including the brain, eyes, tonsils, spinal cord of cattle over 12 months old, as well as
intestines from duodenum to rectum in cattle of any age;
Skull including the brain, eyes, tonsils, spinal cord of sheep and goats over 12 months old or
those which have permanent incisor, as well as sheep and goat spleen of all ages.
The abovementioned tissues which comprise the Specific Risk Material are also prohibited for import
in the Republic of Macedonia, pursuant to the Order on prohibition of import of animals, products, raw
materials and residues of animal origin in the Republic of Macedonia in order to prevent entering of
transmissive spongiform encephalopaties (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 98/2003, amendments No
29/2004), rendered by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.
The Order on prohibition of use of proteins of animal origin inclusion in animal nutrition is adopted in
2001, with which use of protein of animal origin (meat and bone meal, meat meal, bone meal, dried
blood plasma and other blood products, hydrolysed proteins, meal obtained from hoofs and horns,
meat meal obtained from poultry internal organs, meal obtained from feathers, dry bones, fish meal,
declaim phosphate, gelatine and other related proteins obtained from animals) including premixes,
animal feed, feed additives and concentrates containing such products, is prohibited in animal
nutrition for animals species for production of foodstuffs. This prohibition does not include milk and
diary products animal nutrition , fish meal in nutrition of domestic animals other of ruminants; and
dicalcium phosphate and hydrolysed proteins in feeding of other domestic animals.
Currently, the CARDS Project “Strengthening of Veterinary Service in the Republic of Macedonia –
Harmonisation of Veterinary Legislation with Aquis Communautaire” sponsored by European Agency
for Reconstruction (EAR), is underway in the Republic of Macedonia, . By the end of 2004, within the
short-term segment of the Project, the adoption of the general veterinary law and rulebooks
stemming thereof has been adopted, whereas in the long-term segment (end of 2006) adoption of
additional seven separate laws and related secondary legislation thereof, in the field of veterinary is
foreseen, which is detailed in the answer to question
In accordance with the Action Plan of European Partnership, in the second half of 2005 the Law on
Animal Secondary Products, Animal Waste Material and TCE agents will be adopted, thus
This method of waste materials of animal origin disposal is not applied in the Republic of Macedonia,
as a result of the absence of suitable capacities for that purpose.
The disposal of waste material of animal origin in the Republic of Macedonia is regulated by the Law
on Veterinary Health, according to which carcasses, confiscates and waste material of animal origin
are destroyed in an unharmful manner by burning in crematories, discarding into pit holes, or by
burying in animal graveyards or another appropriate places, determined by the veterinary inspector
on the proposal of the Ministry of Transport and Communication.
Even though the Law provides for facilities for collection and incineration of waste material of animal
origin, due to the absence of such facilities in the Republic of Macedonia, their disposal is carried out
only by discarding in pit holes, or by burying, in line with the conditions set in the Rulebook on the
method of unharmful disposal of carcasses and waste materials of animal origin and on conditions
which must be fulfilled regarding: the facilities and collection equipment, the harmless disposal and
establishment of the cause of death, as well as the means of transportation of carcasses and waste
materials of animal origin (“Official Gazette of SFRY ”No 53/89).
The field of animal welfare in the Republic of Macedonia is partially regulated by the Law on
Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98). The provisions of the Law on Veterinary
Health regulate prevention of unnecessary suffering and torment of animals, i.e. protection of animals
from unnecessary pain, tortures and injuries. The provisions define the obligations of owners and
keepers of animals, the animal treatment and securing animal health protection, accommodation and
nutrition, as well as meeting biological needs of animals.
Legal provisions regulate the animal keepers’ obligations related to animal welfare: each of them is
required to maintain and protect the animal health, as well as the human health from contagious
diseases transferable among animals, transferable from animals to humans and vice-versa; the
owner of animals is required to treat the animals in a human way, to protect them from pain, and to
request animal health protection for them on time; the sick or injured animal, when the illness or
injury is of such nature, that the animal life cannot be saved, should be killed in a painless way; the
facilities for animal keeping have to be adapted to accommodate the biological needs of any animal
category; they have to secure the necessary and safe feedingstuffs and water for the animals.
It is forbidden to torture the animals during their keeping/breeding, exploitation for work and training
dressage. Scientific and research examinations of animals can only be performed in medicinal,
veterinary and pharmaceutical scientific institutions, where the animals must not be a subject of
The animal euthanasia is also regulated, and the legal entity that performs collection and safe
elimination of animal corpses, euthanasia of street dogs and cats, and builds facilities for temporary
animal shelter, is obliged to apply methods that are in accordance with the international standards for
animal welfare when performing street animals’ euthanasia or when reducing their population.
Special provisions regulate the punishment provisions related to infringements of rights for animal
welfare if animals are not treated in human manner, are not properly accommodated or are tortured
At this moment, there is no specific legal regulation that would regulate through more specific
provisions the animal welfare, comparable to the legislation of the EU.
Animal welfare during the slaughter is regulated with the Rulebook for Performing Veterinary-Sanitary
Inspection and Control of Animals and Products of Animal Origin Before Slaughter (“Official Gazette
of SFRY” No. 68/89). This Rulebook defines certain measures: for offloading and accommodation of
animals in stables and folds, as well as prohibitation of unnecessary animal disturbance, cause of
pain and injury. Guiding animals is only allowed by using electrical tools, without sharp peaks and
canvas whips. Before slaughter, animals have to be stunned in a human and expert way.
Animal welfare during transport is regulated by the Rulebook for loading, reloading and offloading of
animal consigments, products of animal origin, raw material and waste materials of animal origin in
the internal/domestic trade, export, import and transit, the conditions that the transportation vehicle
has to fulfill, the hygienic and technical conditions that the consignment has to fulfill, and the form for
veterinary sanitary certificate of consignments intended for export (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No.
22/79). The loading, reloading or offloading of animals has to be performed quickly and in expert way
as to avoid animal torture, as well as contact with other animals. At the loading, reloading or
offloading site, the appropriate hygienic, technical and other conditions have to be secured, as
defined by this Rulebook. On open trucks or open boat decks, animals need to be protected from the
influence of sun, rain and wind, with appropriate covers. If transport is performed in closed
transportation vehicles during the hot summer weather, the transporter has to secure sufficient
ventilation in the transportation vehicle by opening windows/covers, by using ventilators.
When transporting animals (in particular young animals or chicken) that are sensitive to low
temperatures, during cold weather, the transporter has to secure appropriate temperature during the
The animals need to be fed and watered. If the transport takes longer then 24 hours, the animals
need to be fed and watered every 24 hours, and it should be performed inside the transportation
vehicle. If transport is done by railroad, and the animals need to be fed and watered during the
transport, then the railroad documentation associated with the consignment needs to specify the
railway station in which the animals need to be fed and watered.
Animal consignment for export, transported by railroad, need to be accompanied by an individual.
One individual can accompany no more then two train cars/wagons, and has to travel in the same
train. Only by exception, during suitable weather conditions for animal transport or in cases when the
transport takes no longer then 12 hours, it is allowed to transport animals without accompanying
individual, and the train wagon then has to be sealed.
According to the Action Plan for European Partnership 2004 of the Government of the Republic of
Macedonia, it is forseen to enact a Law on Animal Welfare in 2005, with associated secondary
legislation in 2006, which would be approximated to the respective legislation of the European Union.
The issues in the field of zoo-technique in the Republic of Macedonia are regulated by a law and
secondary legislation, based on the law:
Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 61/97).
Rulebook on conditions that need to be fulfilled by the quality breeding cattle and elite
breeding cattle, related to their production and breeding capabilities (“Official Gazette of RM”
Rulebook on the examination of male breeding cattle for reproduction (progeny testing),
according to a unique method (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 29/75).
Rulebook on the way and procedure for performing technical supervision, selection and
evaluation of the quality and elite breeding cattle (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 29/75).
Guideline on the way of maintaining records keeping in the register and forms of the register
of producers of quality and elite breeding cattle (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 29/75).
The Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 61/97) regulates the farming and trade in cattle,
sheep, goats, swine, horses, poultry, rabbits and other animals of commercial significance,
production of products of animal origin, production of and trade in semen and embryos, production of
