and trade in feedignstuffs and other issues related to livestock.
The secondary legislation regulates certain issue of the zoo-technique, as follows:
The Rulebook on conditions that need to be fulfilled by quality breeding cattle and elite breeding
cattle related to their production and breeding capabilities, defines the conditions that need to be
fulfilled by the quality breeding cattle and elite breeding cattle related to their production and breeding
The Rulebook on the examination of male breeding cattle for reproduction (progeny testing),
according to a unique method, defines the way and institution for examination of male breeding cattle
for reproduction, in order to evaluate its breeding value and transfer of its features to
The Rulebook on the way and procedure for performing technical supervision, selection and
evaluation of the quality and elite breeding cattle determines the way and institution for
implementation of technical supervision over selection and records keeping, and the way and
procedure for evaluation of breeding cattle and its distribution in classes.
The Guideline on the way of maintaining records keeping in the register and forms of the register of
producers of quality and elite breeding cattle, determines in greater detail the way of maintaining the
register and forms of the register of producers of quality breeding cattle and elite breeding cattle.
According to the Action Plan for European Partnership 2004 of the Government of the Republic of
Macedonia, it is forseen to revise the current Livestock Law by enacting appropriate secondary
legislation in 2006, which will be approximated with the respective legislation of the European Union.

text.b: a) General architecture of the legal basis; organisation and powers of different institutions
b) Respective field of responsibilities of competent authorities concerned.

page.text: The fundamental regulation in the field of plant protection which serves as a basis for adoption of
secondary legislation is the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and
6/00).This Law joins two areas regarding plant protection: plant health protection (protection of plants
and plant products from plant pests, plant health protection in trade and of imported consignments)
and plant protection materials (registration, production, trade of plant protection materials, prevention
of harmful consequences of their application on the human animal, plant health and on environment).
The Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00) created a legal basis for
establishment of the national plant protection service “Plant Protection Directorate”.
The affairs related to the field of plant protection, arising from the Law on Plant Protection (“Official
Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00) and the regulations stemming thereof, as well as the
implementation of the provisions referred to in the international conventions and agreements in the
field of plant protection that Republic of Macedonia is committed thereto, are carried out by the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy through the Plant Protection Directorate, the
State Agriculture Inspectorate, and the State Forestry and Hunting Inspectorate incorporated therein.
The Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy also authorises or assigns other
professional and health institutions (if prescribed conditions are fulfilled) to implement particular
provisions referred to in this Law or to intervene in the plant protection activities. The
abovementioned institutions are, as follows: Institute of Agriculture - Skopje, Institute for Southern
Crops - Strumica, Institute of Tobacco – Prilep, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food – Skopje,
Administrative supervision over the enforcement of the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of
RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00) and the regulations thereof as well as the control over the operations of the
Plant Protection Directorate are carried out by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Apart from the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 25/98 and 6/00), the plant
protection is also regulated by the Law on Production of Poisons (“Official Gazette of SRM” No
18/76) and the Law on Trade of Poisons (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 13/91) and provisions thereof
regarding plant protection materials, as well as by the Law on Safety of Foodstuffs, Products and
Materials in Contact with Foodstuffs (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 54/02) and provisions thereof
regarding plant protection material residues. These laws were drafted by the Ministry of Health.
Except for the abovementioned Ministries, the affairs concerning plant protection materials in the
segments of the approval procedure inspection and control of the plant protection materials and their
residues, are also carried out by the following authorised institutions and organisations:
Institute of Agriculture - Skopje, Institute of for Southern Crops - Strumica, Institute of Tobacco –
Prilep, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food – Skopje, Faculty of Forestry – Skopje, Institute for
Applied Biology - Skopje, Institute of Preclinical and Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology – Skopje,
Republic Institute of Health Protection – Skopje, and the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine – Skopje.
Administrative control on the enforcement of these laws and regulations and on the operations of the
public scientific institutions and faculties is performed by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and
Water Economy. On the Institute of Applied Biology, Institute of Preclinical and Clinical
Pharmacology and Toxicology and Republic Institute for Health Protection, the control is performed
The central level state institutions responsible for phytosanitary protection are the Ministry of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy and the Ministry of Health.
A number of professional scientific institutions and laboratories are included in the technical and
professional activities such are toxicological, physical and chemical, and biological researches,
monitoring, forecasting, diagnosing and identification of plant pests, as well as analyses of plant
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy is responsible for adoption of regulations on
the following: phytosanitary legislation; plant protection; control of cross-border circulation; second
stage of the plant protection materials registration; administrative procedure on registration of plant
protection materials. It is also responsible for inspection supervision over the implementation of the
The Ministry of Health is responsible for: the adoption of regulations in the area of plant protection
materials and their residues; performing a segment of inspection supervision; the first stage of the
registration of plant protection materials procedure – classification in particular group of toxins, and
the administrative procedure regarding classification of the plant protection materials.

text.b: Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy

page.text: The following competent bodies within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy are
responsible for execution of these respective responsibilities:
The Plant Protection Directorate - administrative, legal and international affairs, plant
protection and registration of plant protection materials;
The State Agricultural Inspectorate - - inspection supervision and control of the agricultural
plant throughout the country, control of agricultural and forest plants and plant products in the
cross-border circulation, supervision over enforcement of the Law and regulations thereof;
The State Forestry Inspectorate - - inspection supervision and control of forest plants
throughout the country, and supervision over enforcement of the Law and regulations thereof.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy may also assign other institutions from the
field of plant protection (authorised institutions) for particular technical activities.
The following competences fall under Plant Protection Directorate: plant health condition; registration
of plant protection materials, representation of the Republic of Macedonia in the international bodies
and organisations from the field of plant protection.
Plant protection – monitoring of the appearance, spreading, forecasting, diagnosing, and
identification of certain significant plant pests on the basis of particular programmes; providing
information and recommendations to the producers on optimal timelines and appropriate protection;
intervention in cases of quarantine and calamity; drafting regulations; issuing licenses for import of
harmful organisms intended for scientific research; measures for analysis and evaluation of the
health condition of plants and plant products aimed for establishment of the appearance and
spreading of pests in the country and abroad; determination of the risk level in contingency cases
and establishment of new plant pests; establishment of infected areas; keeping records; technical
monitoring over institutions' operations; notifying the countries of export on detained shipments of
plants and plant products due to unfulfilled phytosanitary requirements; exchange of information
concerning appearance and spreading of pests, in line with the bilateral agreements; providing
information on, and participation in the regional organisation EPPO and the International Plant
The regional reporters in the field of plant protection are located in Skopje, Kocani, Resen, Tetovo,
Strumica, Kavadarci and Bitola. They carry out monitoring of the appearance and spreading of plant
pests, provide information and suggestions to the producers on optimal timeline and appropriate
protection, participate in carrying out measures – interventions in cases of quarantine or calamity,
and keep records on occurrences and situations.
Registration of plant protection materials – The Plant Protection Directorate is responsible for:
drafting regulations; planning and establishing goals and strategies of the plant protection materials
policy; co-ordination of the activities and exchange of information with other bodies and institutions
engaged in the activities regarding plant protection materials; co-ordination of the Commission of
Plant Protection Materials activities; processing reports on biological and physical and chemical tests
and other operations necessary for registration of the plant protection materials; carrying out
administrative operations (issuance of licenses for circulation and application of plant protection
materials); administrative procedure on production and trade, as well as keeping register on
producers and legal entities engaged in trade of plant protection materials; administrative procedure
for authorisations; professional and administrative supervision over institutions authorised for carrying
out professional and technical operations regarding plant protection materials; co-operation with
other bodies and state authorities in the country; representation of the Republic of Macedonia in
international bodies and organisations in the field of plant protection materials.
State Agriculture Inspectorate, pursuant to the Law on Agricultural Inspection and other substantive
laws in the field of plant protection, carries out inspection supervision over: enforcement of laws and
orders rendered by the Minister regarding control over the work performed by legal entities
competent for implementation of regulations or ordered procedures for plant protection from pests,
quarantine facilities and records on health plant condition under quarantine supervision; the work of
legal entities entrusted with certain activities regarding plant protection; organisation of professional
examinations for detecting plant pests (or rendering quarantine decision ) and orders for eradication
of quarantine plant pests. Inspection supervision and control over: production and trade , more
precisely on prerequisites necessary to pursue business; trade of plant protection materials regarding
adequate packing, labelling, instructions, expiry date of the plant protection materials, licence expiry
date – approval for putting into circulation and for application; application - whether it is or not in
compliance with the declaration and instructions; keeping records of the trade and application, etc.
Health control on agricultural and forest plants and products of plant origin is carried out by border
plant protection inspectors. They carry out health control over shipments in the international trade
(import, export, re-export, and transit), issue phyto-certificates for health plant condition, take
samples and set phytosanitary measures. Furthermore, they perform control of the required
documents – licenses for the imported seed and planting material, as well as of the license, expiry
date, labelling, etc., on imported plant protection materials.
Health examinations are carried out on border crossings and locations defined by the Decision by the
Government of Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 34/00). The Government has
established the following border crossing points for circulation of plant and plant product shipments:
Tabanovce motorway – Presevo (Serbia and Montenegro), Skopje (railway terminal, post office and
airport), Blace – General Jankovic (Kosovo – Serbia and Montenegro), Blato – Blato (Albania),
Cafasan – Cafasan (Albania), Megitlija – Niki (Greece), Bogorodica – Evzoni (Greece), Dorjan –
Dorjani (Greece), Novo Selo – Zlatarevo (Bulgaria), Delcevo – Lisickovo (Bulgaria), and Deve Bair –
Besides the border inspections on imports, border inspectors for plant protection also perform
controls on export shipments, on the following 11 export terminals in the country: Skopje, Veles,
Kavadarci, Prilep, Bitola, Resen, Ohrid, Kicevo, Gevgelija, Strumica and Kocani.
State agricultural inspectors from the local units of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy are responsible for inspection supervision on: health plant condition throughout the country;
land, spaces for keeping plants and plant products, plant processing facilities, means of
transportation and devices for application of the plant protection materials; implementation of the
procedure for eradication of plant pests. The inspectors are also responsible for: imposing
phytosanitary measures; proper plant sampling for insight into their health condition control, from the
aspect of production and inland trade, of documents, certificates, and other documentation of natural
or legal entities possessing plants or plant products.
State Forestry and Hunting Inspectorate is responsible for carrying out inspection control on the basis
of the Law on Woods (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 47/97 and 7/00) and the Law on Hunting (“Official
Gazette of RM ” No 20/96, 26/96, 34/97, and 69/04), substantive laws in the field of plant protection,
as well as on the basis of the Minister’s Orders. It is responsible for: control over the work of legal
entities which have authorisation related to enforcement of regulations or ordered procedures on
plant protection from pests, supervision over quarantine facilities and records on health plant
protection under quarantine control; control of the work of legal entities entrusted with particular tasks
regarding plant protection; organisation of professional inspections aimed at detecting plant pests (or
quarantine order); ordering eradication of quarantine plant pests in the field of forestry; control over
authorised institutions for quarantine, and performance of other duties.
Authorised institutions – The Institute of Agriculture - Skopje, Institute for Southern Crops -
Strumica, Institute of Tobacco - Prilep, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food – Skopje, and The
The authorised institutions are engaged in: monitoring plant pests during vegetation; forecasting,
diagnosing and determining plant pests on the basis of respective programmes for particular
regions; setting preventive and appropriate measures; carrying out biological and vegetation
researches on the effectiveness, phytotoxicity of and resistance on the plant protection materials for
the needs of registration of the plant protection materials; physical and chemical testing; laboratory
determination of pests for research purposes (entomological, phytopatological, bacteriological,
viralological and other researches); health examination of seeds and facilities for production of
planting material during vegetation; health examination of seeds and planting material prior their
placing into circulation and issuance of certificates on health condition; suggesting measures for
producers protection; examinations and laboratory testing of samples forwarded by the competent
inspections; education of competent inspection services and persons engaged in the field of plant
The Plant Protection Directorate includes five laboratories for entomology, nematology,
phytopatology, virology and chemistry. The entomological laboratory employs two
Ph.D.(entomologists) and one M.A., the nematological laboratory employs one PhD (nematologist),
the phytopatological laboratory employs one Ph.D. (mycologist); the virology laboratory employs one
PhD (virologist) and one MA in herbology, and the chemical laboratory employs one PhD in
chemistry, as well as two laboratory technicians.

i.b: The Institute for Southern Crops - Strumica

page.text: The Institute for Southern Crops includes three laboratories: entomological, phytopatological, and
nematological: In these laboratories four PhD are employed (one entomologist, one phytopatologist,
one bacteriologist, and one nematologist), two MA (herbologist and entomologist), and two laboratory
The Plant Protection Directorate carries out vegetative tests for assessment of plant effectiveness
and phytotoxity and laboratory determination of pests for research purposes.. The Plant Protection
Directorate includes three laboratories: for entomology, phytopatology, and herbology. Five PhD
(two entomologists, two phytopatologists, one herbologist), and two laboratory technicians are
employed in the laboratories. Tests are performed for the needs of the registration procedure on
materials for plant production, and post-control of materials for plant production)

i.b: The Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food – Skopje

page.text: Two laboratories perform activities within the Plant Protection Department: : entomological with three
PhD and a laboratory technician, and phytopatological with one PhD – phytopatologist. The Farming
Department employs two PhD - herbologist and a laboratory technician.
Two laboratories operate in the Plant Protection Department : entomological laboratory with two
Ph.D. and a laboratory technician, and phytopatological laboratory with one Ph.D. – phytopatologist.
The Ministry of Health is competent for: adoption of a part of regulations regarding plant protection
materials, conducting a segment of the inspection supervision: the first stage of registration
procedure of the plant protection materials; toxicological tests; classification of the materials for plant
protection in a particular toxic group and for administrative procedure for decision on classification
of the plant protection materials in toxic groups. The Institute of Preclinical and Clinical Pharmacology
and Toxicology - Skopje and the Institute of Applied Biology - Skopje within the Ministry of Health are
responsible for toxic researches. The Ministry of Health is also responsible for drafting of primary and
adoption of secondary legislation relevant for the residues of the plant protection materials in the
Laboratory analyses of the plant protection materials residues are carried out in the Republic Institute
for Health Protection - Skopje, Bureau - Skopje, Bureau - Kumanovo, and the Faculty of Veterinary
Competent authorities within the Ministry of Health are the Bureau of Medicines and the State
Sanitary and Health Inspectorate white in the Ministry of Health.
Bureau of Medicines is responsible for drafting primary and secondary legislation relevant to toxins in
the first registration stage of the plant protection materials or toxicological assessment of the active
substances and the preparation, as well as classification in groups of toxins, on the basis of degree
The State Sanitary and Health Inspectorate is responsible for inspection supervision on
implementation of the abovementioned regulations, more precisely, carries out control on import,
export and transit of toxins and residues of the plant protection materials in imported foodstuffs.
Besides, it carries out control over toxins in production and trade of foodstuffs in the country, as well
as on plant protection materials residues therein. .
Pursuant to the Law on Safety of Foodstuffs, Products and Materials in Contact with Foodstuffs
(“Official Gazette of RM ” No 54/02), Food Directorate has been established. The Directorate has
began its activities in of January 2005. Consequently, a segment of sanitary and health inspection
shall be transformed i.e. transferred within the Food Directorate. In the transitional period before its
establishment, the responsibilities of the Directorate had been conducted by the State Sanitary and
These institutions within Ministry of Health conduct toxicological tests and evaluations of the plant
protection materials documentation: The Institute for Preclinical and Clinical Pharmacology and
Toxicology – Skopje, and the Institute for Applied Biology –Toxicology Department – Skopje.
Institute for Preclinical and Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology – Skopje performs: evaluation of
documentation for active substances and preparations; tests on the toxic features of the plant
protection materials. It also renders toxicological grades and proposals on classification in groups of
toxins. Tests of toxicological features of the plant protection materials in the Institute for Preclinical
and Clinical Pharmacology and Toxicology – Skopje, are carried out in 24 laboratories. In the
activities regarding toxicological tests and issuance of toxic evaluations 11 doctors – professionals in
several different fields are engaged. These professionals are also engaged in other activities in the
scope of the Institute. The number of engaged professionals is satisfactory regarding previous
The Institute for Applied Biology – Skopje performs tests on toxicological features of the plant
protection materials and issues toxicological evaluations and proposals on classification in groups of
toxins. The Department for Applied Biology within the Institute of Applied Biology performs tests on
toxicological features of the plant protection materials. For this purpose, it employs a total of five
experts in the relevant field. These experts are also engaged in other activities within the institute’s
operations. The number of experts regarding previous volume of operations is satisfactory.
Laboratory analyses on plant protection material residues in food are also performed. The State
Institute for Health Protection and regional institutes for health protection (Skopje and Kumanovo) are
responsible for the activities of the Toxins Commission and Commission for Determination of
The Republic Institute for Health Protection includes Departments for evaluation of health and
ecological risks, which are well equipped and employ highly skilled professionals. The Sector for
hygiene and health ecology includes Department for ecotoxicology and contaminants where analyses
of residues and pests are performed This Department employs five trained persons. The Department
is located in satisfactory premises, however, laboratory equipment and IT and communication
equipment, only partially satisfies modern standards. Therefore, it is impossible to perform
determination of all residues provided for in EU regulations.
Regional bureaus for health protection in Skopje and Kumanovo have trained staff (four employees)
and equipment for detection of residues and pests at their disposal, which is in the scope of their
The Faculty of Veterinary Medicine – the Institute of Food Safety - Department of Foodstuffs
performs analyses on residues of the plant protection materials. Three experts are engaged in the
analyses of the plant protection material residues and in other technical activities.

text.b: a) surveillance of the domestic production;
b) phytosanitary controls at the external borders;
c) measures to eradicate or inhibit the spread of harmful organisms;
d) status of harmful organisms listed in the EU acquis.

page.text: The state of the plant quarantine pests is monitored constantly by the Plant Protection Directorate,
through its regional reporters, the Agriculture Extension Service with more then 30 local centers
throughout the country and relevant scientific institutions.
The monitoring of the health status of plants, aiming at determination of presence or absence and
level of spread of quarantine pests in the Republic of Macedonia is performed on the basis of annual
programmes developed by the Plant Protection Directorate and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry
and Water Economy, and for the following pests specifically:
Potato viruses: (PLRV, PVA, PVM, PVS, PVX, PVY) Plum pox virus (PPV),
Data and reports are submitted periodically, as needed, and an annual report is prepared at the end
of year. They serve for determination of the status of certain pests in the country, for information
purposes, as well as for the purposes of accepted obligations deriving from bilateral agreements and
International Plant Protection Convention (IPPC) and the Regional Organization for Plant Protection
As far as production of seeds and seedlings for perennial plants is concerned, it is mandatory to
perform health checks at least twice during the vegetation, in accordance with the provisions of the
Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 6/00) and secondary legislation
based on it. The mandatory health examination of seeds and seedlings is performed by authorized
institutions. The Certificate (equivalent to the plant passport of EU) for health condition of crops for
seed and seedlings production is issued by authorized institutions. The seeds and seedlings that
have not been examined may not be released for trade. Only seeds and seedlings that are not
infected by quarantine pests or economically significant plant pests over the allowed presence,
defined by measures for determination of health status of the seeds and seedlings which are a
constituent part of the Rulebook for compulsory health examination of crops and facilities, seeds and
seedlings of agricultural and forest plants (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 52/86), are allowed to be
Storing plants and plant products in warehouses, facilities and rooms, is subject to a compulsory
health examination, performed by authorized institutions. The state agriculture inspectors perform
supervision to determine if the health examination is in accordance with the regulations, and based
on the minutes they issue a certificate for health condition of plants in the internal trade. If the
agriculture inspector finds presence of a plant pest, he orders specific measures for disinfection,
Internal/domestic trade in plants and plant products is allowed only for consignments that have no
presence of plant quarantine pests. The phyto-certificate for export is issued for plants and plant
products that have been examined by an inspector authorized for issuing phyto-sanitary certificate, or
by the nearest border-crossing inspector for plants protection, besides being monitored during the
Shipments of plants that are imported, that could potentially transfer pests, are required to be
examined at the entrance point at the border crossing. The health examination of the imported
shipments is performed by the border-crossing inspector for plants protection, at 14 border crossings
specified by the Government of the Republic of Macedonia.
The procedure starts with the following:
1. The importers, transporters (freight forwarders) report their arrival to the border-crossing
inspector for plants protection (first point of entry), they report consignments of plants or plant
products for which the examination is mandatory. They report in writing, with a review of all
documents accompanying that specific shipment. The customs service can not initiate the
customs procedure before the border-crossing inspector for plants protection has examined
the consignments of plants and plant products.
The phyto-sanitary examination consists of inspection of documentation that accompanies the
consignment, control of the transportation vehicle, control of packaging, health examination of plants
and plant products, as well as the records on the consignment examination and the findings.
Inspection of documentation that accompanies the shipment includes the following: review of the
phyto-sanitary certificate, permit by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy (if
required), freight bill, receipts and other documentation related to the consignment.
The above mentioned documentation is reviewed for identification of plant consignments, for
determination if the consignments fulfills the conditions specified by the Law on Plant Protection
(“Official Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 6/00), and for evaluation of the risk of import of plant
The plant consignment is identified through review of data on the phyto-certificate and check of some
of the accompanying documents with the packaging labels, the packaging itself and determination of
the content of the packed plants.
The border-cross inspector for plants protection evaluates the level of risk for import of plant
quarantine pests, by determining the scope of control (determining the number of packages for
sample taking, the number and size of samples, laboratory methods of examination, preventive
measures etc.). For evaluation of the level of hazard/risk, they use scientific and technical data, data
from earlier findings, data on earlier plants examinations from the country of origin, data on plant
quarantine pests for certain plants in the country of origin, phyto-certificate etc.
In case of need for laboratory examination of plants that would take longer period of time, and there
are no sufficient storage conditions at the border crossing, the border-crossing inspection for plants
protection in coordination with the customs service, by means of a special permit allows the
consignment to be transported to a site with adequate warehousing and under customs supervision
till the examination findings are available. The accompanying consignment documentation contains
data on the location and date of examination, signature and stamp verification by the border-crossing
Consignments of certain types of seedlings of perennial plants can be imported into Macedonia only
based on a permit issued by the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, which allows
the consignment to be put under a quarantine supervision – monitoring of the health condition of the
plants at the growing site for a period of two years.
When during a health examination, it is determined that the plants consignment is infected with
quarantine pests, or economically significant pests over the allowed limit, it can not be fully
exterminated with disinfection and disinsection at the import site. The border-crossing inspector for
plants protection forbids the import by means of a special decision, and orders the consignment to be
destroyed or returned to where it originates from. He can further order undertaking preventive
measures against spread of contagious disease (disinfection or disinsection of the transportation
vehicle, transport under cooling conditions etc.)
The consignments of plants that are transited or reloaded in other transportation vehicles at border
crossings (external border) of the Republic of Macedonia, are subject to a health examination. When
such a consignment enters the Republic of Macedonia at a border crossing where reloading is not
performed, the border-crossing inspector reviews the accompanying documentation only. If the
documentation is valid, the border-crossing inspector for plants protection approves the transit.
Consignments that need to be reloaded are put under customs supervision by the border-crossing
inspector at a specified site for reloading and health examination of the plants. The reloading must
not start without presence of the border-crossing inspector for plants protection.
Consignments that are transited through the territory of the Republic of Macedonia in closed
transportation vehicles (containers) where spread of possible contagious diseases is impossible, are
not subject of control of the border-crossing inspector for plants protection, he only reviews the
If the consignment is reloaded and it fulfills the provisions of the Law on Plant Protection (“Official
Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 6/00) and the relevant rulebooks, the border-crossing inspector for
plants protection approves transport of the containers, and they are put under a customs supervision
at a specified terminal for health examination and reloading of the consignment.
In cases when the documentation do not correspond to the required conditions or the plant
consignment is infected with quarantine pests, the border-crossing inspector for plants protection will
prohibit the import of the consgnment and will order its return to the sender.
The Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 6/00) and the related
regulations, represent a legal measure aimed at preventing spread and eradication of plant pests.
With an aim to prevent spread and eradicate possible diseases, the Minister can forbid the following:
growing certain plants at specified locations for a specified period of time;
limit import and transit through the territory of the Republic of Macedonia for certain plants;
limit trafficking of people through the state borders, if along a wider border section, or in a
neighboring country, quarantine plant pests emerges ;
instruct a quarantine supervision for certain plants that are imported for growing;
limit the trade of certain plants, and impose other measures in accordance with the
During an import of plants and plant products, if the border-crossing inspector determines presence
of plant pests, he is in a position to order the following:
disinfection or disinsection of the plants imported, and controls over the implementation of
return the consignment or destroy it;
forbid the import of that consignment; and
undertake other measures in accordance with the law and obligations deriving from bilateral
In case of emergence of plant quarantine pests inside the country, the agriculture inspector orders
one or more of the measures for the following:
forbid any access to the site where such quarantine pests have emerged, and removal of the
plants out of that site if there is a danger for spread of those pests;
to forbid any trade in plants infected with quarantine pests and their utilization for production
to order appropriate plant treatment under supervision of the entire process;
to make an exception to the legal regulations, and allow the plants to be released for trade, if
they are intended for industrial processing, direct consumption or for scientific purposes;
to order extermination of the plants.
The procedures for extermination of plants are undertaken only if they are infected with quarantine
pests that can not be eliminated in another way, and the plant can not be utilized for other purposes.
The extermination of the plants is performed in accordance with the Rulebook on Extermination of
Plants (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 4/78), and it is performed by: burning, treatment with chemicals,
burying in a way that prevents further spread of the pests.
Based on the Law on Plant Protection , lists of plant quarantine pests have been developed (“Official
Gazette of RM” No. 9/96) – list A1 that outlines the plant quarantine pests that have not been defined
in the Republic of Macedonia, and list A2 that outlines the plant quarantine pests that have been
defined for a specific area and are under a control.
Approximately 60% of the pests of Annex I, section 1 (pests for which it has not been confirmed to
exist anywhere in the Union and are relevant for the entire Union) Directive 2000/29/EC are on the
A1 list for plant quarantine pests.
Most part of the pests of Annex I section 2 (pests that have been confirmed to exist in the Union and
are relevant for the entire Union) are on the Macedonian A1 list of plant quarantine pests - Globodera
pallida (Behrens) and Globodera rostochiensis, Popillia japonica Newman, Spodoptera littoralis
(Boisduval), Clavibacter michiganensis(Smith) Davi set al. ssp sepedonicus (spieckermann and
Kottholf, Davi set. Al.. Ralstonia solanacearum(Smith) Yabuuchi, Melampsora medusae Thumen,
Synchitrium endobioticum (Schilberski) Percival, Apricot chlorotic mycoplasm.
Most part of the pests of Annex II, part A, section 2, is on the Macedonian A1 list of plant quarantine
pests, with a reference that those pests of the section 2 that are mostly approximated, are on the
Macedonian A1 list of plant quarantine pests – those that do not exist on the territory of the Republic
of Macedonia. Comparison by plants on which the pests must not be detected is not possible,
because such list has not been developed in the Macedonian legislation.
The list of pests of Annex III A 2000/29EC is partially approximated to the Order for ban on import
and transit of certain plants and for ordering quarantine supervision of certain plants that are
imported for growing (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 59/91). The inconsistence with acquis refers to
both the plants and the banned area.
Annex III B – has not been approximated with the Macedonian regulations with regard to the
protected zones, although certain plants are covered by Article 10 of the Rulebook on Healt Control
on Plants Trade Across the State Border (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 59/91).
The list of plants and plant products in Annex IV A 2000/29/EC has been partially approximated. For
certain plants and plant products there are special conditions that have to be fulfilled – Order on ban
of import and transit of certain plants and determination of quarantine supervision of certain plants
imported for growing (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No.59/91), Order on determination of quarantine
supervision for import of seedlings for perennial plants (“Official Gazette of RM” No.81/03), Order on
undertaking measures for import of potato in the Republic of Macedonia (“Official Gazette of RM”
No.88/00, and 92/02), and the Rulebook Health Control on Plants Trade Across the State Border
Import of the referenced plants is forbidden unless the special conditions are fulfilled.
Annex IV B - 2000/29/EC – has not been transposed in the Macedonian legislation (protected zones).
Annex V B - 2000/29/EC – has been partially transposed in paragraph 2 of Article 2 of the Rulebook
on Health Control of Plants Traded Across State Border (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 59/91). Health
examination is obligatory for all plants if they have not been treated in chemical, thermal, mechanical
or other way for elimination of a possibility of transfer of pests.
Annex V A I - 2000/29/EC has been partially transposed in Article 22 of the Law on Plant Protection
(“Official Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 6/00). There is no system of plant passports, but the
seedlings, before taking them from the location where they have been produced, as well as plants
that originate from infected areas, have to be issued a certificate of plant health status based on
which they can be granted a certificate of plant health status for the internal trade.
Annex V A II - 2000/29/EC – has been partially transposed in the Law on Plant Protection (“Official
Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 6/00) if the protected zones are not taken into account..
Annex VI - 2000/29/EC (Plants on which special measures can be applied) has been partially
transposed in the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 6/00).

text.b: 3. Quality of seeds and plant propagating material:
b) certification in view of marketing. Postcontrols.

page.text: The Law on Seeds, Seedlings and Propagating Material, and Variety Recognition, Approval and
Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 41/2000) regulates the production, processing, trade, export
and import of seeds, seedlings, and propagating material of plant origin, as well as the variety
The health safety of agricultural crops, as well as the seeds and seedlings is regulated by the Law on
The secondary legislation, i.e. the rulebooks, for implementing technical examinations during
vegetation period and for examination of quality properties of the seeds and seedlings include:
Rulebook on methods for expert and health control on agricultural plants’ seed production
Rulebook on norms of quality, packaging, sealing and labeling of seedlings for agricultural
plants (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No. 45/75 and 26/79);
Rulebook on agricultural plants’ seed quality (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No. 47/87, 60/87 and
Rulebook on the content and data that have to be included in the request for recognition of a
new variety, i.e. permit for introduction of a foreign variety of agricultural or forest plants, and
variety name (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No. 56/89);
Rulebook on quality norms and other conditions for trade in agricultural seedling material
Rulebook on quality norms for certain types of agricultural plants seeds and other conditions
for trade, as well as unique methodology for analysis of agricultural seeds (“Official Gazette of
The procedure for recognition of newly developed domestic varieties and introduction of foreign
varieties of agricultural plants in production is regulated by the Law on Seeds, Seedlings and
Propagating Material, and Variety Recognition, Approval and Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No.
The procedure starts with submission of an application for variety recognition and approval, by the
author or owner of the specific variety, or for foreign varieties, by the authorized agents in the
The request is submitted to the Directorate for Seed and Seedling Material that functions within the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.
The variety, according to the said law, can be adopted and approved/recognized if: it is distinct,
uniformed, stable (Distinctness Uniformity Stability - DUS), has a value as an agriculture crop and is
marked with appropriate variety mark, under which it can be registered.
In the Republic of Macedonia, there is no authorized and registered institution for performing DUS
tests, i.e. for examination if the variety is distinct, uniformed and stable. The variety recognition is
based on the examinations for determination of its agricultural value in several locations, on different
soil types and under different climate conditions. The purpose of these examinations is to
recognize/approve only those varieties that exhibit greater agricultural value relative to the existing
The party that submits the request is required to deliver the seeds material to the Directorate within a
month before the planting season, and to pay the expenses for the procedure for variety recognition
Rulebook on amount, methods and time terms for payment of the expenses for the procedure for
acknowledgment and authorization of the plant variety and plant variety control (“Official Gazette of
RM” No. 59/2001) has been adopted by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.
For the purpose of variety recognition and approval, the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy forms a Committee on Crops and Gardening Plants, comprised of experts from the fields of
selection and genetics, and employees of the Directorate for Seed and Seedling Material.
Based on the performed examinations of the variety, statistically processed data and confirmation of
the derived results/outcome, and by a proposal of the Committee for Adoption and Certification of
New Varieties, the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy approves a permission for
adoption of the variety and its introduction in the production process.
The validity of the permit for new variety recognition and approval for crops is ten years, and for vines
and fruits it is twenty years.
When a particular variety is recognized and approved, the Directorate for Seed and Seedling Material
prepares a list of newly recognized and approved varieties, which is afterward published in the
Official Gazette of the Republic of Macedonia.
The entire material in this field is regulated by the Law on Seeds, Seedlings and Propagating
Material, and Variety Recognition, Approval and Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 41/2000).
Seeds can be released for trade only if they originate from varieties that are entered into the varieties’
list of the Republic of Macedonia and thus published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of
Trade in seeds and seedlings can only be performed by legal trade companies that are registered in
the Register of Traders, maintained in the Directorate for Seed and Seedling Material.
The producer of the seed material is required to report the production of seed material to the
Directorate for Seed and Seedling Material within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy, at no later then one month after the planting process has been completed.
Seed material released for trade has to be produced under control of authorized institution, with a
The control of the seed crops is performed by authorized institutions, their technical personnel goes
out to the field, performs the inspection and pays attention if the crops fulfill the legal norms for
approval of seed crops (preceding crop, space isolation, identity and variety purity, presence of
diseases and pests, condition of the crop and yield estimate). After the performed control, they issue
a “Certificate for recognition of a seed crop”, and besides other data, it outlines an estimate of
expected yield of natural seed material.
This certificate can be compared to the OECD certificate, but the OECD certificate only outlines the
quantity of seed that is released for trade.
Pre-control and post-control tests for verification of variety purity is also regulated by the Law, but in
practice, this control measure is not implemented. Control of variety purity is implemented only based
on a request of an interested party.
Examination of the seed quality is performed in authorized institutions – laboratories, that need to
fulfill certain legal conditions related to technical personnel and other conditions. The results of the
examinations of the seed quality properties are issued in a “Report on Seed Quality”, which contains
the following data: Serial No. of the Certificate for recognition of seed crop, plant species, variety,
category, seed purity, content of admixture, germination energy in %, seed germination rate in %,
In the Republic of Macedonia, there is no accredited laboratory for examination of the seed quality
properties, which would be a member of the International Seed Testing Association – ISTA, and that
would operate under the ISTA Procedures and authorized to issue an Orange certificate.
The content of the “Report on Seed Quality ” issued by an authorized laboratory is similar to the
content of the Orange certificate – ISTA certificate, and is not adopted by the international seed trade
The seeds released for trade must be accompanied by a Declaration of Seed Quality, with an invoice
The seeds released for trade must have attached a small “product declaration” on its packaging,
issued by the processor of domestic seeds or importer of the imported seeds, and it contains a
portion of the data of the large declaration. The large declaration comprises the data from the
received Report on seed quality issued by the authorized laboratory.
Like as large declarations, the small declarations (labels) that are attached to the shipment are
prepared by the Preprocessors of the domestic seed or importers for the imported seed.
The protection of new varieties of plants is regulated by the Law on Seeds, Seedlings and
Propagating Material, and Variety Recognition, Approval and Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No.
The request for variety protection is submitted by the owner, author, an authorized agent or a legal
successor. If a variety is developed by more authors, they all submit a joint request. The party that
submits this request is required to declare that the variety is a new one and not maintained by other
parties. He is also required to declare the variety trademark or indicate a temporary trademark. He is
also required to submit samples of the seed material and all necessary documents like Variety
Trademark and Certificate for Recognized or Approved Variety, at least a month earlier than the
The Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy establishes a Committee for Recognized
and Approved Varieties Protection, comprised of technical personnel in the field of genetics and plant
selection, as well as a lawyer.
If the variety, according to the trademark, fulfills the conditions for becoming a protected variety, the
Directorate performs field and other examinations. The Directorate will not perform any examination if
results from official institutions of countries members of the International Union for Protection of New
Based on a proposal by the Committee for Recognized and Approved Varieties Protection, the
Minister issues a Certificate for the protected variety. The form, content and the manner in which the
certificate is issued are regulated by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.
The Certificate for variety protection is valid for 25 years for crops, and for the vine, hops, potato and
fruits, it is valid for 30 years.
Our analysis at present reveals that it is necessary to prepare a new Law on Protection of Agricultural
Plants, approximated with the UPOV Convention. Currently, we are in a preparation phase for
development of a draft text for the new Law for protection of new varieties. This law is expected to be
Republic of Macedonia, i.e. the Directorate for Seeds and Seedling Material within the Ministry of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, is not a member of the International Union for Protection
of New Varieties of Plant (UPOV). Republic of Macedonia through its Directorate for Seeds and
Seedling Material as institution, plans to become a member of this organization within the next 5
years, and to therefore adopt the UPOV Convention.

text.b: a) placing on the market of plant protection products;
b) setting up of maximum residue levels;
c) controls of maximum residue levels.

page.text: In the Republic of Macedonia, it is allowed to import and use only registered plant protection
products, appropriately packed, and legally declared and marked/labeled.
The procedure for registration of the plant protection products, according to the current legislation, is
divided in several phases or actions. The Ministry of Health is the competent institution for the first
phase of the procedure for registration of plant protection products, which performs this procedure
according to the provisions of the Law for Trade of Poisons (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 13/91).
Given that one portion of the plant protection products fall within certain poison group, one section of
the provisions of the Law on Trade of Poisons (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 13/91) regulates the
obligations and requirements related to plant protection products. This Law incorporates provisions
that refer to classification of poisons and labels. The poisons may not be released for trade if they are
not included on the list of poisons. This list is published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of
The procedure for determination of the group of poisons starts with a request submitted by the
producer of plant protection products, for appropriate toxicological assessment of plant protection
product. This is performed by institutions authorized by the Ministry of Health. Those authorized
institutions for performing toxicological assessment of the product and the documentation for active
substance are the Institute for Pre-clinic and Clinic Pharmacology with Toxicology and the Institute of
Applied Biochemistry – Department of a Applied Toxicology.
Based on the performed toxicological examinations of the plant protection product by the authorized
institution and the outcome, the producer submits a request for certificate for allocation of the plant
protection product in or out of the group of poisons. Besides the above, the Ministry of Health obtains
a positive recommendation from the Committee for Poisons. After the Ministry of Health issues this
certificate, the registration procedure of the plant protection product continues in the Ministry of
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy is competent for the following phase – the
registration – issuance of Permit for trade and application of plant protection product. For the purpose
of issuance of permit for plant protection product, there are mandatory examinations on physical,
biological and chemical properties, performed exclusively in authorized institutions.
The examination of physical and chemical properties is performed according to adopted methods of
the international organizations like WHO, FAO, OECD, EPA, EEA, EWRS, CIPAC, AOAC, and
methods indicated by the producer, and the biological examinations are performed by testing in the
open field (field testing), with a duration of 1 – 2 vegetation seasons, according to the standards and
methods of the European and Mediterranean Plant Protection Organization (EPPO).
After positive results and reports are returned, the producer or the party that has submitted the
request, submits request to the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy for a Permit for
trade and application of plant protection product.
Issuing this permit, besides the already mentioned, is performed upon accompanying positive
recommendation from the Committee for Plant Protection Product, established by the Minister of
Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy. The members of this Committee include representatives
of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, the Ministry of Health, experts from
scientific, technical and education institutions in the field of entomology, phyto-pathology, herbology
This Committee reviews the submitted documentation (the reports of authorized institutions, the
recommendation of the Committee for Poisons, the certificate for allocation of the plant protection
product in or out of the group of poisons as well as other related documentation) and proposes the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy to issue a permit for trade and application of
plant protection product on the Macedonian markets.
Next follows an administrative procedure for issuance of the permit by the Ministry of Agriculture,
Forestry and Water Economy. This permit is issued with a validity of 5 or 10 years, depending on
whether the active substance is already known or unknown. If the active substance is known, i.e. a
plant protection product that has been applied in the Republic of Macedonia for more than 20 years,
and it turned out to be efficient with no harmful side effects, then they issue a permit valid for 10
years. The plant protection products have to be properly packed for trade release, the label has to be
in Macedonian language, and other conditions that are in accordance with the provisions of the two
laws and rulebooks based on them, have to be fulfilled as well.
Detailed description of the procedure for registration of plant protection product is provided in the
Rulebook for Manner of Issuance of Permits for Release Trade of Plant Protection Product (“Official
Gazette of RM” No. 65/01 and 99/02), in one segment of the Rulebook that defines the conditions
that have to be fulfilled by legal entities that perform wholesale and retail trade with plant protection
The list of plant protection products that have permit for trade and application in the Republic of
Macedonia is officially published in the Official Gazette of Republic of Macedonia. In the final list of
registered plant protection products in the Republic of Macedonia, there are no registered plant
protection products that are forbidden according to the EU Directive 79/117/EEC.
Trade in plant protection product can be performed only by legal entities that fulfill certain conditions
related to facilities, equipment and technical personnel and they are entered in the register of legal
entities in the Plant Protection Directorate within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water
Economy. These conditions are regulated in the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM”
No. 25/98 and 06/00), and the Rulebook on conditions that have to be fulfilled by legal entities that
perform examinations of plant protection product (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 54/01).
According to the EU regulation, there should be only one state designated authority as a holder of the
procedure for registration of plant protection products and for coordination with other institutions
involved in this procedure, for assessment of the documentation related to plant protection products,.
Within CARDS 2002, the NIPS project secures technical assistance for preparation of a Law on Plant
Protection , which will fully regulate the plant protection products (it will unify the provisions related to
plant protection product of the current Law on Trade in Poisons - “Official Gazette of RM” No. 13/91,
and Law on Plant Protection - “Official Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 06/00, and will also unify the
procedures for assessment of documentation about plant protection products, its classification,
packing, labeling) aiming at approximation with the basic EU Directives (91/414/EEC and 99/45 EC).
According to the Law on Plant Protection (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 25/98 and 06/00) and the
Rulebook for Manner of Issuance of Permit and Release for Trade of Plant Protection Product, a
permit for a plant protection product can not be issued if maximum level of residues for it are not
defined (MRLs), as well as prohibition for use, specifically for each purpose and for each application.
The maximum allowed residue quantities of the plant protection products in food products are defined
Rulebook on quantities of pesticides and other poisonous product, hormones, antibiotics and
mycotoxins that can be found in foodstuffs (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 59/83 and 79/87)
The above mentioned rulebook refers to old substances. Because of this, the Ministry of Health set a
priority to prepare a rulebook for determination of maximum allowed amounts, where the EU
regulations are taken as a basis.
The institutional structure and the determination procedures will also be defined with the new Law on
This control is performed by the State Sanitary and Health Inspectorate within the Ministry of Health,
related to border monitoring and in the local units of the ministry. The competent inspectors take
samples according to their own judgment, or upon a request by legal entities or natural persons. The
Rulebook on Safety of Drinking Water requires taking 6 samples annually.
Analysis of residues is performed on organochlorine and organophosphorus pesticides,
carbamates and piretroids. A limiting factor for proper control of residues in foodstuffs is that the
laboratories do not have the necessary and sufficiently sophisticated equipment. That is exactly why
it is not possible to perform analysis of maximum allowed quantities for certain combinations of plant
protection products in foodstuffs. However, the number of samples is satisfactory, in quantitative
terms. Samples for analysis are taken and the procedures are implemented in accordance with some
more specific regulations that regulate the following:
the way the residue analysis is performed
criteria that the authorized laboratories have to fulfill, related to equipment and technical
Residue analysis is performed in the laboratories of the State Health Care Institute, regional
branches of the Institute in Skopje and Kumanovo, as well as in the Faculty of Veterinary Medicine.
These laboratories, operating on this working principle, took and analyzed on average 10,573 residue
samples in 2003, out of which 9,854 were from import, and the rest of 719 were of domestic origin.
The hygiene of fresh products of plant origin and raw material for processing, are not regulated by
any specific law. The hygiene is regulated by the Rulebook for Fruits, Vegetables and Mushrooms
Quality (“Official Gazette of SFRY” No. 29/79), which defines that these products can be released for
trade only if they fulfill the following conditions:
they are not dirty, wet or with mildew;
it does not contain residues of plant protection products in amounts higher then the allowed;
it does not contain unfamiliar and unpleasant flavor and smell and does not contain strange
it is not cracked, smashed, nor damaged by plant diseases and pests, if this Rulebook does
not specify otherwise for certain types and classes of fruits.

text.b: a) general architecture of the legal basis; organisation and powers of different institutions
b) respective field of responsibilities of competent authorities concerned.

page.text: Animal nutrition is regulated by two laws and secondary legislation under the competence of the
Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, as follows:
Law on Livestock (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 61/97);
Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98);
Rulebook on Quality of Feedingstuffs (“Official Gazette of SFRY”, No. 15/89 and 54/90);
Rulebook on Maximum Amounts of Harmful Substances and Ingredients in Feedingstuffs
Rulebook on Methods of Sample Taking and Methods of Physical, Chemical and
Microbiological Analysis of feedingstuffs (“Official Gazette of SFRY”, No. 15/87);
Rulebook on Veterinary-sanitary Control of Feedingstuffs and establishments for production
of feedingstuffs Conditions that Laboratories Performing Super-analysis Need to Fulfill
Rulebook on Maximum Allowed Content of Radionuclide in Feedingstuffs in Raw Material for
production of compound feedingstuff for Animal Nutrition and in drinking Water for animal and
Conditions Under Which They Can be Released for Trade and Used for Animal Nutrition if
Content of Radionuclide is Above Specified Limits (“Official Gazette of SFRY”, No. 16/92);
The competent authority within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy for
implementation of the legal regulations in the field of feedingstuffs include:
Authorized institutions and laboratories for examination of feedingstuffs are as follows:
Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food;
The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy, through its Department of Agriculture
performs supervision over the implementation of the provisions related to feeding stuffs in
accordance with the Law. The State Agriculture Inspectorate is the competent authority body for
inspection supervision related to quality control of concentrated feeding stuff in production and trade.
The Veterinary Directorate is the competent authority responsible for safety of feedingstuffs in
production, import, trade and use.. Inspection supervision and control is performed by the Veterinary
Inspection Unit, i.e. the state veterinary inspectors in the internal trade and at border inspection
The Faculty of Veterinary Medicine runs an authorized laboratory for examination of veterinary and
The Institute for Livestock and the Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and Food run laboratories
authorized for analysis, i.e. super-analysis of quality of feeding stuff.
According to the Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 61/97), use of feedingstuffs that
endangers the health of animals, or that endangers human health through products of animal origin,
is not allowed for animal nutrition.
According to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), marketing of non
safety feedingstuffs is forbidden. Feedingstuffs is unsafe if: it contains pathogenic microorganisms or
parasites that could harmfully affect the animal health, or if it contains disallowed volume of
saprophytic microorganisms or their metabolites (endo-toxins and egzo-toxins); if it contains
hormones, sedatives, thyreostatics, disallowed content of antibiotics or pesticides, fungicides,
rodenticides or other pharmaceutical means, salts of non-organic material, radioactive material, as
well as other material harmful for animal health; if it is organoleptically changed; if the content is
inappropriate, which affects its biological value and usability, if the expiry date (validity) stated in the
declaration has passed, and if the salt for animal nutrition does not contain iodine.
A special Rulebook on feed additives regulates the production, registration, trade and use of feed
additives. This rulebook regulates the following: categories and functional groups of feed additives;
conditions that the feed additives have to fulfill in order to be registered; procedure for assessment of
compliance and registration of feed additives , their declaration/labeling, as well as the marketing and
Depending on the function and characteristics/features, the feed additives are categorized in one or
more of the following categories and functional groups of additives:
1. Technological additives are all the substances added into feedingstuffs for technological purposes,
a. Preservatives: substances, or, if possible, microorganisms that prevent the feed from
decay caused by microorganisms or their metabolites;
b. antioxidants: substances that extend the warehousing period of the feedingstuffs and
nutritional material, and their protection from decay with oxidation;
c. mulsificators: substances that allow or support blending of homogeneous volumes of two
d. stabilizers: substances that support the physical and chemical stability of feedingstuffs ;
e. thickeners: substances that strengthen the viscosity of feedingstuffs ;
f. gel-making substances: substances that give the feedingstuffs a structure of gel;
g. binders: substances that increase the adhesive tendency/property of parts of feedingstuffs
h. substances that perform suppression of radionuclide or support their excretion;
i. substances that decrease tendency for separate lumping of feedingstuffs, that would stick
regulators of acidity: substances that regulate the pH value of;
k. silage additives: substances, including enzymes or microorganisms, intended for adding
into feedingstuffs in order to improve the production of silage;
m. substances that, when used for production of feedingstuffs, allow for identification of origin
of specific feedingstuffs or nutritional material;
2. Sensor additives are those substances, the addition of which to feedingstuffs improves or
changes the organoleptic properties of the feedingstuffs , or improves or changes the visual
properties of the feed of animal origin, with the following functional groups:
substances added or returned back to feedingstuffs;
substances that when added to feedingstuffs during animal nutrition, give a color to it;
substances that favorize the effect of color of decorative fish or birds;
b. admixtures of spices: substances that when added to feedingstuffs, improve the odor/smell
3. Nutritive additives are substances that are added to feedingstuffs in order to improve its nutritional
a. vitamins, pro-vitamins, and well determined chemical substances that feature similar effects;
4. Zoo-technical additives are those additives that are used in order to favorably affect the animal
performances related to their health condition, or positively affect the environment, with the following
a. enhancement of digestion: substances that assist in better feed digestion in animal
nutrition, through specific performance of certain nutritional material;
b. stabilizers of good flora: microorganisms or their chemically determined substances, that
positively affect the animal flora during nutrition;
c. substances that positively affect the environment;
In order to be registered, the feed additives are required to fulfill the following conditions:
to have no harmful effect on animal health, human health and environment;
to not be presented in a way that might confuse the user;
to not damage the user by deteriorating the properties of products of animal origin, or to
confuse the user about certain properties of products of animal origin;
They also need to possess one or more of the following characheristics :
to positively affect the properties of feedingstuffs;
to satisfy the nutritional needs of animals;
to positively affect the livestock production, animal welfare and performances, in particular by
affecting the intestinal flora or digestion properties of the feedingstuffs ;
to positively affect the properties of products of animal origin;
to favorably affect the color of ornamental fish or birds;
to positively affect the environment from livestock production perspective;
to yield coccidiostatic or histomonistatic effect.
With the exception of coccidiostatics and histomonistatics, antibiotics will not be registered as
feedingstuffs additives, in accordance with this Rulebook.
According to the Action Plan for European Partnership of the Government of the Republic of
Macedonia 2004, preparation of a Law on Feedingstuffs (Veterinary aspects) is envisaged during the
fourth quarter of 2005, which will be approximated with the legislation of the European Union.
The trade of compaund feedingstuffs is regulated by two legal acts: the Livestock Law (“Official
Gazette of RM” No, 61/97), and the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM ” No 28/98).
Pursuant to the on Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM” No 61/97), production of compound
feedingstuffs (aimed for trade) may be performed by legal person if particular conditions prescribed
by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy are fulfilled.
Compound feedingstuffs that is put into circulation must possess prescribed declaration on the
packaging and the accompanying accounting document, where main data on the quality and quantity
are filled in, and it must be in compliance with the data declared.
Legal persons who produce bulky feedingstuffs aimed for trade are obliged to control the quality of
their products beginning from the production process until to putting into circulation.
Only feedingstuffs that fulfils prescribed conditions regarding the content and quality is put into
circulation. Usage of feedingsuffs which poses a threat to animal's health, or through consumption of
product of animal origin to human health, is not permitted.
Regarding content and quality, imported feedingstuff aimed for trade must fulfil the same conditions
as feedingstuffs produced in the Republic of Macedonia.
Pursuant to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No 28/98), legal persons engaged
in production and trade of feedingstuffs must provide safety feedingstuffs Before putting into
circulation, legal persons registered for production and processing of feedingstruffs are obliged to
perform laboratory analyses in order to determine the feedingstuffs safety. Putting on market non
safety feeding stuff is forbidden. Regular veterinary sanitary inspection is also carried out at the
facilities for production, processing, storing and trade of feedingstuffs, and in case of infective
disease suspicion, control of feedingstuff located in the yards of animal owners is also carried out.
Import of feedingstuff is permitted by the Minister of Agriculture, Forestry and Water, after
establishing in each individual case that no veterinary sanitary obstacles exist for its import, transit
and storing according to provisions referred to in the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of
RM” No 28/98). This permition also determines veterinary-sanitary conditions for import and transit
and calls for the importer to submit the consignment for investigation, or orders other measures. The
consignment must be accompanied by an international veterinary-sanitary certificate.
The method of packing, transporting and keeping of feedingstuffs is regulated by the Rulebook on
Feedstuffs Quality. Feedstuff may be transported and kept in a bulk or packed in appropriate
packaging. The wrapping material of the feedingstuff must ensure originality of the packaging.
Transportation is carried out in closed vehicles by railway, land, marine or river traffic, and on shorter
destinations use of open vehicles is permitted. Means of transportation must be cleaned and
prepared so that contamination of feedingstuffs is prevented. The feedingstruffs can be stored in the
wrapping material or out of it, in clean, dry and ventilated spaces, in order to prevent warming,
burning and spoiling. This space must be free of pests, plant protective materials as well as of other
materials that may poison or contaminate the feedingstuffs
The trade of feed materials is regulated pursuant to the Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM ” No
61/97) and the Rulebook on feedstuff quality (“Official Gazette of SFRY ”No 15/89
This Rulebook determines the raw materials of plant, mineral, and animal origin which may be used
in animal nutrition as well as the conditions regarding the quality to be fulfilled.
Legal entities which produce bulky feedingstruffs aimed for trade are obliged to carry out quality
control in the production process before putting it into circulation.
Raw materials for use in animal nutrition are put into circulation if their composition and quality fulfil
prescribed conditions. Using raw materials which endanger animal health , or which, through
products of animal origine may endanger humans health is not permitted for use in animal nutrition .
Imported raw materials for production of feedingstruffs intended for trade, regarding its content and
quality, must fulfil the same conditions as raw materials for production of feedingstruffs produced in
According to the Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 61/9), use of feedingstuffs that
endangers the animal health, or that endangers the human health through products of animal origin,
is not allowed for animal nutrition/feeding.
According to the Law on Veterinary Health (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 28/98), trade and use of
unsafe feedingstuffs is forbidden. Feedingstuffs is unsafe if it contains, inter alia, pathogenic
microorganisms or parasites that could harmfully affect the animal health, or if it contains unallowed
volume of saprophytic microorganisms or their metabolites (endo-toxins and egzo-toxins); if it
contains hormones, sedatives, thyreostatics, unallowed content of antibiotics or pesticides,
fungicides, rodenticides or other pharmaceutical means, salts of non-organic material, radioactive
material, as well as other material harmful for animal health.
Undesirable substances in feedingstuffs are regulated by means of Guideline for ban of utilization of
feedingstuffs for animal nutrition that contains undesirable substances. This Guideline forbids
production, trade and utilization of feedingstuffs, raw material for production of feedingstuffs and
other products for animal nutrition, hat contain the following:
undesirable substances and products or their metabolites above the maximum allowed
non-organic material above maximum allowed content;
indicators of chemical disintegration above maximum allowed values;
saprophytic microorganisms above maximum allowed number;
pathogenic microorganisms above maximum allowed number;
toxins of toxic bacteria in 1 gram (Clostridum botulinum, Clostridium perfrinegens and
toxins and toxic fungi above maximum allowed number;
poisonous plants and parasitic fungi above maximum allowed amounts.
According to the Action Plan for European Partnership of the Government of the Republic of
Macedonia 2004, it has been envisaged to prepare a Law on Feedingstuffs (Veterinary aspects) ,
during the fourth quarter of 2005, which will be approximated with the legislation of the European

text.b: 12. Feedingstuffs intended for particular nutritional purposes.

page.text: At present, feedingstuffs intended for special nutritional purposes is not regulated in the current
The issue of feedingstuffs for special nutritional purposes will be regulated by the revised Livestock
Law (“Official Gazette of RM”, No. 61/97), and by the enacting of the Law on Feedingstuffs

text.b: 13. Certain products used in animal nutrition.

page.text: The products used in animal nutrition are regulated by the Rulebook on Feedingstuffs Quality
(“Official Gazette of SFRY”, No. 15/89 and 54/90). Nutriments are products of vegetable, animal and
mineral origin, produced naturally or industrially, and are not harmful for the health of humans and
animals. Nutriments could be in the following forms:
products and auxiliary products that come out of milling processing;
auxiliary products of the starch industry;
auxiliary products of the industry for alcohol and fermentation;
auxiliary products of the industry for consumable oils;
nutriments with addition of non-protein nitrogen based compounds;
The issue of certain products that are used in animal nutrition are additionally regulated by the
Livestock Law (“Official Gazette of RM”, No. 61/97), and with the enacting of the Law on
An Order for prohibition for use of proteins of animal origin in domesticated animals’ nutrition has
been made in June 2001, and it specifically forbids use of proteins and processed animal proteins
(meat bone meal, meat meal, bone meal, blood meal, dried plasma and other products of blood
origin, hydrolyzed proteins, meal derived out of hoofs and horns, meat meal out of poultry internal
organs, meat out of feathers, dry bones, fish meal, di-calcium phosphate and other related proteins of
animal origin), including premixes, feedingstuffs , feed additives and compound feedingstuffs that
contain them, in the nutrition of animal that are farmed for production for food . The ban does not
refer to milk and dairy products for animal nutrition, fish meal for nutrition of other domestic animals
except ruminants; and di-calcium phosphate and hydrolyzed proteins for nutrition of other domestic

text.b: 14. Conditions governing the preparation, placing on the market and use of medicated

page.text: The preparation, releasing for trade and utilization of feedingstuffs that contains medicated l premixes
is not regulated in the current legislation of the Republic of Macedonia.
According to the European Partnership Action Plan of the Government of the Republic of Macedonia
2004, it is foreseen to have a Law on Feedingstuffs (Veterinary aspects) enacted, in the fourth
quarter of 2005, to be approximated with the legislation of the European Union.
The field of medicated premixes is regulated by the Law on Drugs, Additional Medicines and Medical
Instruments (“Official Gazette of RM” No. 21/98). Pharmacologically active substances added to the
feedingstuffs or water in the form of premixes can only be released for trade after previously obtained
license for releasing for trade received from the competent body of the administration – the
Veterinary Directorate within the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Water Economy.
The procedure for obtaining a license is regulated in several consecutive phases. The Veterinary
